headline: No-Mess Chocolate . . .
abstract: LEAD: Long years of monkeying with mousses at a Geneva laboratory has produced for the Battelle Memorial Institute a chocolate that will not melt in hot weather.

headline: GRACE'S ENVIRONMENT CHIEF: Hugh L. Carey; An Old Pol Tackles a New Post
abstract: LEAD: WHEN W. R. Grace & Company hired New York's former Governor, Hugh L. Carey, in December to head its new Office of Environmental Policy, the move caused barely a public ripple. But speculation has been lively among competitors and shareholders. Why, they wonder, would Grace, which has endured more than its share of depressed profits and job cuts this decade, fork over $400,000 a year to a 69-year-old lawyer with no recent corporate experience?

headline: Market Place; Clamor for Zenith To Sell a Division
abstract: LEAD: AS losses have mounted at the Zenith Electronics Corporation's consumer electronics division, investors have begun putting pressure on the last major American manufacturer of televisions to sell its troubled unit.

headline: NICARAGUAN SEEKS NEW CONTRA TALKS
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra called today for new peace talks with United States-backed rebels but warned that approval of fresh American military funds for the rebels would be ''totally unacceptable.''

headline: Tough Sanctions Against Pretoria Are Sought by House Democrats
abstract: LEAD: Democratic leaders in the House of Representatives are pressing hard for a sweeping trade embargo against South Africa and a ban on virtually all American business investment in that country.

headline: Salomon Earnings Up 16.1% in First Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Salomon Inc., the parent of one of Wall Street's largest securities firms, announced yesterday that its first-quarter earnings increased 16.1 percent.

headline: 3 States Study Pepperell Bid
abstract: LEAD: The offices of the attorneys general of New York, South Carolina and North Carolina said yesterday that they were investigating the antitrust implications of a possible merger of West Point-Pepperell Inc. and the J.P. Stevens Company, two makers of designer sheets and towels. Stevens, citing regulatory hurdles, favors a rival bid from Odyssey Partners, an investment firm.

headline: Gillette Alters Bylaws In Coniston Dispute
abstract: LEAD: The Gillette Company has amended its bylaws in an effort to limit the power of candidates backed by Coniston Partners in the event the nominees succeed in gaining seats on the board, the company said yesterday.

headline: Rice Output Rise Seen
abstract: LEAD: The world's output of rice is headed up, led by sharply expanded planting in the United States, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. American production is expected to increase by 23 percent this year from 1987.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Executive Hired by G.M.
abstract: LEAD: General Motors has hired Shirley Young, long Grey Advertising's premier consumer researcher, as vice president of consumer market development.

headline: Company News; Kuwait Won't Buy Larger B.P. Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Kuwait Investment Office has agreed not to increase its 22 percent stake in the British Petroleum Company pending a British Government inquiry into its holding, the Government said. In cases where the Government investigates share holdings, Britain routinely asks investors involved not to buy more stock.

headline: Taiwan Grants Asylum to Two Who Hijacked Mainland Jet
abstract: LEAD: Two Chinese men, seeking to defect, hijacked a domestic airliner from the mainland to Taiwan on Thursday. They were granted asylum, and the jet took the other 116 people aboard back to China early today.

headline: How One Company Will Cope
abstract: LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company has been developing new systems for assembling and interpreting marketing data. It is in the process of automating much of the processing of this data. Anthony Adams, vice president of market research, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about how Campbell Soup will manage its marketing data.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.  Economic and Social Council  COMMISSION ON U.N. INTERGOVERNMENTAL STRUCTURE AND FUNCTIONS IN ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL FIELDS - 10 A.M.  UNITED NATIONS CHILDREN'S FUND - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Publishers Add Zeros To Book Bids
abstract: LEAD: Only a few years after vowing never again to throw big bucks after big books, the publishing industry is spending huge sums in pursuit of authors. And while the risks are as enormous as they used to be, the way the big money is spent today is significantly different.

headline: Malaysian Jailing of 4 Hurts Women's Cause
abstract: LEAD: They are an unlikely gang of four: two social workers and two church workers committed to the struggle for women's rights and social change in Malaysia.

headline: Rising Aluminum Prices Spur Oversupply Fears
abstract: LEAD: Economists and industry analysts have expressed concern that surging aluminum prices will encourage producing countries to increase their capacity further, which could lead to an oversupply in the future.

headline: Market Place; Specialists Seek Deeper Pockets
abstract: LEAD: IN the wake of October's stock market collapse, the nature of the specialist system at the New York Stock Exchange appears to be changing as old-line partnerships are acquired by large investment banks. Several acquisitions have been made in the last six months, and talks are under way about a number of other deals.

headline: India-Penney Sales Drive Set
abstract: LEAD: India, seeking to increase its share of the garment market in the United States, will soon begin its biggest American sales promotion drive ever, an Indian official said today. The executive director of the

headline: Business and Health; Nursing Shortage Is Costing Billions
abstract: LEAD: AN ACUTE shortage of nurses in hospitals and nursing homes has added billions of dollars to the nation's escalating expenditures for health care.

headline: Suzuki Defending Samurai Against Safety Complaints
abstract: LEAD: A week after Consumer Reports magazine judged the Samurai utility vehicle ''not acceptable'' and urged that it be recalled, the Suzuki Motor Company is poised to strike back with its own test analyses and a new advertising campaign in support of its contention that its vehicle is safe.

headline: Haitian Says Drive on Drugs Led to His Ouster as Leader
abstract: LEAD: Leslie F. Manigat, deposed by the military as President of Haiti last Sunday, said today that the main reason for his ouster was the resistance of the army and police to his efforts to curb corruption and drug trafficking to the United States.

headline: The Credit Card Wars
abstract: LEAD: THE New York Stock Exchange was threatened. With its slow, anachronistic trading methods it was losing business to a new, competing market.

headline: Flight Plan for Berlin
abstract: LEAD: A proposed joint-venture airline operated by Air France and Lufthansa could begin flights to West Berlin by November if the plan is accepted, a senior Lufthansa executive said today. But Frank Beckmann, a member of Lufthansa's executive board and the West German carrier's marketing director, acknowledged the proposal was controversial because Lufthansa is not permitted to fly to Berlin under an agreement signed by the Allies after World War II.

headline: DATA BANK: May 22, 1988
abstract: LEAD:           THE ECONOMY               Gross National Product   I Q'88   IV Q'87   Year Ago        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $3,902.6   $3,880.8   $3,735.2               Real G.N.P. headline: Sandinistas Said to Prepare an Attack
abstract: LEAD: United States and Honduran officials say Nicaraguan forces appear to be preparing to attack the contras if cease-fire talks fail to produce a negotiated settlement to the civil war.

headline: Xerox to Eliminate 800 Marketing Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The Xerox Corporation, the giant copier company, said that its United States marketing group would eliminate about 800 jobs. The company said that as many employees as possible would be reassigned to other Xerox operations and that it hoped to avoid layoffs.

headline: Market Place; Blue Skies Seen In Steel Industry
abstract: LEAD: THE Bethlehem Steel Corporation's announcement last week of a public offering of 10 million of its common shares at $19 each is viewed as a sign not only of the attractiveness of steel stocks but also of the relative prosperity of basic industry.

headline: Proposal to Dismiss Charges Against Noriega Is Assailed
abstract: LEAD: An Administration proposal to drop all drug-related charges against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega if he leaves power in Panama was sharply criticized today by members of Congress, law-enforcement officials and Panamanian opposition leaders.

headline: VIETNAM LEADERS MEET WITH GANDHI
abstract: LEAD: India's Prime Minister, Rajiv Gandhi, met Vietnam's new Communist Party leader for the first time here today to discuss relations between the two countries and ways to help resolve the nine-year war in Cambodia, according to diplomats following the talks.

headline: New Sun Models Blur Computer Distinctions
abstract: LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc., the fast-growing maker of engineering work stations, will move a step closer to the personal computer market Wednesday when it introduces a family of machines based on a microprocessor used in some advanced personal computers.

headline: South African Rebel Commander: A Portrait in Erudition and Ruthlessness
abstract: LEAD: With his tailored clothes and suave manners, Martin Thembisile Hani looks more like a prospering business executive than the chief of staff of Umkhonto we Sizwe, the military wing of the African National Congress.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * JoAnn Fraser has been elected senior vice president, management supervisor at Saatchi & Saatchi DFS/ San Francisco.

headline: U.S. Law Firms Expand To Reach Global Clientele
abstract: LEAD: Coudert Brothers, a Park Avenue law firm, earlier this year sent a partner to practice full time in Moscow. Shortly before that, Baker & McKenzie, the mammoth Chicago firm with more than 1,000 lawyers, established offices in Budapest and Barcelona. And Kelley Drye & Warren has hired a New Delhi lawyer to serve clients with Indian interests.

headline: Unocal Names Chief Executive
abstract: LEAD: Fred L. Hartley, chairman and chief executive of the Unocal Corporation since 1960, will retire as chief executive and be succeeded by Richard J. Stegemeier, the company said today.

headline: Loan Unit Sets $200 Million Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Credithrift Financial Corporation, the consumer loan subsidiary of the American General Corporation, is offering $200 million in debt securities through a two-part financing.

headline: Colgate Plans Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company said that it was putting its Kendall Health Care unit up for sale in keeping with its strategy of concentrating on the company's consumer products businesses. Reuben Mart, chairman and chief executive of the New York-based company, said the sale would ''provide Colgate with significantly greater financial flexibility'' to build up its consumer products businesses and reduce debt.

headline: PUNJABIS DISBAND SECRET MILITANTS
abstract: LEAD: The Punjab Government has disbanded and disarmed a group of Sikh extremists that it had financed and armed for several months to attack and confront other militants, a top security official said today.

headline: J.P. Stevens Truce May Collapse
abstract: LEAD: A three-day truce in the $1.2 billion takeover battle for J. P. Stevens & Company seemed in danger of collapse yesterday, unless a solution can be found to major problems raised by its directors.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
abstract: LEAD: The Fox Broadcasting Company, which is trying to start a fourth major television network, is likely to lose $80 million this year, $30 million more than it had anticipated, the chief financial officer of the News Corporation, has predicted.

headline: Del Webb Casino To Golden Nugget
abstract: LEAD: The Del Webb Corporation said that it would sell the Nevada Club, a hotel and casino in Laughlin, Nev., to the Las Vegas casino operator Golden Nugget Inc. for $40 million. The sale is the first under a restructuring plan proposed by Del Webb, based in Phoenix, in March to shed its leisure businesses and refocus around its real estate operations.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly

headline: Echoes of Vietnam; A Superpower Is Desperate to Leave, But in Afghanistan It Is the Russians
abstract: LEAD: Only a few weeks ago, the Reagan Administration seemed to be risking failure in the Afghan peace talks - insisting, because its conservative supporters in the Senate insisted, on the right to keep supplying the insurgents with weapons after a Soviet withdrawal began, despite an earlier pledge to cut them off.

headline: Oil Investments By Abu Dhabi
abstract: LEAD: The emirate of Abu Dhabi plans to make substantial investments in foreign oil companies as a safeguard against oil price fluctuations, an industry official said today. Khalifa Mohammed al-

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Arnell Bickford Gains 2 More Assignments
abstract: LEAD: Arnell Bickford has again been visited by the new-business fairy, who gave the shop two taps with her wand on a weekend visit.

headline: Municipal Bond Dealers Seek Timely Disclosures
abstract: LEAD: The Public Securities Association said Friday that a survey of municipal bond dealers showed widespread dissatisfaction about the availability of official statements for new and old bond issues.

headline: Tokyo Journal; Shinto Is Thrust Back Onto the Nationalist Stage
abstract: LEAD: When militant nationalists ruled in the first half of the century, Japan's native Shinto religion was the core of official ideology.

headline: Moscow Says Its Force In War Was 100,300
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union had 100,300 troops in Afghanistan at the start of its military withdrawal earlier this month, a senior army official announced today.

headline: Sinking-Fund Debt From Westvaco
abstract: LEAD: The Westvaco Corporation, a paper and wood products company, is offering $100 million worth of sinking-fund debentures due in 2018 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Philip Morris Offers 9% Issue
abstract: LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies is offering $350 million of 9 percent notes due in 1998 at a price of 99.50 to yield 9.11 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Bankers Insurance Group Inc., Miami, said it had agreed to sell its Financial Insurance Group Ltd. unit to Allegiance Capital Partners for $:39.8 million, or $74 million, in cash and debt.

headline: Pope Picks High-Level Group To Go to Moscow Church Fete
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican announced today that Pope John Paul II, hoping to open ''new paths'' for peace in the world, had named a delegation to attend a major religious celebration in Moscow that will be the largest group of Roman Catholic Church leaders ever to visit the Soviet Union.

headline: For Computers, the Year 2000 May Prove a Bit Traumatic
abstract: LEAD: The dawn of the new century may come as a shock to thousands of computers around the world. Programs that record years in two digits and know no time but the 1900's may be stymied by the year 2000.

headline: The Boom in Real Estate Auctions
abstract: LEAD: HAVE you ever been tempted by advertisements for real estate auctions that promise a steal of a deal - the chance to purchase a ski condominium in Vail or a town house on the Florida coast for 50 cents on the dollar? If so, you're not alone. Thousands of potential buyers have been flocking to real estate auctions from coast to coast recently, as auctioneers try to upgrade the industry's image.

headline: Market Place; A Merger Flurry Among Utilities?
abstract: LEAD: SOME utility experts expect that heightened competition will spark a flurry of takeovers among electric utilities in the next five years, forcing a realignment of what has been a fragmented industry of regional companies.

headline: China Seeks GATT Tie
abstract: LEAD: China has made its case for readmission to the international trade body GATT, saying it no longer has a centrally planned economy and is reforming its system of foreign trade, GATT delegates said today.

headline: German's Red Square Plane Offered for Sale
abstract: LEAD: Mathias Rust may still be in a Soviet prison cell, but the single-engine plane he put down next to Red Square in Moscow a year ago has basked in a bit of celebrity since the Russians let it out of custody six months ago.

headline: The Drive to Speed Automation
abstract: LEAD: The world's leading industrial companies and engineering bodies came to a Baltimore convention center last week to spend a few days making something no one needed - 4,000 desktop holders for business cards and pens.

headline: Top Negotiator Wants to Continue U.S. Efforts to Drive Noriega Out
abstract: LEAD: The State Department official who led the abortive negotiations with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, said today that removing him from power ''will not be an overnight occurrence.''

headline: Estimated Cost Of Pipeline Cut
abstract: LEAD: Technological advances and an improved economic climate have helped cut the estimated cost of a proposed pipeline by $11.5 billion, according to American and Canadian pipeline executives.

headline: Bonds and Notes Little Changed
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed in quiet trading yesterday, as market participants once again shrugged off a big upward move in commodity prices.

headline: Tesoro-Pentane
abstract: LEAD: The Tesoro Petroleum Corporation said that its board of directors had rejected a takeover offer from Pentane Partners L.P., calling it deficient and not in the shareholders' interest. Under the proposal, Tesoro's common shareholders other than Pentane would exchange their shares, totaling 66.9 percent of Tesoro, for 34.6 percent of the surviving corporation plus $6 a share, Tesoro said.

headline: A Slow Beginning For an I.B.M. System
abstract: LEAD: Software is now being sold that is designed to run with OS/2, the operating system introduced last fall by the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation, a major software publisher. But analysts say the new products fall short of tapping OS/2's vast potential.

headline: Griffin Bell Defends Inquiry In Hutton Overdraft Scheme
abstract: LEAD: Griffin B. Bell, the former Attorney General, has been initiated into a new realm of the law: he is defending himself against a lawsuit.

headline: Advertising; Lord, Geller Fills 2 Posts In Top Rank
abstract: LEAD: DEPLETED high and low by defections, the staff of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein is getting an infusion of management talent.

headline: Iran Seeking Oil Cutbacks
abstract: LEAD: The oil minister of Iran, Gholam Reza Aghazadeh, arrived here today, apparently seeking support for a reduction in oil output in advance of the June meeting of the ministerial council of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

headline: Good Friday in Israel: Holy Rites and 2 More Deaths
abstract: LEAD: Along the Via Dolorosa, Christian pilgrims walked the Stations of the Cross today on what was to all appearances a sunny and peaceful Good Friday. But there was a brief clash outside a mosque elsewhere in Jerusalem and two more Palestinians were killed near Hebron after firebombs were reportedly hurled at

headline: Taiwan's Gold Imports Surge
abstract: LEAD: Flush with cash, Taiwan is rapidly becoming a leading gold importer, bullion dealers said today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Bankers Trust Co., a subsidiary of Bankers Trust New York Corp., said its international private bank unit had acquired Wells Fargo Bank's international private banking business. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: 3 Bomb Attacks in Greece
abstract: LEAD: Two bombs exploded in the Athens suburb of Nikaia early today, and a third was thrown from a car in the port of Piraeus. There were no injuries, the police said. All three attacks were claimed by a local left-wing terrorist group, Revolutionary Popular Struggle.

headline: The Fine Art of Managing Corporate Memories
abstract: LEAD: IN 1979, Philip Cantelon, president of History Associates, was doing research for a book at the National Archives, when he overheard a Texas state official complaining that he could not find someone to write a cartographic history of part of the state's coastline. Mr. Cantelon offered to take on the project, and the rest is, well, history.

headline: Hijackers of Jet Went to Syria, Arab Aides Say
abstract: LEAD: Arab officials said today that the hijackers of the Kuwait Airways plane left Algiers early Wednesday and were flown on a private Algerian jet to Damascus, Syria. The officials said the hijackers were then believed to have traveled overland to Beirut, Lebanon.

headline: Toy Maker Has Financing Pact
abstract: LEAD: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the once high-flying toy maker now in bankruptcy proceedings, said today that its chairman would resign as part of a financing agreement with its banks and creditors.

headline: France and Iran Restoring Diplomatic Ties Today
abstract: LEAD: After 11 months of confrontation, hostility and secret negotiations, France and Iran announced today that they would re-establish diplomatic relations on Thursday.

headline: High Schools in West Bank Are Reopened by the Israelis
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army reopened high schools today for 36,000 students in the West Bank and freed more than 100 Palestinian teen-agers from jail so they could attend classes.

headline: Jerusalem Journal; Palestinians' Bete Noire: How Will He Play in U.S.?
abstract: LEAD: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin is to leave this week for a visit to the United States, where he will meet with senior Government officials and leaders of American Jewish organizations. By Mr. Rabin's own account, ''I'm not expecting very much applause.''

headline: Ford's Probe Gets Fast Start
abstract: LEAD: The sporty 1989 Ford Probe, built for the Ford Motor Company by its Japanese partner, the Mazda Motor Company, will make its debut this week with enough advance orders to fill production schedules until October, Ford officials said today.

headline: Halliburton Revises Terms for Gearhart
abstract: LEAD: The Halliburton Company and Gearhart Industries have revised the terms of Halliburton's proposed acquisition of Gearhart to give Gearhart creditors an additional $6 million. The restructuring would not change the value of the transaction, worth approximately $295.5 million in cash, stock and assumable debt, Halliburton's head of investor relations, Guy T.

headline: Greek Terrorists Admit Killing of U.S. Attache
abstract: LEAD: A Greek terrorist organization blamed for previous assassinations of American diplomats claimed responsibility today for a car bombing that killed the United States military attache as he drove to work.

headline: Rise of 0.9% in Area Costs Highest in Four Years
abstract: LEAD: Consumer prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in April, the highest monthly increase in four years, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Matchbox Toys Account To Berenter Greenhouse
abstract: LEAD: Berenter Greenhouse & Webster reported yesterday that it had been assigned the $12 million Matchbox Toys account. The former agency is Saatchi & Saatchi's AC&R/DHB & Bess, and Stephen Rose, its chief executive, said Matchbox had yet to inform his agency.

headline: Texaco Says It Is Talking With Icahn
abstract: LEAD: Texaco Inc. announced yesterday that it was engaged in talks with Carl C. Icahn, its largest shareholder, in an effort to resolve their differences over the company's future.

headline: Senators Seeking to Overhaul War Powers Resolution
abstract: LEAD: The Senate majority leader and senior members of key Senate committees introduced legislation today to overhaul the War Powers Resolution, a 1973 law originally intended to give Congress a greater policy voice when American troops are introduced into hostile situations short of full-scale war.

headline: I.B.M.'s New Line
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new line of high-performance products that allow customers to turn their typewriters into modified word processors. The Wheelwriter 10, 30, 50 and 70 all include spelling aids while the 50 and 70 have 25-line screen display. They include options to expand memory to 720,000 bytes with a diskette drive.

headline: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase 6.9% on Nasdaq
abstract: LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 6.9 percent rise in the number of shares sold short that have not yet been covered among the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

headline: Latvians Said to Demonstrate To Mark Deportations of 40's
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of people demonstrated in Soviet Latvia today to mark the anniversary of mass deportations from the Baltic republic under Stalin, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

headline: Drug Case Raises Doubts in Bolivia
abstract: LEAD: The recent dismissal of charges against 16 Bolivians in a cocaine-related murder has raised questions about the ability of the justice system to resist the pressures of drug traffickers.

headline: Travelers Is Hurt in Real Estate
abstract: LEAD: The Travelers Corporation, the nation's sixth-largest insurance company, is struggling to limit the damage from a growing portfolio of troubled real estate loans that is already depressing its earnings.

headline: Beer's Shelf Life ...
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Hawker Siddeley To Buy Von Weise
abstract: LEAD: Hawker Siddeley Group P.L.C. said it had agreed to buy the Von Weise Gear Company of St. Clair, Mo., for $:13 million ($23.5 million) in cash. Von Weise, a subsidiary of American Technical Industries, is among the leading United States makers of fractional horsepower gear motors and gear reducers, and it supplies medical, dental, food processing and ice-making equipment.

headline: Newspaper Publishers Note Gains
abstract: LEAD: Though it has been a rough year at some of the nation's dailies, members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association were mostly celebrating the industry's considerable prosperity as they began their annual convention today.

headline: Market Place; Optimism Grows On I.B.M. Outlook
abstract: LEAD: HAS the International Business Machines Corporation turned the corner? Last week I.B.M. shares made their strongest move upward since the market's October crash, and many analysts say that, after three years of declining earnings, the computer giant is ready for growth again.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Charles W. Schmid has been named senior vice president of marketing at the Miller Brewing Co., Milwaukee.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 7, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Yields Show Little Change
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were unchanged to slightly higher for the week ended yesterday.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: In the tax-exempt market, Iowa is offering $130 million of tax and revenue anticipation notes through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, which submitted the winning bid on the competitive issue.

headline: Companero Paul, of Harvard Law
abstract: LEAD: As the search for peace in Nicaragua has intensified, Paul S. Reichler, an American lawyer who advises the Sandinista Government, has emerged as a key political figure here.

headline: First Russian Column Leaves Afghanistan
abstract: LEAD: The first Soviet troop convoy to withdraw from Afghanistan crossed the border into the Soviet Union this morning.

headline: Amfac Adopts 'Poison Pill' Plan
abstract: LEAD: Amfac Inc., the hotel, retail and Hawaiian real estate concern, said its directors had adopted a ''poison pill'' to ''protect against abusive takeover tactics.'' Amfac's defensive measure would go into effect if any party acquires 15 percent or more of the company's stock or begins a tender offer.

headline: Noriega Reported to Discuss Stepping Down
abstract: LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has been holding indirect conversations with opposition groups, apparently to find a formula allowing him to step down with his wealth and his dignity intact, opposition figures and diplomats say.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agency Sells One-on-One Marketing
abstract: LEAD: RAPP & COLLINS, one of the better direct-marketing agencies, has won eight accounts in the last 12 months. Six came in as the result of the book ''Maximarketing,'' written by Stan Rapp and Tom Collins and published by McGraw-Hill in November 1986.

headline: Advanced U.S. Cruiser Enters Persian Gulf
abstract: LEAD: The United States Navy has introduced to the Persian Gulf one of its billion-dollar Aegis cruisers, among its most sophisticated warships.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Vicki Mondae has been elected senior vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Bradford National Life Insurance Co., Lexington, Ky., an operating unit of Whitehall Financial Group, named William F. Healy president and chief executive, succeeding Ronald S. Scowby, who will become president and chief executive of the parent company, while remaining a Bradford director.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.  Monday

headline: Contras Spurn Proposal by Sandinistas
abstract: LEAD: The Sandinista Government offered a peace proposal today that called on contra guerrillas to give up their arms by June 28, but the contras turned it down.

headline: Advertising; Commercial Makers' Unions in Tentative Pact
abstract: LEAD: Advertising industry representatives announced yesterday that a tentative agreement had been reached with the talent unions that have been on strike for three weeks, curtailing the making of commercials. Although the agreement was reached on Saturday, details of the agreement will not be made public until the unions vote on it this week.

headline: At Bengali School: Slates, Then Land to Till
abstract: LEAD: It took just five minutes to memorize her homework poem, said Nazma Akhtar proudly, and she can recite it so fast that the words run together in a flash of 10-year-old enthusiasm:  Orange flower, orange flower,  Flower of orange,  Orange flower will get married  With emeralds in her ears.

headline: Apple's Chief Takes Time Off
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said this week that John Sculley, its chairman and chief executive, would take a six-week paid sabbatical as well as three weeks' vacation at the end of the month.

headline: Modern Jazz Software Is Canceled by Lotus
abstract: LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation said yesterday that it had canceled development of Modern Jazz, an integrated software program intended for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh personal computer.

headline: Phillips Adopts A 'Tin Parachute'
abstract: LEAD: The board of the Phillips Petroleum Company has adopted a ''tin parachute'' to provide better severance pay and benefits should a job be lost without just cause within two years of a management change.

headline: P.L.O. Expands Its Force in South Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: The number of Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas in southern Lebanon has nearly doubled in the last six months, raising the prospect of increased clashes with Israeli forces, Lebanese security officials say.

headline: Dow Slips by 8.89, to 2,121.98, in Slow Day
abstract: LEAD: The stock market ended moderately lower yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.89 points, to 2,121.98.

headline: Zia Decrees the Islamic Code Is Supreme Law of Pakistan
abstract: LEAD: The President, Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, decreed today that the Islamic legal code, known as sharia, would be the supreme law in Pakistan.

headline: Chase and Continental Earnings Up
abstract: LEAD: Two of the nation's major banking companies, the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Continental Illinois Corporation, yesterday reported increases in first-quarter earnings.

headline: Moscow's New Slant on the Mideast
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union appears to be shifting its Middle East policy to take Israeli interests into account and claim a role for itself as a peacemaker in the region.

headline: In South Korea, Anger at U.S. Spreads
abstract: LEAD: Ever since American troops died defending this nation in the Korean War, Americans have basked in the gratitude of the Korean people. But now the image of a benevolent America is being called into question as a new wave of anti-Americanism moves off campus and into the mainstream.

headline: Anger at Suspect's Expulsion to U.S. Smolders in Honduras
abstract: LEAD: Heavily armed troops in camouflage uniforms patrolled the streets of the Hondurdan capital today, maintaining the public order, but the widespread popular resentment provoked by the Government's decision last week to hand a suspected drug trafficker over to the United States otherwise showed few signs of abating.

headline: Students Will Manage $5 Million
abstract: LEAD: In a test of whether amateurs can beat professionals at investing, Ohio State University said yesterday that it would take $5 million of its $245 million endowment and entrust it to undergraduate business students.

headline: I.B.M. Copier Rights To Be Sold to Kodak
abstract: LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company will acquire service and marketing rights to the International Business Machines Corporation's domestic copier business, the two companies announced yesterday.

headline: The Forecast Is for All Talk, No Action
abstract: LEAD: The annual economic summit conference of the Group of Seven nations begins today in Toronto. Heads of state from the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada will meet, but most analysts are not expecting breakthroughs. Important items on the agenda include giving a greater role to gold in fixing exchange rates, phasing out agricultural subsidies and prompting the European countries to increase their rates of economic growth.

headline: Van Brunt's 'Postcard' Evokes Barbados Life
abstract: LEAD: The creative people at Van Brunt & Company have cleverly captured the look and feel of an inexpensive fold-out postcard in a television commercial for the Barbados Board of Tourism.

headline: Japan Asks End To Builder Ban
abstract: LEAD: Japanese construction executives today called for the United States to lift its ban on Japanese bids for American public works projects now that a construction dispute has been formally settled.

headline: 2 LARGE DEALS WITH SOVIET
abstract: LEAD: Two United States companies signed separate agreements today to build industrial plants in the Soviet Union that together will cost more than $25 billion.

headline: Industrial Output Rose 0.7% in April
abstract: LEAD: Output of the nation's factories, mines and utilities jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in April after two months of virtually no growth, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It was the biggest advance since a 1.1 percent surge in October.

headline: INDIA RULING PARTY LOSES A KEY VOTE
abstract: LEAD: A popular former member of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Cabinet who was dismissed last year won a crucial parliamentary by-election today, making it likely that he will lead the opposition in the next general election.

headline: 24 NEW CARDINALS INSTALLED BY POPE
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II installed 24 cardinals today, offered them as symbols of church unity and urged the followers of Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre, the dissident French cleric, not to break with the papacy.

headline: Hiring Outlook Appears Strong
abstract: LEAD: Hiring in the third quarter is expected to reach its highest level in a decade, driven by strong seasonal demand in the construction and service industries, according to a survey to be issued Monday.

headline: COMPANY NEWS: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: Arkansas Best Corp., Fort Smith, Ark., a freight transportation company, rejected Razorback Acquisition Corp.'s revised tender offer of $23 a share.

headline: Bid for Lucky Gets Financing
abstract: LEAD: The American Stores Company said that it had received a commitment for $2.5 billion in financing for use in its battle to acquire Lucky Stores Inc.

headline: Grain Prices Surging on Drought News
abstract: LEAD: As hot, dry weather continued to bake much of the nation's prime farmland, soybean and grain traders in Chicago bid up prices by the daily permissible limits, leaving huge pools of unsatisfied buy orders at the close.

headline: Before the Order for Retaliation, A Major Effort to Woo Congress
abstract: LEAD: The Administration's decision to retaliate against Iran received unusually broad support on Capitol Hill today, after intensive consultations between President Reagan, his national security advisers and Congressional leaders at the White House over the weekend.

headline: PRAVDA PUBLISHES ATTACK ON STALIN
abstract: LEAD: The Communist Party newspaper Pravda published a denunciation today of Stalin's friendship treaty with Nazi Germany and accused him of crippling the Red Army by purging the officer corps just before World War II.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 15, 1988:  MONDAY

headline: Republican Alternative Bill On Plant Closings Defeated
abstract: LEAD: The Senate today defeated the last major Republican effort to derail a a bill that would force companies to give advance notice of factory closings or large-scale layoffs.

headline: Crash Just the Latest Of Airbus's Troubles
abstract: LEAD: Even before Sunday's crash in eastern France of one of its A320 jetliners, Airbus Industrie, the European airplane consortium, was having serious problems.

headline: Court Curbs Lord, Einstein Agency
abstract: LEAD: The Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners advertising agency was ordered yesterday not to solicit or accept any clients or personnel of the Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein agency until a court hearing later this month.

headline: Steel Complaint Rejected
abstract: LEAD: The European Community executive commission today dismissed complaints by West German steelmakers over illegal state subsidies reportedly given to other European steel companies. ''We have no proof of illegal British or French subsidies,'' a commission spokesman said. The West German Iron and Steel Federation had said on Tuesday that it wanted the commission to examine apparent violations of a European Community ban on subsidies not directly related to plant closings.

headline: Senate's Condition to Treaty
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of the condition attached by the Senate on Thursday to the resolution to approve the Treaty on Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces:

headline: Utility in Virginia Marketing Bonds
abstract: LEAD: In the competitive bond market, the Virginia Electric and Power Company, a unit of Dominion Resources Inc., awarded a $150 million bond issue to a group of underwriters headed by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: Desert Partners Drops a Request
abstract: LEAD: At a hearing today in Federal District Court here, Desert Partners L.P. withdrew a request to delay the USG Corporation's annual meeting on Wednesday.

headline: New-Home Sales Off 0.3% Last Month
abstract: LEAD: Sales of new homes edged down three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the first decline in four months.

headline: Vehicle Sales Off 10.8% In Early April Period
abstract: LEAD: Early April sales of new American-made cars and light trucks dropped 10.8 percent from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

headline: In Vietnam, Craft Project Breaks Mold
abstract: LEAD: Although the world has heard how resilient Vietnamese refugees have transformed neighborhoods in Paris, Chicago or Los Angeles over the last decade, the story of Thu Duc didn't get publicity.

headline: Home Loan Rates Rise
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates on both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages rose in April, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday.

headline: Reagan to Press Religious Freedom at Summit
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would call for greater religious freedom when he travels to the Soviet Union this month.

headline: Offer to Protect Koppers Jobs
abstract: LEAD: In the latest round of its takeover battle with the Koppers Company, Beazer P.L.C. has offered to make ''substantial and important'' guarantees to all Koppers employees in Pittsburgh except for senior management if the company agrees to an immediate merger.

headline: Irving Bank Offer Extended
abstract: LEAD: Banca Commerciale Italiana said yesterday that it would extend until midnight on June 8 its offer to buy 51 percent of the Irving Bank Corportion's stock at $80 a share.

headline: Stocks Post Broad Gain; Volume Low
abstract: LEAD: The stock market rallied broadly yesterday, although trading was again anemic.

headline: Approval of Canada Trade Pact Seen
abstract: LEAD: The clash between the White House and Congress over broad trade legislation has failed to derail a free-trade agreement with Canada.

headline: Market Place; Japanese Portfolio Insurance Grows
abstract: LEAD: THE Japanese are known for copying American fads and the latest to appeal to them is portfolio insurance, which was cited as a chief contributor to the selling panic on Wall Street last October.

headline: Colombia Inflation Slows
abstract: LEAD: This country's inflation slowed to 1.73 percent in May, compared with 3.91 percent in April, and is running at an annual rate of 28.4 percent, the Government's statistics office said today. President Virgilio Barco Vargas has said that inflation control is one of the priorities of his economic policy.

headline: COMPANY NEWS;
abstract: LEAD: MCA Inc, the entertainment conglomerate, said it expects to take a $35 million after-tax charge against its second-quarter earnings because of losses on its Gotcha! toy gun line and its investment in Coleco Industries, the troubled toy maker. The announcement Tuesday was made after a review of MCA's LJN toy business and its stockholdings in the Hartford toy company, M

headline: Money Managers Stress Rockefeller Expertise
abstract: LEAD: Two members of the Rockefeller family, David Elliman and his brother, Christopher J. Elliman, have teamed up with Cynthia Flowers and Arthur S. Penn to form a registered investment advisory and management firm called Stillrock Management. Since 1981, David Elliman has been running a firm called Elmrock Inc., devoted exclusively to the financial affairs of the

headline: Pension Panel Silent on Talks
abstract: LEAD: Members of the Pension and Financial Managers Advisory Committee, an advisory panel to the New York Stock Exchange, met for most of the day yesterday but declined to disclose details of the discussions.

headline: French Photojournalist Freed by Afghanistan
abstract: LEAD: A French freelance photojournalist, captured 14 months ago and imprisoned after entering Afghanistan with Moslem guerrillas, was freed today, a French official reported.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Sets 7 New Models
abstract: LEAD: Expanding its product line at both the high and low ends, the Hewlett-Packard Company introduced seven new computers in its Spectrum series, based on a common architecture using reduced instruction set computing, or RISC. The company also introduced two entry-level business computers using its traditional design, as well as a high-speed disk drive interface using fiber-optic technology.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: LEAD:  International

headline: Judge Puts Off Centel Meeting
abstract: LEAD: A Federal district judge in Kansas today ordered the Centel Corporation to postpone Thursday's annual shareholder meeting to allow time for arguments about the issue of cumulative voting of shares.

headline: New Life for an Old Idea
abstract: LEAD: Traditional electric motors can spin a shaft at speeds up to 10,000 revolutions a minute. At higher speeds, the motor rotors, which include the metal shaft and an assembly of laminations, wire windings or magnets, are torn apart by centrifugal force. The problem plagues both rotors for induction-type motors and synchronous motors, above left, and is particularly troublesome for high-power motors.

headline: Now, a Trade Flap on Knotholes
abstract: LEAD: Because it is warmer in the United States, trees grow faster and produce lumber with larger knotholes than in Canada. In the arena of international trade, such a bit of lumberjack lore is of more than passing interest. In fact, passions run high when Canadian and American plywood producers discuss knotholes.

headline: A New Chief Executive Is Named at Symbolics
abstract: LEAD: Symbolics Inc., a struggling technology company in the artificial intelligence business, announced yesterday that it had named Jay Wurts chairman and chief executive.

headline: Saturn to Continue Firestone Supplies
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's Saturn subsidiary said it would retain the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company as its sole supplier of tires for the planned Saturn compact auto even though G.M. has said it will drop Firestone as a supplier for its existing models. The Saturn automobile, which will be built in Spring Hill, Tenn., is set for introduction in 1990.

headline: Now, Custom-Made Office Towers
abstract: LEAD: Scrambling to keep active in the face of weak demand for office space, real estate developers these days are letting their customers have it their way. They are increasingly offering to build custom-made buildings at attractive prices for corporate tenants willing to sign long-term leases before the buildings are constructed.

headline: Land Mine Kills 18 Afghans
abstract: LEAD: A land mine killed 18 people on a bus Monday in the eastern Afghan town of Jalalabad, the Kabul radio said today. The radio, monitored here, blamed the incident on Moslem insurgents fighting the Afghan Government.

headline: Retail Layoffs Start to Rise As Merger Wave Subsides
abstract: LEAD: With the wave of retailing mergers beginning to subside, their effect is now being felt hard by those who work in this people-intensive industry. The number of people displaced from jobs is expected to be the largest in a long time because of the concurrent mergers, divestitures and internal restructurings at some of the nation's largest retailing companies.

headline: Delhi Lawyers End Strike Over Police Official
abstract: LEAD: A bitter 75-day strike by lawyers ended in a new flood of controversy this week, as the authorities bowed to the lawyers and removed one of the highest ranking women in India from her post as deputy commissioner of police in New Delhi.

headline: Business Forum; INCOME DISTRIBUTION: A GROWING GAP BETWEEN RICH AND POOR
abstract: LEAD: Robert Solow, a Nobel prize-winning economist, said it best, ''Redistribution is something Americans aren't very good at.'' Instead, America's chosen weapon against income inequality has been rapid economic growth. And in fact, rapid growth is a devastating weapon against this problem, promoting rising wages and salaries and helping low-income workers in other ways.

headline: Beijing Is Said to Restrict Foreign Travel to Tibet
abstract: LEAD: Chinese officials have indicated that they will sharply restrict tourism to Tibet in the wake of last month's riot by Buddhist monks demonstrating for Tibetan independence, according to a United States official who has just returned from the region.

headline: No-Mess Chocolate . . .
abstract: LEAD: Long years of monkeying with mousses at a Geneva laboratory has produced for the Battelle Memorial Institute a chocolate that will not melt in hot weather.

headline: GRACE'S ENVIRONMENT CHIEF: Hugh L. Carey; An Old Pol Tackles a New Post
abstract: LEAD: WHEN W. R. Grace & Company hired New York's former Governor, Hugh L. Carey, in December to head its new Office of Environmental Policy, the move caused barely a public ripple. But speculation has been lively among competitors and shareholders. Why, they wonder, would Grace, which has endured more than its share of depressed profits and job cuts this decade, fork over $400,000 a year to a 69-year-old lawyer with no recent corporate experience?

headline: Market Place; Clamor for Zenith To Sell a Division
abstract: LEAD: AS losses have mounted at the Zenith Electronics Corporation's consumer electronics division, investors have begun putting pressure on the last major American manufacturer of televisions to sell its troubled unit.

headline: NICARAGUAN SEEKS NEW CONTRA TALKS
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra called today for new peace talks with United States-backed rebels but warned that approval of fresh American military funds for the rebels would be ''totally unacceptable.''

headline: Tough Sanctions Against Pretoria Are Sought by House Democrats
abstract: LEAD: Democratic leaders in the House of Representatives are pressing hard for a sweeping trade embargo against South Africa and a ban on virtually all American business investment in that country.

headline: Salomon Earnings Up 16.1% in First Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Salomon Inc., the parent of one of Wall Street's largest securities firms, announced yesterday that its first-quarter earnings increased 16.1 percent.

headline: 3 States Study Pepperell Bid
abstract: LEAD: The offices of the attorneys general of New York, South Carolina and North Carolina said yesterday that they were investigating the antitrust implications of a possible merger of West Point-Pepperell Inc. and the J.P. Stevens Company, two makers of designer sheets and towels. Stevens, citing regulatory hurdles, favors a rival bid from Odyssey Partners, an investment firm.

headline: Gillette Alters Bylaws In Coniston Dispute
abstract: LEAD: The Gillette Company has amended its bylaws in an effort to limit the power of candidates backed by Coniston Partners in the event the nominees succeed in gaining seats on the board, the company said yesterday.

headline: Rice Output Rise Seen
abstract: LEAD: The world's output of rice is headed up, led by sharply expanded planting in the United States, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. American production is expected to increase by 23 percent this year from 1987.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Executive Hired by G.M.
abstract: LEAD: General Motors has hired Shirley Young, long Grey Advertising's premier consumer researcher, as vice president of consumer market development.

headline: ACCORD IS SOUGHT BY U.S. AND SOVIET ON MENTAL WARDS
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union are moving toward an agreement that would allow American psychiatrists to visit Soviet mental hospitals to determine if dissidents are being imprisoned in the hospitals, according to a top State Department official.

headline: Federal Energy Official Resigns
abstract: LEAD: Another member of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has resigned, leaving the five-member board with two vacancies and only one sitting member with a regular appointment. Commissioner Anthony

headline: A Pulitzer Winner Who Can Go Home Again
abstract: LEAD: David Mitchell sat at his rolltop desk, an old Royal typewriter to his left and a Macintosh computer to his right, and thumbed through the latest issue of The Point Reyes Light, the weekly newspaper at which he won a Pulitzer Prize nine years ago.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, APRIL 15, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The trade deficit climbed sharply in February, to $13.8 billion, as imports surged more than twice as much as exports. The worsening of the deficit stunned the financial markets and the many economists who had been expecting the figure to shrink from January's $12.4 billion.

headline: OVERSEAS SPENDING BY U.S. COMPANIES SETS RECORD PACE
abstract: LEAD: The weak dollar, which has reduced the cost of manufacturing in the United States relative to that in other countries, should in theory be prompting American companies to halt or scale back expansion of their factories abroad, and even close some of them.

headline: SOVIET NEWSPAPER PRAISES DISSIDENT
abstract: LEAD: Roy Medvedev, the independent historian whose fiercely critical books about the Stalin era have won world acclaim but have been banned in his own country, was praised this week by an official newspaper for his work and his role as a voice of conscience.

headline: Allegheny Proxy Vote
abstract: LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. said yesterday that it had retained control of its board in a proxy fight with a group of dissident shareholders led by the New York brokerage firm of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg, according to preliminary results of the voting.

headline: Divided by Politics and the 38th Parallel
abstract: LEAD: The border that South Korean students tried to march to yesterday before they were driven back by riot police has defined political life in this divided peninsula for more than four decades.

headline: Company News; Electrolux Withdraws Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Swedish consumer products giant A.B. Electrolux, which was rejected twice in its efforts to acquire the Murray Ohio Manufacturing Company, has unexpectedly dropped out of the bidding for the bicycle and lawn mower maker based in Brentwood, Tenn. In a letter dated June 17 to

headline: Vast Flow of Cash Threatens Currency, Banks and Economies
abstract: LEAD: The vast international trade in illegal drugs is being viewed and prosecuted not just as a criminal network but as a multinational business.

headline: PATENTS; Preventing Collisions Of Birds and Planes
abstract: LEAD: A Swiss inventor received a patent entitled ''Process and Apparatus for Preventing Bird Collisions,'' involving collisions between birds and aircraft. Patent 4,736,907 was awarded to Riidiger Steffen, who is an aircraft pilot.

headline: TV Show Questions British Killings
abstract: LEAD: The British Foreign Secretary has failed to block the broadcast of a witness's account that two Irish terrorist suspects killed in Gibraltar were shot as they raised their hands in surrender to British troops.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * B. Altman's, a division of L. J. Hooker Retail Group, as part of its executive restructuring, named as senior vice presidents: Robin Clairfield-Tolvin, director of stores; Philip Blanco, marketing and sales promotion, and Joseph Giudice, operations.

headline: Palestinians Seen With Firebombs May Be Shot on Sight, Israel States
abstract: LEAD: Responding to a sudden wave of firebomb attacks, senior Israeli Government officials are advising civilians that members of the public are within their rights to shoot on sight anyone seen carrying a firebomb.

headline: U.S. Assailed at World Court on P.L.O. Office
abstract: LEAD: The United States was formally accused today before the World Court of breaking its obligations under international law by enacting legislation to close the Palestine Liberation Organization observer mission to the United Nations.

headline: Sale Planned By Fremont
abstract: LEAD: The Fremont General Corporation agreed to sell all of its property and casualty insurance operations to a management-led group for $82 million in cash, notes and stock warrants. Upon completion of the deal, Fremont General will remain a financial services concern with commercial and life insurance operations, a real estate finance unit and half ownership of a workers' compensation insurance firm.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 42.9% Gain for Quarter At Grey Advertising
abstract: LEAD: Grey Advertising released its first-quarter earnings on Friday, and they were good enough to elicit a cautionary note from Edward H. Meyer, its chairman, who said that while he appreciated the performance, he doesn't want shareholders to expect similar percent gains during the rest of the year.

headline: France Easing Exchange Curb
abstract: LEAD: The French Finance Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, has decided to lift all remaining restrictions on corporate borrowing abroad, the Government said this week.

headline: Dingman Puts $103.9 Million In One of His Henley 'Dogs'
abstract: LEAD: Michael D. Dingman, the chairman of the Henley Group, said today that he had purchased another 17.2 percent of the Henley Manufacturing Corporation for $103.9 million, or $55 a share.

headline: Athens Says U.S. Seeks Arab in Attacks on 2 Jets
abstract: LEAD: A Greek police official said today that the United States was demanding the extradition of a Palestinian in connection with two mid-flight bomb attacks on American passenger planes.

headline: Texaco in Deal With the Saudis
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia has signed a letter of intent to buy a 50 percent interest in Texaco Inc.'s refining and marketing system in 23 Eastern and Gulf Coast states for $1.28 billion.

headline: Company News; Investors Disclose Talks on Scherer
abstract: LEAD: Two New York-based investment firms that hold the equivalent of an 8.8 percent stake in the R. P. Scherer Corporation disclosed that they had held talks with a senior Scherer executive and other shareholders about a possible sale of the gelatin capsule manufacturer, based in Troy, Mich.

headline: Crowe, in Gulf, Terms Iran a Dangerous Foe
abstract: LEAD: Iran remains a dangerous foe in the Persian Gulf despite losses in battles with the United States Navy two weeks ago, Adm. William J. Crowe Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today.

headline: Seoul Journal; A Kim Has Tumbled From Ranks of Angels
abstract: LEAD: Old friends and former allies shake their heads and say they wish Kim Dae Jung had heeded this admonition, which he wrote in 1982 while imprisoned on trumped-up sedition charges:
