headline: Dispute Threatens P.L.O.-Syrian Reconciliation
abstract: LEAD: A recent reconciliation between Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization has suffered a setback as a new dispute has broken out between Yasir Arafat and the Damascus Government.

headline: Sears's Net Down 37.7% In Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Buffeted by earnings declines in three of its four businesses, Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, yesterday reported a 37.7 percent drop in net income for the first quarter. The businesses adversely affected were merchandising, insurance and real estate, while Sears's financial services group had sharply higher net income.

headline: South Africa Reported To Jail Fewer Children
abstract: LEAD: Domestic and international pressure has led to a decline in the number of children under detention in South Africa, according to a commission of inquiry into the situation.

headline: ANGOLA OF 2 MINDS ON ECONOMIC SHIFT
abstract: LEAD: About 200 yards from the pink stucco campus of Engels University, shoppers recently moved past pyramids of oranges, vials of lighter flints, cans of sardines and a Cuban soldier discreetly peddling a new pair of army boots.

headline: Outcry From Some Singapore Detainees
abstract: LEAD: Government opponents were detained last year under Singapore's Internal Security Act. Here are passages from a statement issued by eight of them April 18:

headline: Economic Scene; Trench Warfare In Lotusland
abstract: LEAD: FANTASY-DRENCHED Los Angeles, home to Forest Lawn, 24-hour sushi bars and Cher, seems an unlikely locale for a sobering war of attrition between management and labor. But as the Writers Guild strike against producers of television and feature films enters its 17th week, jokes about the small blessings of the stalemate -empty tables at La Scala, the opportunity to reread

headline: U.S. WILL INCREASE ITS GULF DEFENSE OF MERCHANT SHIPS
abstract: LEAD: Top Defense Department officials told Congress today that the Reagan Administration had decided to revise the rules for American warships in the Persian Gulf to allow them in unspecified circumstances to protect neutral merchant ships under attack.

headline: MEXICO CANDIDATE TESTS U.S. WATERS
abstract: LEAD: Although he is several months away from becoming president of Mexico, Carlos Salinas de Gortari is already moving behind the scenes to establish lines of communication with a force that always looms large in Mexican foreign relations: the United States.

headline: New Afghan Province: A Toehold for Moscow?
abstract: LEAD: A decision by the Government of Afghanistan to create a new northern province has aroused speculation among diplomats that Moscow may be planning to retain a military zone in the north if the stalled Geneva peace talks break down.

headline: New York State Marketing Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The State of New York entered the debt market yesterday with a $111 million issue of general obligation bonds won in competitive bidding by an underwriting group led by Prudential-Bache Securities.

headline: Byrd to Step Down at Year's End As Leader of Senate's Democrats
abstract: LEAD: Ending months of speculation, Robert C. Byrd said today that he would step down as Senate majority leader at the end of the year, opening the way for new leadership when the next President takes office in January.

headline: Robert Allen Is on the Line
abstract: LEAD: ''THIS is a bitterwsweet moment for me,'' said Robert E. Allen, addressing shareholders after being named chairman of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company last week. Mr. Allen, 53 years old, got the job after the sudden death of James E. Olson, who succumbed to cancer at the age of 62.

headline: April Home Sales Up, Maybe at Peak
abstract: LEAD: Despite rising mortgage interest rates, sales of new single-family homes rose in April for the third straight month, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: Calmat To Sell 2 Businesses
abstract: LEAD: In a restructuring to avert a takeover by a New Zealand investment firm, the Calmat Company said today that it intended to sell its cement and real estate operations and distribute the estimated $800 million in proceeds to shareholders.

headline: Advertising; Royal Crown Ads With No Black Actors
abstract: LEAD: IT'S hard to believe in this day and age that an ad agency could produce three 30-second television commercials for a major soft drink and not include any black actors.

headline: Japan-Australia Dispute on Beef
abstract: LEAD: Japan's agriculture minister, Takashi Sato, said today that he was willing to go to Australia to settle a dispute over Australia's beef exports.

headline: Toronto Stock Prices Up
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices moved higher in mixed trading today on the Toronto Stock Exchange. The composite index rose 14.10, to 3,187.20, as stocks falling in price outnumbered those posting a gain, 366 to 329. Stock exchanges in the United States and Europe were closed for the holiday.

headline: President Charms Students, But His Ideas Lack Converts
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan gave a lesson in American civics today to about 600 students and faculty members at Moscow State University, the alma mater of both Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa.

headline: Power Plant Bond Ruling
abstract: LEAD: The State of Washington's Supreme Court ruled today that purchasers of Washington Public Power Supply System bonds could sue the state for its role in the huge default on those bonds.

headline: State Dept. Labels Haitian Army Coup 'Blow to Democracy'
abstract: LEAD: The United States today condemned the coup in Haiti, saying it was a ''serious blow to hopes for democracy in that troubled land.''

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Creamer Dickson Head Quits for Rowland Post
abstract: LEAD: Mitchell Kozikowski, 51 years old, the chairman and chief executive of Creamer Dickson Basford, the public relations subsidiary of Britain's WCRS Group, has left to become president of the New York office of the Rowland Company, the public relations subsidiary of Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi.

headline: Real Estate; Ritz-Carlton Style Coming To Jersey, Too
abstract: LEAD: Until recently a stay at a Ritz-Carlton hotel, a name long associated with the epitome of hotel comfort, traditional style and urban elegance, meant a visit to Boston, New York, Washington or Chicago. Now a Ritz-Carlton hotel is coming to suburban New Jersey, and the project is regarded as a high-risk venture.

headline: Offer Is Made For Amfac Unit
abstract: LEAD: In another step toward completing its restructuring, Amfac Inc. said a group including management and an unidentified financial instituition plans to buy the company's wholesale pharmaceutical business for $120 million. The hospital and chain store distributor is the fifth of eight operations that Amfac, based in Honolulu, plans to sell.

headline: A Good Idea Gone Sour: Savings Talent on Loan
abstract: LEAD: When Federal regulators developed a plan three years ago to allow the most troubled savings and loan institutions to continue operating under executives borrowed from well-run institutions, everyone agreed it was a good idea.

headline: OPEC and Non-Members Will Meet Today on Prices
abstract: LEAD: Major oil producers from inside and outside the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Vienna on Tuesday to try to fashion an agreement on controlling production and bolstering the price of oil.

headline: Compaq-Digital Technology Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation said they had reached a technology exchange agreement to insure the connectibility of their respective products. The agreement, which follows a similar pact between Digital and Apple Computer Inc. in January, formalizes support for customers connecting Compaq personal computers in networks with

headline: RALLY IN BOND PRICES CONTINUES
abstract: LEAD: The bond market's rally continued yesterday, as prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose by as much as 1 3/4 points in light trading.

headline: Contra Split Widens as a Director Vows to Seek Commander's Ouster
abstract: LEAD: A split in the Nicaraguan rebel movement deepened today after Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, one of the movement's five political leaders, announced he had agreed to represent a group of officers and civilians who continue to demand the replacement of the military commander, Col. Enrique Bermudez.

headline: MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Alexander's Stake
abstract: LEAD: The investment group led by Donald J. Trump, the developer, and Steven Roth has raised its stake in Alexander's Inc. above 50 percent for the first time, to 54.4 percent from 49 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Interstate Partners, a New Jersey-based real estate concern controlled by Mr.

headline: No Bail for Man In Bomb Arrest
abstract: LEAD: A man arrested Tuesday in New Jersey with three bombs was held without bail yesterday as authorities investigated whether he had ties to the Japanese Red Army. A Federal magistrate said there was a risk the suspect, Yu Kikumura, would flee the country.

headline: Chrysler Air Bags
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation has begun installing driver's-side air bags as standard equipment on three of its models and will add them this week to three more, becoming the first United States auto maker to make air bags standard equipment. Federal safety regulations require increased use of passive restraints, such as air bags, which inflate in event of a collision, or automatic seat belts.

headline: Reagan's Gift Recalls Hollywood Blacklist
abstract: LEAD: When President Reagan gave Mikhail S. Gorbachev a videotape of the 1956 movie ''Friendly Persuasion,'' he did not mention that the screenwriter of the film had been blacklisted in the 1950's on suspicions of being a Communist.

headline: Texas Air Investigator Tends to Shun Limelight
abstract: LEAD: Rosalind A. Knapp, who will conduct a Government investigation of the Texas Air Corporation, will probably not take personal advantage of the publicity spotlight, those who know her said yesterday.

headline: Fiery Supporters Bury P.L.O. Official
abstract: LEAD: The slain military commander of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Abu Jihad, was given a martyr's funeral today after thousands of his impassioned followers seized his coffin and carried it through the dusty streets of a refugee district.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 4, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: Corporations' Credit Quality Declined in the First Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The credit quality of United States corporations declined in the first quarter, as did the volume of new bond issues, Moody's Investors Service reported yesterday. The drop reflected weakness in the banking, securities, retail and automotive sectors.

headline: Icahn in Appeal to Wary Analysts
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn told more than 300 analysts and Texaco shareholders yesterday that he could easily raise the $14.22 billion needed for his ambitious $60-a-share proposal to take over the nation's third-largest oil company. But analysts in the audience continued to show the skepticism that has held the stock near $50 a share even after the $60 bid.

headline: Texas Bank Halts Payment
abstract: LEAD: The First Republicbank Corporation, the Texas banking company that is receiving emergency Federal aid, said today that it had suspended payments on $1.3 billion in long-term debt, which will save $78 million in annual interest costs.

headline: SHAKEN BY DOWNSIZING, THE GROUPS REGROUP
abstract: LEAD: One way that trade associations reflect American business as a whole is that both have been shaken by the recent trend toward consolidation.

headline: Finding a Cure for Financial Inertia
abstract: LEAD: ARE your finances making you feel guilty? Does every passing week leave you more determined to finally get your fiscal affairs under control . . . and more frustrated because you don't know how or where to start?

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: Like the Postcard? Now Try the Book
abstract: LEAD: In the belief that browsers spend no more than three seconds looking at most paperbacks, publishers have long tried to lengthen that attention span by splurging on the books' jackets. Hard-cover publishers, by contrast, have traditionally believed that customers are attracted more by content than by packaging, although they, too, now spend far more for attractive book covers.

headline: DEVELOPMENT SEEN FOR THE MINERALS OF ALL ANTARCTICA
abstract: LEAD: Concluding 6 years of difficult negotiations, 33 nations have agreed to open all of Antarctica to regulated development of its oil and mineral resources, according to American participants in the talks.

headline: Maxwell Bid Reported
abstract: LEAD: Robert Maxwell, chairman of the Maxwell Communications Corporation, is trying to buy a West German publishing company that prints dictionaries and encyclopedias, a local newspaper said. The Saturday edition of the Mannheimer Morgen quoted a spokesman for Bibliographisches Institute and F.A. Brockhaus A.G.

headline: Texaco Meeting May Get Delay
abstract: LEAD: Texaco Inc. said yesterday that it would postpone its annual meeting by 10 days if requested by Carl C. Icahn.

headline: On Brazilian TV, the Subtle Sell Pays Off Big, Too
abstract: LEAD: In Brazilian soap operas, when lovers kiss passionately in a car its ultramodern control panel comes into focus; after the bronzed surfer buys a popular shampoo at the pharmacy the camera lingers on its brand name, and as beautiful young models put on a fashion show, the name of a well-known textile company blinks in the background.

headline: Market Place; Is Dow Chemical Recession-Proof?
abstract: LEAD: THE Dow Chemical Company is earning more than ever from a business that is more evenly balanced than ever. So some analysts contend that despite a rise of about $6 in the last two weeks, its stock is undervalued. Dow's shares closed at $89.875 yesterday, off 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: THE CRUCIAL INGREDIENT; Quality Is Not Accidental - It's Designed
abstract: LEAD: WHEN quality is cited in discussions of United States competitiveness, design is conspicuously absent from consideration. However, quality cannot be built-in unless it is first designed-in. About 40 percent of all quality problems can be traced to poor design.  It is useful to think about designed-in quality in terms of design integrity.

headline: The Media Business: Advertising; Sales Promotion Unit Under Saatchi's Roof
abstract: LEAD: To get a sales promotion resource under its own roof and one as free as possible of conflicts with its clients, Saatchi & Saatchi DFS, a North American operation, has established a joint venture sales promotion agency with the Howard Marlboro Group, a sister company within Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi.

headline: G.M. Share Is Higher, Profits Disappointing
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's heavy use of financial incentives helped it to regain some of its lost share of the car and truck market but caused it to earn slightly less in the first quarter than many analysts had expected.

headline: Bonn to Sell Remaining Viag Stake
abstract: LEAD: The West German Government, continuing its disposal of its corporate holdings, will sell its remaining 60 percent stake in Viag A.G., the giant energy, chemical and metal enterprise.

headline: April Output By OPEC Up
abstract: LEAD: Oil production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries rose to 18.2 million barrels a day in April from 17.7 million barrels in March, the International Energy Agency said Friday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Information Resources' Shopping Cart With TV
abstract: LEAD: Information Resources of Chicago, the nation's third-largest marketing research company, is making an interesting diversification move: into TV-equipped supermarket carts. It is called ''VideOcart,'' with a capital O. That's right, carts that have 6-by-8-inch video screens mounted on the handles and cued electronically to run commercials when they pass the shelfspace of an advertiser's products.

headline: Shultz May Fly to Mideast In June for More Peace Talks
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz may make another trip to the Middle East in June in a further effort to promote Arab-Israeli peace talks, a United States official said today.

headline: New York Area Store Sales Off
abstract: LEAD: Sales of several large New York retailers dropped by an average of 6.7 percent in the city in April from the period a year earlier, while the stores' overall sales in the metropolitan area fell 7.8 percent, a spot-check found.

headline: USG Bid Extended
abstract: LEAD: Desert Partners L.P. extended its $42-a-share tender offer for the USG Corporation until midnight on April 29. The offer was to expire at midnight tonight. In a hearing in Federal District Court here, USG and the investor group failed to agree on the terms for a proposed vote on a preferred share rights plan, a so-called poison pill.

headline: Times Mirror Fills Position
abstract: LEAD: Donald F. Wright, a broadcast and cable executive at the Times Mirror Company, was given responsibility today for supervising the company's smaller newspaper operations in the East. Publishers of The Hartford

headline: Israel Moves Troops Into Lebanon In a Search for P.L.O. Infiltrators
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army announced tonight that it had sent forces into southern Lebanon in search of Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas who have tried to slip into Israel and take hostages twice in the last week.

headline: The Russians, Too, Embrace 'Secret Silliness' of Astrology
abstract: LEAD: In a one-room clinic a few paces from Moscow's most popular pedestrian mall, Dzhuna Davitashvili, celebrity psychic healer, gesticulates over the head of a deaf and blind man, as if pulling invisible weeds from his cranium.

headline: Australian Trade Gain
abstract: LEAD: Australia's trade picture improved dramatically in April, with the current account deficit narrowing to a smaller than expected $396 million (Australian), or $302 million (American), the Statistics Bureau said today. The deficit in March stood at $1.09 billion (Australian), which was revised from $1.18 billion.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Market Place; Small-Company Funds Forge Ahead
abstract: LEAD: Mutual funds that specialize in small-company growth stocks led the pack in the first quarter, registering an average gain of 14.05 percent, according to Lipper Analytical Services of New York. These funds have lagged the overall market since 1983, and some professionals think the turnaround since the

headline: U.S. Hondas Go to Japan
abstract: LEAD: The first cars made in the United States by a Japanese company arrived in Tokyo Friday when the Honda Motor Company unloaded 540 autos. ''We hope this will help reduce trade tensions between the two countries and eventually cut down the trade surplus,'' a Honda spokesman said. The Accord cars were made by Honda's wholly owned subsidiary, Honda of America Manufacturing, in Marysville, Ohio.

headline: Yields Mostly Unchanged
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday.

headline: Ford to Delete a Model
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company plans to eliminate its two-seat Escort EXP model this summer, to allow more production of the Escort, the Escort wagon and the Escort GT. Ford sold 24,427 EXP's last year, out of a total of 392,360 Escorts, it said Wednesday.

headline: Airlines Reach Listing Accord
abstract: LEAD: British Airways and American Airlines have settled their legal battle over their computer reservation systems, with both airlines agreeing to change the way flights from the overseas carriers are listed in their reservation systems.

headline: Protesters March to Remember Nagy
abstract: LEAD: Demonstrators clashed repeatedly with the police in the center of Budapest today on the 30th anniversary of the hanging of Imre Nagy, Prime Minister of the revolutionary Government that was ousted by the Soviet military intervention in 1956.

headline: Step Taken In Talks on Farm Aid
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the European Community took a step forward today in resolving their dispute over reducing the world's farm subsidies. How big a step is a matter of dispute.

headline: A Meatpacker Cartel Up Ahead?
abstract: LEAD: IN little more than a year, Conagra Inc., the giant food products and grain company, has stormed to the top of the beef industry. Buying one large meat processor and a half interest in another, Conagra has suddenly become one of three companies that dominate the business.

headline: Japanese Protest Curbs On Toshiba
abstract: LEAD: Japanese Government and business leaders today denounced an agreement by United States Congressional negotiators to include stringent curbs on the Toshiba Corporation in an omnibus trade bill.

headline: With the Economic Summit, Toronto Hopes Visitors Savor Its Melting Pot
abstract: LEAD: When a rusty freighter carrying 174 Indian Sikhs nudged illicitly into a rocky Nova Scotia cove last summer, one of the Sikh immigrants waded ashore, attache case in hand, and asked the first resident he met for help in summoning a taxi to Toronto, more than 1,000 miles away by road.

headline: Soviet Nuclear-Powered Satellite Expected to Hit Earth in Summer
abstract: LEAD: A crippled Soviet nuclear-powered satellite is expected to fall to Earth in August or September, threatening to spread radioactive debris. Yesterday both Soviet and American officials said they were monitoring the situation.

headline: British Banks Raise Key Rate
abstract: LEAD: Britain's commercial banks, heeding a signal from the Bank of England, raised their base lending rate today by half a percentage point, to 8 1/2 percent.

headline: Moscow Rejects Homeland for the Tatars
abstract: LEAD: A high-level Soviet commission set up to review the rights of Crimean Tatars has rejected their demands for an autonomous homeland, the official press agency Tass reported today.

headline: Greater Role in Debt Crisis Is Urged for World Bank
abstract: LEAD: The president of the World Bank, Barber B. Conable Jr., outlined ways today in which the institution could play a larger role in managing the global debt crisis.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  International Report

headline: Study Finds Soviet Output Is Stagnant
abstract: LEAD: Despite the ambitious economic program of the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet Union last year experienced almost no economic growth, cut back its imports from the West and failed to increase standards of living for its consumers, an analysis by two United States intelligence agencies concluded.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   7.75        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.75   6.24   6.84        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.20   6.14   5.51        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.38   6.39   5.78        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.70   8.67   8.33        30-YR.

headline: Trade Bill Passes First Crucial Vote
abstract: LEAD: A trade bill made it through the House. A party-line vote of 312 to 107 approved the measure, which included an intensely disputed item requiring that workers be given 60 days' notice of plant shutdowns or big layoffs. President Reagan, in a stand backed by many business groups, has said he will veto a bill that includes the notice provision.

headline: Hungarian Party Opens Talks
abstract: LEAD: The national conference of the Communist Party, called to renew the party's leadership and policies, opened today without any indications of the internal contest that the session is intended to resolve.

headline: Schisms Crumble Korea's Opposition
abstract: LEAD: This nation's opposition coalition, the diverse group that forced the Government to carry out sweeping democratic changes last year, has dissolved in bitterness and confusion, unable to overcome personal antagonisms in time for the legislative elections next month.

headline: Allies Wiggle Wings Over Berlin
abstract: LEAD: The three Western Allies re-enacted the Berlin airlift today with a nostalgic flight on a vintage C-47 aircraft of the type used in the mammoth supply operation 40 years ago.

headline: Farm Bank Issue Among Sales This Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's regular auction of three-month and six-month bills and Wednesday's auction of two-year notes, which are sold every month.

headline: Brazil Debt Pact Called Innovative
abstract: LEAD: The agreement between Brazil and its foreign creditor banks to reduce sharply the interest Brazil pays on more than $60 billion in debt and to provide it with $5.2 billion in new loans was described yesterday as innovative and significant by a number of experts on third-world debt.

headline: Managua Weighs Rejection of U.S. Aid for Wounded Children
abstract: LEAD: The Sandinista Government is apparently considering rejecting American aid for young victims of the Nicaraguan conflict.

headline: Borden's Lemon Battle
abstract: LEAD: The United States food giant Borden Inc. lost another round today in its court battle to enter the British lemon juice market. The Court of Appeal dismissed Borden's appeal against last year's High Court ruling preventing the company from selling Realemon on the ground that consumers would confuse it with Jif, a popular British product manufactured by Reckitt & Colman.

headline: Soybean and Grain Prices End Mixed in Profit Taking
abstract: LEAD: Soybean and grain prices closed mixed yesterday as many speculators who had cleared large profits during the recent strong advance cashed in some of their gains.

headline: RLI Tender Offer For Redken Starts
abstract: LEAD: Paula Kent Meehan, the founder and chairwoman of Redken Laboratories Inc., rejected a $30-a-share leveraged buyout offer from an unnamed private investment firm on April 25, one month before Redken agreed to be acquired by Mrs. Meehan for $34 a share.

headline: Ohio Law Review Ordered
abstract: LEAD: A Federal appeals court today ordered a lower court to re-examine its 1986 ruling that an Ohio law regulating corporate takeovers is unconstitutional.

headline: U.S. Rig Count Down
abstract: LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States dropped by 14 last week, to a total of 883, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The rig count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, totaled 744 a year ago. The rig count reached a peak of 4,500 in December 1981, at the height of the oil boom.

headline: U.S.-Japan Farm Talks
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Japan will resume talks Tuesday on Tokyo's quotas on beef and citrus imports, the United States trade representative's office said today.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  Economic and Social Council  ECONOMIC COMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M.  SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  Trusteeship Council  Meets at 3 P.M.

headline: O.A.S. Chief Faults Contra Aid
abstract: LEAD: The top official of the Organization of American States has told the United States Government that its food shipments to Nicaraguan guerrillas based in Honduras violate the terms of a cease-fire between the contras and the Sandinista Government.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New England Monthly Is Bustling
abstract: LEAD: THERE'S a lot of activity inside the old brick brass works on the Mill River in Haydenville, Mass., and it is being felt thoughout New England and beyond.

headline: Company News; Labor Pact Spurs NWA Stock Gains
abstract: LEAD: A gain of more than 10 percent in the common stock of NWA Inc. in the last week indicates that the carrier has regained its footing after its 1986 takeover of Republic Airlines, analysts said. NWA's stock rose 62.5 cents today to close at $44.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Investcorp Tie To Gucci Uncertain
abstract: LEAD: Guccio Gucci S.p.A. said it could not confirm or deny a report in The Financial Times today that a Bahrain-based investment bank, Investcorp, had secretly built a large stake in the Italian fashion group. ''I just don't know,'' Gucci's chairwoman, Maria Martellini, said. ''Of all the rumors lately, this seems the most believable.

headline: No Accord By OPEC On Oil Cuts
abstract: LEAD: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended four days of meetings early today without an agreement on a production cut. OPEC officials said the cartel would meet again next month.  The failure here is bound to depress oil prices by at least $1 a barrel, an analyst said, because the oil markets had been anticipating some kind of decision to reduce output, which would have propped up oil prices.

headline: WHERE THE JOBS WILL (AND WON'T) BE
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are selected career possibilities that, from the standpoint of availibility, will provide the most and least security through the end of the century, according to projections by the United States Labor Deptpartment's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The percentage growth in the number of jobs expected through the year 2000 in each field is indicated next to the job titles.

headline: Court Bars Extradition In Technology Sale Case
abstract: LEAD: A Canadian appeals court has ruled that a former California businessman accused by the United States of trying to sell advanced computer technology to the Soviet Union cannot be extradited.

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: LEAD: The increase in short-term interest rates in the last two months led to a sharp outflow of $5.04 billion from money market mutual funds during the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

headline: Two Japanese Banks to Buy Primary Treasury Dealers
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved the acquisition by two Japanese banks of primary dealers in the United States Treasury market. Both purchases had been pending for well over a year and were exempted from restrictions included in the trade bill passed by Congress earlier this year.

headline: President Quits A. & S. Post
abstract: LEAD: Federated/Allied Department Stores said Robert J. Anderson had decided to resign as president of the Abraham & Straus division to pursue other business interests. Mr. Anderson, 50 years old, was named president of A. & S. in March 1985.

headline: Belo Earnings Decline 59.3%
abstract: LEAD: The A. H. Belo Corporation said its earnings had declined by 59.3 percent in the first quarter from the corresponding period last year because of higher operating costs and weak advertising demand.

headline: Coke Executive Joins Law Firm
abstract: LEAD: Francis T. Vincent Jr., the former head of Columbia Pictures Industries and former executive vice president of the Coca-Cola Company, has returned to the private practice of law as a member of Caplin & Drysdale, effective this week.

headline: Market Place; Disappointments At Paine Webber
abstract: LEAD: THE stocks of several major brokerage firms are trading below their book value, a reflection of the fact that investors perceive Wall Street as a potentially dangerous arena in the wake of last October's stock market crash. But no brokerage industry stock has been hit as hard as Paine Webber.

headline: Citicorp Notes To Yield 9.10%
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp yesterday began offering $250 million of 9 percent notes due in 1993 at a price of 99.60, to yield 9.10 percent, through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: Rival Moslems Clash in Lebanon; 13 Killed
abstract: LEAD: Rival Shiite Moslem factions, using machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, clashed in southern Lebanon today for the second consecutive day, and the police said 13 people were killed and 40 wounded.

headline: Fair Futures
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Patents; Drug Is Said to Inhibit Cancer-Linked Enzyme
abstract: LEAD: An inhibitor against the enzyme aromatase, which is said to be a cause of breast cancer in postmenopausal women, was patented this week for the Washington Research Foundation in Seattle. The research was financed by the National Institutes of Health.

headline: THOUSANDS BATTLE AS SEOUL BLOCKS MARCH TO NORTH
abstract: LEAD: Fierce but sporadic battles erupted here this afternoon as riot policemen tried to block students from marching to the North Korean border for a meeting with North Korean students at Panmunjom.

headline: Icahn Loss On Texaco Conceded
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn conceded yesterday that he had lost his proxy battle with the management of Texaco Inc. after Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, which held the second-largest block of voting rights after Mr. Icahn, said it had voted for management.

headline: PRESIDENT CHALLENGES GORBACHEV TO IMPROVE HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan challenged Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to improve the Soviet human-rights record by reuniting divided families, increasing emigration, ending suppression of religion and releasing political prisoners.

headline: Soviet Scientists in U.S. for Tests on Verification
abstract: LEAD: A group of scientists from the Soviet Union have arrived in Washington to join a private environmental group in field experiments to test ways of enforcing potential limits on underground nuclear explosions.

headline: Hilton Plans Hotel
abstract: LEAD: The Hilton Hotel Corporation said it planned to build a hotel-casino of at least 1,000 rooms on 19.5 acres purchased in Laughlin, Nev., for $27 million from the Horseshoe Club Operating Company. John V. Giovenco, Hilton's president for its Nevada operations, said architects were drawing up plans, but he could give no estimate of the project's cost or the expected completion date.

headline: Seoul Ruling Party Replaces Hard-Liners With Moderates
abstract: LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo replaced the head of the governing party with a moderate today and indicated that he would cooperate with the opposition after a major election setback.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  Economic and Social Council

headline: Paris Gives Only a Few Posts to Centrists
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Michel Rocard announced the formation of a Cabinet today whose weightiest portfolios went to members of his Socialist Party. Only a few posts were given to independents and centrists.

headline: A Chance to Pile Up a Few Dollars More
abstract: LEAD: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.

headline: New Yorkers & Co.; Handmade on 38th Street, The Shoes of a Heavyweight
abstract: LEAD: To survive in the garment business in New York these days, you have to have an angle. You can't compete with foreign producers because of labor costs. You can't compete with companies in rural America because their rent and taxes are so much lower.

headline: Drug Traffic Rises Sharply In Argentina
abstract: LEAD: Argentina, on the southern fringe of South America's cocaine region, is experiencing a sharp increase in drug production and trafficking.

headline: Talks to End Strike Begin in Gdansk
abstract: LEAD: The management of the big Lenin shipyard met today for the first time with workers striking for higher pay and for the legalization of the Solidarity trade union.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * Newsweek is raising its ad rates 3.7 percent with the July 4 issue. Subscription rates will rise about 10 percent.

headline: Moscow Plans 2d Bond Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union plans to sell bonds in West Germany to help finance perestroika, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of social and economic restructuring, bankers said today.

headline: At a Le Pen Rally, Little Fraternite for Mitterrand
abstract: LEAD: Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the ultra-right National Front, called on his supporters today not to vote for President Francois Mitterrand on May 8, but he declined to endorse the Socialist head of state's conservative challenger, Prime Minister Jacques Chirac.

headline: Polaroid Displays Printer and Camera
abstract: LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation previewed new products that include a cigar-box-size printer that can create high-quality color photos in minutes from a television picture or any other digital source. The new device, still in the prototype stage, is seen by the company as the forerunner of inexpensive, compact instant printers that work with a variety of cameras.

headline: For MGM/UA, Bidders Are Scarce
abstract: Few financiers love trading assets more than Kirk Kerkorian.

headline: Socialists Jittery Over French Voting
abstract: LEAD: Uncertainty surrounds the outcome of parliamentary elections in France on Sunday, with President Francois Mitterrand's Socialists fearful that they might fall short of a majority in the National Assembly.

headline: ISRAELIS PREVENT GUERRILLA ATTACK
abstract: LEAD: Israeli soldiers prevented two guerrilla bands from entering Israeli-held territory early today, killing two armed men who tried to cross the northern border, an army spokesman said.

headline: China Is Reportedly Willing To Grant Asylum to Pol Pot
abstract: LEAD: The Chinese Government has reportedly told the United States it would be willing to offer the Cambodian guerrilla leader Pol Pot and his top aides permanent asylum in an effort to reach a poltical settlement to end the nine-year civil war in Cambodia.

headline: Taiwan Ends Broker Curbs
abstract: LEAD: The Cabinet approved proposals this week that would allow new securities firms to be established, ending a 15-year ban on such licenses.

headline: Yields Show Little Change
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were little changed during the week ended yesterday. Short-term rates have risen just a tenth of a point in four weeks and longer-term rates only half as much.

headline: Phone Services To Tromson
abstract: LEAD: Tromson Monroe Advertising, a longtime specialist in travel advertising, has become the agency for Calaber Communications' Calaber Telecommunications Network.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  COMPANIES  I.B.M. will phase out manufacturing at five domestic factories and reduce its headquarters staff in Westchester County by several thousand employees. I.B.M. said 10,000 of its 228,000 domestic employees would be affected. [ Page D1. ] Michael D. Dingman will pay $103.9 million for the 17.2 percent stake in Henley Manufacturing held by two foreign investors.

headline: At 85, Sam Goody Longs For a New Business
abstract: LEAD: Sam Goody, the once-upon-a-time music man, wants to play it again, but to a different tune.

headline: Centel Acquiring Cellular Phone Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Centel Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a definitive agreement to buy United Telespectrum Inc., the cellular telephone and paging division of United Telecommunications Inc., for $763 million.

headline: P.L.O. Man's Rites to Be Held in Syria
abstract: LEAD: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria offered today to let the funeral of a slain Palestine Liberation Organization leader be held Wednesday in Damascus, a gesture that could help improve severely strained relations between Syria's leader and the P.L.O.

headline: U.S. AND JAPAN CLEAR A TRADE HURDLE
abstract: LEAD: Today's settlement of a bitter dispute over beef and oranges clears up one of the most contentious trade issues between the United States and Japan.

headline: S.&P. Announces Dual Rating Policy
abstract: LEAD: The Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday that it had adopted a new dual rating policy to help investors distinguish between traditional pass-through issues and pass-through issues that get their cash flow from a convertible adjustable-rate mortgage collateral pool and include a repurchase obligation from the originator or servicer.

headline: Amount of New Issues Rises By 58% From Crash Period
abstract: LEAD: Corporations found Wall Street a greater source of new money in the first three months of this year than during the shell-shocked climate after the stock market collapse in October. The amount for stock and bond underwriting jumped 58 percent in the first quarter, to $67.9 billion, from $43.1 billion in the previous quarter.

headline: LARGE BANKS RAISE PRIME RATE TO 9% ON INFLATION FEAR
abstract: LEAD: Many of the nation's major banks raised their important prime lending rate today, a decision prompted by growing fears at the Federal Reserve Board and on Wall Street that inflation is now a greater threat than recession.

headline: U.S. Officials Link Pakistan Blast to Kabul Regime
abstract: LEAD: One week after a major explosion at a Pakistani ammunition dump, Defense Department officials say that they believe that the explosion was the work of agents of the pro-Soviet regime in Kabul.

headline: Hong Kong Sees Rising Emigration as Peril
abstract: LEAD: In a reversal, the Hong Kong Government has begun to acknowledge that rising emigration among skilled and professional workers is hurting the thriving economy of this British colony, which is due to be returned to China in 1997.

headline: Hated Numbers
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Paraguay Official Linked to Assault in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: A Paraguayan official and six other men here for the General Assembly's special session on disarmament assaulted demonstrators who were protesting against Paraguay's military Government near the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Monday evening, officials at the United States Mission to the United Nations said today.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. is offering $300 million of 8 1/8 percent notes due in 1991 at a price of 99.736 to yield 8.226 percent through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton.

headline: Solentiname Journal; Font of Lush Paintings, Inspired by a Rebel Priest
abstract: LEAD: The peasants on this pristine archipelago raise cattle and grow rice and beans like peasants everywhere in Central America, but unlike others, they are also artists whose paintings have been exhibited around the world.

headline: Merc-Comex Talks Snagged
abstract: LEAD: In a new twist in merger talks between New York's two largest futures exchanges, directors of the New York Mercantile Exchange decided late Wednesday to bypass a comprehensive merger plan and to make a more limited proposal to the Commodity Exchange.

headline: Dow Up 0.50, To 2,062.17; Volume Off
abstract: LEAD: A day after Wall Street enjoyed one of its best sessions of the year, stock prices rose modestly in moderate, uneven trading.
