headline: DANES CALL A VOTE ON A NUCLEAR BAN
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Poul Schluter today called an election for May 10 in which he said voters should ''take a stand'' on Denmark's full partnership in NATO.

headline: NASA to Aid Fuel Supplier
abstract: LEAD: The American Pacific Corporation said today that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration would provide up to $33 million in financial backing to help it rebuild its destroyed plant, one of two sites that produced the primary fuel component for the space shuttle.

headline: Hungary May Name New Leader Today
abstract: LEAD: A senior Communist Party official strongly hinted today that Prime Minister Karoly Grosz would be chosen Sunday to replace Janos Kadar as party leader. He said the Soviet Union did not have a say in the choice.

headline: Apple Accused By Microsoft
abstract: LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation filed a countersuit last week charging that Apple Computer Inc. had broken a 1985 settlement agreement between the two companies and had interfered with Microsoft's relationship with other software developers. Microsoft's filing was in response to the suit Apple filed March 17, which contended that Microsoft's Windows 2.03 program and the Hewlett-Packard Company's New Wave program both infringed on its copyrights for the

headline: Arab Declaration Falls Short of P.L.O. Demands
abstract: LEAD: An Arab summit meeting ended today with a broad resolution supporting the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories and pledging ''all necessary help and assistance in all necessary forms'' to insure that the upheaval continues.

headline: Entertaining In Moscow: A Guest List
abstract: LEAD: Following are the guests who attended a dinner given tonight by the President and Nancy Reagan at Spaso House, the American Ambassador's residence, as released by the White House.  SOVIET GUESTS  Yuri N. Afanasyev, historian, and his wife.  Bella Akhmadulina, writer and poet, and Boris Messerer, painter.

headline: Cannon Group Details A Reorganization Plan
abstract: LEAD: Cannon Group Inc. said today that, as part of a proposed reorganization, its European stockholders had agreed to inject at least $100 million into the company in the next year and to arrange for a $100 million credit line.

headline: Yugo Airbags
abstract: LEAD: Yugo of America said it would offer airbags as standard equipment on all of its 1990 models, following the introduction of seat belts and shoulder harnesses in the back seats of 1989 models. The bags, which inflate on impact to cushion a car's occupants, will be offered only on the driver's side.

headline: Canadian Agency Wins Top Prize for Billboards
abstract: LEAD: For the first time in the 46-year history of the Obie Awards for outdoor advertising, a Canadian agency has received the top prize, for its billboard for McDonald's of Montreal.

headline: Jane Byrne Joins Edelman
abstract: LEAD: Edelman Public Relations, the nation's largest privately held public-relations agency, said today that Chicago's former Mayor, Jane M. Byrne, had joined the firm as a senior public affairs consultant.

headline: SINHALESE GROUP TO END INSURGENCY
abstract: LEAD: The Government signed a peace accord today with an ethnic Sinhalese group that has conducted a guerrilla campaign in which at least 260 people have died, officials announced.

headline: Soviet Believed To Be Preparing Afghan Pullout
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union appears to have taken some steps in preparation for withdrawing its troops from Afghanistan, Reagan Administration officials said today.

headline: Vote Fraud Charges Fill Mexican Air
abstract: LEAD: With presidential and congressional elections here nine days away, opposition parties and civic groups say there are signs that the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party is preparing to rig the vote.

headline: A Rockwell Closing
abstract: LEAD: The Rockwell International Corporation said it would discontinue operations at the plant here that its North American Aircraft division operates to make structural components for the B-1B aircraft. The company has delivered the last of the B-1B's ordered by the Air Force. Rockwell said final closing would require about 15 months.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * BSN S.A., Paris, the biggest food group in France, agreed to acquire Saratoga Sparkling Mineral waters from Anheuser-Busch Cos., St. Louis. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Buyout May Mean Raises for I.C.M. Talent Agents
abstract: LEAD: Tom Wolfe, Meryl Streep and Willie Nelson will not be directly affected if a proposal to take International Creative Management private receives Government approval. But their agents, and those representing 2,600 other agency clients, could be. They stand to be paid much more if the proposed leveraged buyout of I.C.M.

headline: Reporter's Notebook; At Sikh Temple, an Uncertain Song Returns
abstract: LEAD: The sound of Sikh hymns rang across the Golden Temple this morning for the first time in two weeks and echoed off the empty chambers and corridors of the nearly deserted shrine.

headline: First Chicago Blocks Theft
abstract: LEAD: The First National Bank of Chicago, a unit of the First Chicago Corporation, said today that it had thwarted an attempt by an employee to embezzle $70 million from three customer accounts.

headline: Demand Up? Plants Can Take It
abstract: LEAD: With exports rising, some factories have been having trouble keeping up with orders, leading to a handful of shortages and some price increases. But all the recent Government and industry data indicate that the scarcities are the exception and will not result in higher inflation in the immediate future.

headline: Ford-VW Venture
abstract: LEAD: The head of the Ford Motor Company's international automotive operations said he did not expect its South American venture with Volkswagen A.G. to post a profit in 1988 because of skyrocketing inflation. Ford began the venture with Volkswagen, dubbed Autolatina, in 1987. Ford holds a 49 percent stake in the concern, the largest single company in South America.

headline: Airbus Deal Seen
abstract: LEAD: Airbus Industrie, the West European aircraft consortium, is expected to sign a sales contract for three A-310 jets with East Germany's Interflug airline in Toulouse, France, on Friday, industry experts said. Airbus received the go-ahead for the sales earlier this month from the Western alliance's Coordinating Committee for Multinational Export Control, diplomats said last week.

headline: Senators Seek Delay of Military Sale to Saudis
abstract: LEAD: A bipartisan group of 58 senators asked the Reagan Administration today to delay plans to sell Saudi Arabia $450 million in military equipment because of disclosures that the Saudis had purchased missiles from China.

headline: Warsaw Bids a Big Benvenuto to Italian TV
abstract: LEAD: The notion of spaghetti westerns along Poland's Vistula River may become a reality when Italy's principal state-owned network begins direct transmission of its full television program to Poland later this year.

headline: Integrated Net Service Started by Southern Bell
abstract: LEAD: The Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company began offering a new class of services today that gives businesses the ability to transmit voice, data and video pictures simultaneously on the same telephone line.

headline: Nicaraguans Begin Pact's 60-Day Cease-Fire
abstract: LEAD: After more than six years of fighting, Nicaragua's warring armies today began observing a 60-day cease-fire that leaders on both sides hope will lead to permanent peace.

headline: Volleyball, Swimming and the Dow
abstract: LEAD: School will be out soon. Want to make sure that your child doesn't spend the whole summer just enjoying fishing or hanging around the malls? Then send him or her to business camp. Between volleyball and swimming, the future financiers of America can spend a week sharpening their money-making skills.

headline: F.C.C. Approves Atlantic Cable Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday approved plans by an international group of telecommunications companies to build a new trans-Atlantic undersea cable that would go into service in 1991. The fiber optic cable, known as TAT-9, will carry 80,000 simultaneous telephone calls, or about twice the capacity of the TAT-8 cable scheduled to go into operation between the United States and Europe this year.

headline: Moscow Summit: Unmaking History and Debating Rights; Gorbachev and Reagan Toasts: 'Man's Survival' and 'Peace and Freedom'
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from the toasts by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan at a state dinner tonight at the Kremlin. Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were translated by a Soviet interpreter.  Gorbachev Toast

headline: Two Journeys
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan's arrival in Moscow today marks the end of a long ideological journey. He has gone from a sense of anxiety over the Russians to a new confidence in possibilities for negotiation. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, too, has made a remarkable passage, from anti-American Communist boss to pragmatic leader willing to make compromises that will help him change his country's course.

headline: Britain's Maxwell Sets Deal For Educational Publisher
abstract: LEAD: Two weeks after saying that ''unacceptably high'' prices for publishing companies had cooled his interest in deals in the United States, Robert Maxwell, the British publishing entrepreneur, announced yesterday that he would acquire Science Research Associates for around $150 million.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Stride Rite Assignment Is Awarded to Mullen
abstract: LEAD: Mullen, which used to be known as Mullen Advertising and is in Wenham, Mass., has just won a $2 million advertising account from the Stride Rite Corporation's Children's Group.

headline: Hanoi Is Seeking Talks On Political Prisoners
abstract: LEAD: Vietnam today invited the Reagan Administration to open negotiations on the resettlement in the United States of several thousand recently released political prisoners.

headline: No-Mess Chocolate . . . And No-Risk Bubbly
abstract: LEAD: Popping open a bottle of warm champagne that has just been agitated can send the cork rocketing away at 200 miles an hour. So Theta Resources Inc., a San Francisco industrial design company, has come up with a champagne stopper that it says could prevent such errant corks from nicking a chandelier or injuring a guest.

headline: Reform Rabbis Urged Not to Convert Awad
abstract: LEAD: The leaders of Reform Judaism sent a letter yesterday to the movement's 1,500 rabbis in the United States and Canada urging them not to accommodate Mubarak Awad should he come to them seeking to convert to Judaism.

headline: Public Flirtation With Private Desire
abstract: LEAD: There is an ancient adage, whispered these days, that goes: ''First marriage, to please one's parents; second marriage, to please oneself.''

headline: Kodak Income Climbs 46.1%
abstract: LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company's earnings rose 46.1 percent in the first quarter of 1988, to $260 million, from $178 million a year ago, the company said today.

headline: Pipeline Blast Laid to Rebels
abstract: LEAD: Leftist guerrillas blew up Colombia's main pipeline Saturday as Latin American and Caribbean oil-exporting countries ended talks in the Caribbean resort of Cartagena, Government officials said.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Affiliated Medical Enterprises, Orange, Calf., an investor-owned health-care corporation, announced that it had acquired American Health Group International Inc., Kirkland, Wash., for $100 million. The acquisition included the purchase of four acute-care hospitals and a home health company.

headline: Is Unix's Time Finally at Hand?
abstract: LEAD: FOR years the ritual was the same. Supporters of the Unix operating system would proclaim that their time had come - that widespread acceptance of Unix was at hand. But 12 months later, Unix would remain right where it had been, firmly entrenched in the academic and scientific computing centers and largely ignored by businesses.

headline: West Coast Bank Profit
abstract: LEAD: The First Interstate Bancorp, rebounding after losses of $556 million last year, said today that its earnings rose 27.3 percent in the first quarter.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Promotion May Lead To the Top at Honda
abstract: LEAD: The Honda Motor Company yesterday named Shoichiro Irimajiri as managing director for its worldwide manufacturing operations, effective June 30. Mr. Irimajiri, who since 1984 has been president of Honda's American manufacturing subsidiary in Marysville, Ohio, will be succeeded by Hiroyuki Yoshino.

headline: Ex-Envoy Indicted on Drugs
abstract: LEAD: A former Honduran diplomat was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of smuggling and possession of cocaine with the intention of distributing it.

headline: ARAFAT IS IN SYRIA FOR FENCE MENDING
abstract: LEAD: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived unexpectedly in Damascus today in an effort to seal a reconciliation with Syria after five years of fierce rivalry.

headline: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
abstract: LEAD: BUSINESSES are finding it increasingly important to transfer high volumes of data from one computer to another rapidly and accurately.

headline: Zayre Names Chairman For Its Troubled Stores
abstract: LEAD: The Zayre Corporation said yesterday that it had named Herbert J. Zarkin chairman of its largest unit, Zayre Stores.

headline: Korean Trade Surplus
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's current account surplus rose 41 percent in the first four months of this year from its level of a year earlier, the Bank of Korea reported Friday. The current account measures trade in merchandise and services. The surplus for January through April was $3.89 billion, up from $2.76 billion one year ago.

headline: Article 581988 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Lucky Stores Inc., a West Coast supermarket chain that has been hotly pursued by the American Stores Company, said yesterday that it had agreed to a $2.4 billion buyout proposal from Gibbons, Green van Amerongen Ltd., a New York investment firm.

headline: Rebel Kurds Reportedly Kill 25 Turkish Villagers
abstract: LEAD: In a dramatic resurgence of violence, Kurdish separatist guerrillas were reported today to have killed at least 25 civilians in two remote southeastern villages over the last three days.

headline: Dole Opposes Deal on Noriega Indictments
abstract: LEAD: The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, served notice on the Administration tonight that the Senate would protest if the United States dropped drug indictments against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama as part of a deal to force the ouster of the military leader.

headline: Showdown of Rivals on 77th St.
abstract: LEAD: A dramatic three-hour showdown Thursday night between Edward S. Finkelstein and Robert Campeau at Mr. Finkelstein's Manhattan town house led to the $6.6 billion merger agreement reached yesterday morning between Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Campeau Corporation.

headline: Macmillan Gets a Bid From Bass
abstract: LEAD: The Robert M. Bass Group of Texas said yesterday that it had made an unsolicited offer to acquire Macmillan Inc., the New York-based publishing and information services company, for $64 a share, or about $1.6 billion.

headline: Citicorp Selling Notes at 9.031%
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp is offering $250 million of 9 percent notes due in 1993 at 99.875 to yield 9.031 percent through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: Shultz Plans to Take New Arms 'Ideas' to Moscow
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he was taking some new arms control ''ideas'' to Moscow on Thursday in an effort to make headway toward a new agreement reducing long-range nuclear arms.

headline: Further Rate Drops Not Expected
abstract: LEAD: The recent drop in interest rates has temporarily masked what continues to be strong bearish sentiment in the credit markets, analysts said.

headline: Cartier to Acquire 2 Watch Concerns
abstract: LEAD: Cartier S.A. said it would acquire a controlling interest in the Swiss watchmakers Piaget S.A. and Baume & Mercier S.A. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but Cartier's chairman, Alain Perrin, said the acquisition should help to increase Cartier's sales to $840 million this year.

headline: U.S.-Japan Chip Talks Collapse
abstract: LEAD: The Semiconductor Industry Association said today that its talks in Tokyo with the Electronic Industries Association of Japan had collapsed without the two groups reaching an accord on market access issues. The Semiconductor Industry

headline: Shiseido to Buy Conair's Zotos
abstract: LEAD: The Shiseido Company of Japan, one of the world's largest cosmetic concerns, has agreed to purchase the Conair Corporation's hair-care products division, Zotos International Inc., for $345 million. Zotos, based in Darien, Conn., poineered the ''cold-wave-perm'' and now licenses its professional hair-care products to more than 50 countries around the world.

headline: Suchard's Merger Bid Rejected by Rowntree
abstract: LEAD: Rowntree P.L.C., the venerable British candy company, today rejected a bid of $:2.31 billion, or about $4.3 billion, by Jacobs Suchard A.G., the Swiss chocolatier ''It is the board's unanimous view that the Suchard offer fails to reflect the true value of Rowntree,'' a Rowntree spokeswoman said.

headline: In Eye of Stormy Africa, Zaire Dictates Stability
abstract: LEAD: A dozen women stood on this city's main boulevard recently, handing out leaflets criticizing the Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko until the security police arrested them minutes later.

headline: 'Brawl' in Burma Takes an Anti-Government Turn
abstract: LEAD: An argument over a gambling debt in a tea house here last March escalated into a week of rioting by Burmese students and other Rangoon residents, with estimates of fatalities ranging from two to 200.

headline: Prospects; Regulating for Safer Skies
abstract: LEAD: Since airline deregulation in 1978, traffic has almost doubled, putting strains on the system. An increase in near misses, allegations against the Boeing Company of poor quality control, and last month's damage to an Aloha Airlines jetliner, have intensified concern over safety. What changes will be made in the way the skies are regulated?

headline: INVESTING; A High Yield and Rising Profits
abstract: LEAD: A RETURN of 12.5 percent is nothing to sneeze at, especially when some of it may be tax deferred.

headline: 'Interesting Numbers' for the Manufacturers
abstract: LEAD: NEW technology, particularly genetic engineering, is reviving interest in vaccines - agents that induce immunity to diseases. After a 20-year slump that saw the number of vaccine producers shrink by half and fundamental advances slow to a crawl, the pace of development is quickening.

headline: In Singapore, A Sales Pitch Done to Order
abstract: LEAD: ''Hi, Mike,'' said Ali Khan, demonstrating one of Singapore's ancient arts, the sales pitch. ''A nice silk kimono for you?''

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: COMPETING FOR THE YEN; Japan's Money Helps Build America
abstract: LEAD: THESE uncertain economic times suggest it is time to take a new look at our view of Japan. Japan's emergence as a world economic power has created a strange dichotomy in American public policy. On the one hand, public pressure continues to mount on Congress and the President to take decisive steps to pry open the Japanese market for American goods and services.

headline: White Castle's Search for Youth
abstract: LEAD: For years, the Ingram family ran its White Castle restaurant chain in a stubbornly old-fashioned way. Instead of advertising heavily, franchising or resdesigning stores, it relied on a simple menu of a square little hamburger that die-hard fans would buy by the bagful and devour at one sitting.

headline: Beirut Captivity: A Frenchman's Story
abstract: LEAD: It might never have happened if Jean-Paul Kauffmann and Michel Seurat had not missed the bus at the airport on May 22, 1985, the day the two men arrived in Lebanon. A few minutes later, a Mercedes-Benz blocked the way in front of their taxi on the road to Beirut.

headline: Study Says U.S. Doesn't Need Wide On-Site Blast Monitoring
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration's position on nuclear testing verification was challenged today by a report issued by the Office of Technology Assessment, a Congressional agency.

headline: U.S.-Japan Talks Go On
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Japan continued high-level negotiations today in their dispute over increasing the sale of American beef and oranges in Japan.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 439 money market mutual funds increased by $908.7 million, to $266.28 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 122 institutional funds increased by $458.7 million, to $70.95 billion. The assets of the 220 general-purpose funds were up by $281 million, to $81.83 billion.

headline: Koppers Says Ad Violates Ruling
abstract: LEAD: The Koppers Company complained in Federal court that its unwelcome suitor, Brian Beazer, had violated a judge's order with a newspaper advertisement advising shareholders to become impatient with Koppers's management. ''You, our fellow shareholders, ought to ask: 'How long must we wait?' '' for management to accept a $60-a-share tender offer, worth an estimated $1.7 billion, the advertisement said.

headline: Vehicle Sales Up By 2.6%
abstract: LEAD: Mid-May sales of new American-made cars and light trucks rose 2.6 percent above the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

headline: Allegheny Bankruptcy Plan
abstract: LEAD: The board of Allegheny International Inc. approved a plan of reorganization yesterday that would pay the company's secured creditors in full, meet part of the debt to many of its unsecured creditors and dilute the ownership of current shareholders.

headline: A Wall Street Greeting For Unocal's New Chief
abstract: LEAD: Richard J. Stegemeier has served as Wall Street's window into the Unocal Corporation ever since becoming president and chief operating officer of the nation's 12th-largest oil company in 1985.

headline: Crash Legacy
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Borland Deal for Surpass
abstract: LEAD: Surpass Software Systems Inc., a company founded by Seymour Rubenstein, a pioneer in the personal computer industry, is selling its software to a rival, Borland International Inc., and will cease operating by year-end. The purchase price, in cash and stock, was not disclosed. Borland said it would incorporate technology from Surpass's computer spreadsheet program into future versions of its own personal spreadsheet program, known as Quattro.

headline: Bonds and Notes Up in Busy Day
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes rose in brisk trading yesterday, bolstered by falling commodity prices and a firmer dollar on foreign currency markets.

headline: Ad Industry Faulted on Over-50's
abstract: LEAD: Advertising agencies and consumer products companies routinely underestimate the willingness of consumers over the age of 50 to try new products and overestimate the effectiveness of many marketing techniques, according to a survey released yesterday by Donnelly Marketing, a subsidiary of the Dun & Bradstreet

headline: Millions Missing From German Jewish Fund
abstract: LEAD: The leader of West Germany's main Jewish organization said today that tens of millions of marks were missing from a fund intended for Jewish victims of Nazism and that his predecessor might have taken them.

headline: India Awaits the Monsoon, a Welcome Cloud
abstract: LEAD: For days now, Indians have been tracking the progress of a huge saturated mass of air moving from south to north, as if its coming offers hope for relief, prosperity and even political stability.

headline: Boesky Move Speculation
abstract: LEAD: There was growing speculation yesterday that Ivan F. Boesky, the former investor imprisoned for insider trading, was transferred from a California prison to Manhattan to testify before a grand jury investigating John F. Mulheren, a takeover stock speculator.

headline: Hitler's Bunker Demolished As East Berlin Park Is Built
abstract: LEAD: The concrete bunker where Adolf Hitler shot himself as the Russians advanced into Berlin is being demolished to make way for a park, East Berlin building officials said today.

headline: Moderately Higher Inflation Forecast
abstract: LEAD: The United States appears to be entering a period of moderately higher inflation in which the general price level could rise 5 percent or more a year into the early 1990's, many economists and business executives maintain.

headline: U S West Has Lyonnaise Link
abstract: LEAD: U S West Inc., the Denver-based regional telephone company, said yesterday that it had agreed to purchase a 10 percent stake in Lyonnaise Communications, a French cable television concern.

headline: Hong Kong Stake Raised
abstract: LEAD: Jardine Strategic Holdings announced today that it had raised its stake in the Hongkong Land Company to 33 percent from 25 percent.

headline: The Low Dollar Has Worked Wonders
abstract: LEAD: NEARLY two centuries ago Alexander Hamilton, in his famous ''Report on Manufactures,'' tied the future of the United States to the health of its manufacturing sector. Hamilton's prescient words still ring true today.

headline: Equicor's President Moves Into Top Post
abstract: LEAD: William T. Hjorth has been named chief executive of Equicor, a joint health-care venture of the Hospital Corporation of America and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

headline: Korea Shipyard Decline
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's shipbuilding orders have dropped by 41.3 percent this year, compared with the 1987 period, because of the national currency's appreciation in foreign exchange, officials said today. The value of the South Korean won has risen 7.43 percent against the United States dollar since the beginning of the year.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD: General Assembly  AD HOC COMMITTEE ON INDIAN OCEAN -10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.  Economic and Social Council  COMMISSION ON TRANSNATIONAL CORPORATIONS- 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Reagan in New Tack On Rights in Soviet
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan tried again today to clarify a comment he made at the Moscow summit talks, during which he blamed bureaucratic inertia rather than official policy for human rights problems in the Soviet Union.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shandwick Announces Two More Acquisitions
abstract: LEAD: Less than two weeks after making an acquisition in Atlanta, Britain's Shandwick P.L.C., the world's largest independent public relations company, has announced two more acquisitions. In the United States it's Rubenstein, Wolfson & Company and in West Germany it's Kommunikations Marketing in Bonn.

headline: India Does an About-Face and Courts the Drug Industry
abstract: LEAD: In an about-face, India has decided to court American and multinational drug companies, hoping that they will increase investments and develop more drugs and technologies in a country that has previously tried to keep them at bay.

headline: To the Raided, He's Icahn the Terror
abstract: LEAD: Except possibly for T. Boone Pickens, who seems to have lost interest in attacking corporations, no single corporate raider these days comes close to Carl C. Icahn for an uncanny ability to terrorize corporate chieftains by the simple act of buying stock and, one way or another, emerging with a profit.

headline: 10-Year Offering By Seagram Unit
abstract: LEAD: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc., a unit of the Seagram Company, is offering $250 million of 9.65 percent notes due in 1998, at a price of 99.75, to yield 9.689 percent, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: MITTERRAND, BREAKING SILENCE, ASKS VOTERS FOR SOLID MAJORITY
abstract: LEAD: With the Socialists increasingly concerned about their prospects in Sunday's legislative elections, President Francois Mitterrand appealed today for a solid parliamentary majority to match his own triumphant re-election last month.

headline: SHULTZ ENDS VISIT AND VOWS RETURN
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz ended his six-day mission to the Middle East today with a promise to return to the region to keep alive the American peace initiative.

headline: Dow Rises 6.30, to 2,003.65; Trading Slows
abstract: LEAD: Trading in stocks was slow yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average managing enough of a gain to put it barely back above the 2,000 level.

headline: TV Campaign to Begin For California Magazine
abstract: LEAD: California magazine, based in Los Angeles, is about to break its first television campaign and its first advertising will come from Hal Riney & Partners.

headline: Suspect's Childhood Goal: Money
abstract: LEAD: This was to have been the week that Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr. completed the two-year financial analysts' program at Morgan Stanley & Company. Instead, he was suspended under a cloud of scandal.

headline: Mixing Cultures On the Assembly Line
abstract: LEAD: TWO distinctly different car models are rolling off the assembly line at a gleaming new automobile plant here, about 15 miles south of Detroit. One bears the block letter badge of Mazda, the other the oval emblem of Ford.

headline: GOVERNMENT CRISIS LOOMS IN LEBANON
abstract: LEAD: The candidates for the Lebanese presidency agree that without a Christian-Moslem consensus on political changes and a compromise candidate, a power vacuum may be inevitable when President Amin Gemayel's term expires in September.

headline: Yields Rise In Week
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were all up for the week ended yesterday. But analysts said that the modest rise in bank rates that began May 11, after an increase of half a percentage point in the prime lending rate, might be ending.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Group Expands
abstract: LEAD: Over in England the WPP Group has acquired EWA Ltd., a data base management company whose output is useful to direct marketing companies. WPP will pay up to $41.3 million over time. EWA had pretax profits of $1.1 million for the 10 months ending Jan. 31.

headline: ARMS AID REPORTED FADING AS BLOCK TO AFGHAN PEACE
abstract: LEAD: There were signs at the Afghan peace talks today that the United States and the Soviet Union had removed major obstacles and were moving toward an understanding on military supplies for Afghanistan after a peace treaty is signed.

headline: Airbus Jet Order
abstract: LEAD: A joint venture company formed by the GATX Leasing Corporation, a subsidiary of the GATX Corporation, and Credit Lyonnais of France announced an order for 10 Airbus Industrie A320 planes. The order by GATX/CL Air was the first for the plane produced by the European aerospace consortium since an Air France A320 crashed on Sunday at a French air show.

headline: Dow Up by 22.21; Trading Remains Light
abstract: LEAD: A modest demand for oil stocks and some other blue chips was sufficient yesterday to move the market moderately higher, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose by 22.21 points, to 2,037.30. Volume, however, remained relatively light.

headline: Militia War Abates in Beirut As Negotiations Go Forward
abstract: LEAD: Fighting between Shiite Moslem militias slowed today as negotiators worked on the terms for the deployment of Syrian forces in the capital's battle-torn southern suburbs.

headline: Congress Aid Request Due Soon, Contra Says
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration told Nicaraguan rebel leaders today that it would soon ask Congress to provide the contra guerrillas with additional aid, the chief contra peace negotiator said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said its Bendix Automotive Group and Hankuk Brake Industrial Co., Seoul, South Korea, had formed a venture to produce brake components and friction materials in Korea.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Jordan, McGrath Ends 11-Year Tie With Aetna
abstract: LEAD: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor has said farewell to Aetna Life and Casualty after an 11-year relationship during which billings went from about $1 million, to $19 million last year, and the agency could say in heartfelt fashion, ''Aetna, I'm glad I met ya.''

headline: CHERNOBYL PLANT BEING MISMANAGED, PRAVDA CHARGES
abstract: LEAD: Two years after it was the scene of the world's worst nuclear accident, the Chernobyl power station is riddled with negligence and nepotism, Pravda charged today.

headline: BEHIND THE TRADE-BILL VETO
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's message to Congress discussing his veto of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988.  Notice of Plant Closings

headline: Eroding Empire
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Bangladesh Election Reform Panel Ousted
abstract: LEAD: President H. M. Ershad has dissolved the Election Reforms Commission after the head of the commission criticized the Government's role in the last election.

headline: MGM/UA Parts for Sale
abstract: LEAD: Kirk Kerkorian, who controls the MGM/UA Communications Company, disclosed yesterday that he might sell parts of company and distribute the proceeds to shareholders.

headline: Shultz Begins Latin Trip Today as Policy Is Reviewed
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is to leave Wednesday on a quick trip to Central America as the Reagan Administration reassesses its policy toward Nicaragua.

headline: Court Refuses to Hear Appeal on Annuities
abstract: LEAD: In a case that has caused concern in the insurance industry, the Supreme Court declined today to hear an industry appeal of a Federal appeals court decision suggesting that millions of ''fixed annuities'' sold by insurance companies are subject to Federal securities laws.

headline: Angolan Rebel Asks for U.S. Aid
abstract: LEAD: Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan guerrilla leader, asked Congress today to provide more aid to his organization to support its war against the Luanda Government.

headline: Units of Travelers
abstract: LEAD: The Travelers Corporation announced yesterday that it would offer its Canadian subsidiaries for sale. The properties to be sold include Travcan Ltd. and two of its insurance subsidiaries, Travelers Life Insurance Company of Canada and Travelers Indemnity Company of Canada. The company, which is based in Hartford, said it would concentrate on its United States insurance operations and use the capital from the sale to finance long-range business goals.

headline: Abrams Predicts Sandinistas Will Violate Accord and Consolidate Power
abstract: LEAD: Elliott Abrams, the combative custodian of American policy on Central America, expresses grave reservations about the new cease-fire in Nicaragua. He fears the Sandinistas will violate its terms and use it to consolidate their power.

headline: To Our Readers
abstract: LEAD: Because of a computer problem, the trading volume for Pacific Gas and Electric Company's stock is incorrect in today's New York Stock Exchange list, the N.Y.S.E. most-active list and the table of Dow Jones averages that shows the volume of component stocks. The actual number of Pacific

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Charles W. McConnell has joined Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, as a senior vice president, account director, on Dean Witter, Contel and the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Editor of the Letters Tests Limits
abstract: LEAD: The tiny office is submerged in stacks of readers' letters, one day's worth of mail piled precariously on the desks and spilling onto the floor. The small staff of Ogonyok, the brash weekly magazine, is inundated by an outpouring of newly voiced passions from the Soviet people.

headline: Key Changes At Magazines
abstract: LEAD: Nicholas H. Niles, who introduced Changing Times magazine to advertising (and vice versa) during his nine years as publisher, is now headed for American Express Publishing where he will be vice president and publisher of Food & Wine. Mr. Niles will be replaced by

headline: Consultants Criticized by Agency Side
abstract: LEAD: ALVIN A. ACHENBAUM, a former ad agency executive turned consultant, came under heavy attack from a high advertising industry executive last Friday for what he purportedly has been doing to reduce agency compensation.

headline: Chrysler to Expand Car Output in Mexico
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation will increase production of its K-body cars in Mexico after American production is phased out in this country by the end of the current model year, company officials said today. The K-cars, including the Dodge Aries and Plymouth Reliant, were instrumental in the company's financial recovery in the early 1980's.

headline: Three Officials Quit Paperback
abstract: LEAD: Paperback Software International said today that three top officers had left the company in a reorganization that would also reduce the day-to-day operating responsibilities of Adam Osborne, the prominent computer entrepreneur who founded the company.

headline: Icahn Makes New Bid For the Rest of T.W.A.
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor and chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., yesterday resumed his efforts to take the airline private.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Torchmark Corporation priced a $200 million issue of 10-year 9 5/8 percent notes through a syndicate led by the First Boston Corporation yesterday.

headline: Afghan Guerrilla Warns of Disorders in Pakistan
abstract: LEAD: The leader of the Afghan guerrilla alliance today rejected the accord on withdrawal of Soviet troops and raised the threat of unrest among Afghan refugees in Pakistan.

headline: 2 EX-SECRETARIES URGE A CONSENSUS
abstract: LEAD: In an unusual collaboration by a diplomatic odd couple, Henry A. Kissinger and Cyrus R. Vance, two former Secretaries of State, have issued an appeal for a ''restoration of bipartisan consensus in American foreign policy.''

headline: Audi's Goal For Japan Set
abstract: LEAD: Volkswagen A.G.'s luxury car subsidiary, Audi A.G., said today that it plans a campaign to increase its Japanese sales.

headline: Bangladesh Insurgents Kill 13 Bengali Settlers
abstract: LEAD: Tribal insurgents shot and killed 13 Bengali settlers in attacks Sunday in southeastern Bangladesh, bringing the number of dead to 36 in the last week, the authorities said today.

headline: World's Tallest Platform
abstract: LEAD: Seven tugboats today began hauling the world's tallest offshore drilling platform to a site off the Louisiana coast. After its two drilling rigs are installed in the Gulf of Mexico, the platform, dubbed Bullwinkle, will weigh 78,000 tons and stand 1,615 feet high - 161 feet higher than the world's tallest building, the Sears Tower in Chicago.

headline: Gorbachev Says Reagan Remarks On Rights Issues Threaten Accords
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused President Reagan today of jeopardizing improvements in Soviet-American relations by reverting to a confrontational approach toward Moscow, the press agency Tass said.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly

headline: REBEL ARCHBISHOP THREATENS SCHISM
abstract: LEAD: Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre announced today that he would consecrate four bishops on June 30 without papal authority. The action threatens the first formal split in the Roman Catholic Church in 118 years.

headline: New Microsoft Word Program
abstract: LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation has announced a new version of its word-processing program for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh personal computers.

headline: Iran Acts for Better Ties With West
abstract: LEAD: Moving to revive diplomatic and economic ties with the West, Iran named an Ambassador to France today and welcomed a group of British legislators for talks in Teheran this week.

headline: Citicorp-Led Group To Take Over York
abstract: LEAD: The York International Corporation, a leading manufacturer of air-conditioners, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by a group led by Citicorp's venture-capital unit for $57.50 a share in cash and securities. The total takeover deal was valued at about $750 million.

headline: Iran Dissidents Enter Gulf War
abstract: LEAD: The ground war between Iran and Iraq, which is approaching its ninth year, has taken a small but politically significant turn with the first major attack by dissident Iranians against positions held by troops loyal to the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

headline: South Korea Swept by Labor Unrest
abstract: LEAD: A second wave of labor unrest is sweeping this nation, as workers who exploded in protest last summer now try to expand on the rights they won.

headline: TOP COMMANDER DECLARES HIMSELF PRESIDENT OF HAITI
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy, who ruled Haiti for two years before yielding to a civilian President in February, seized power today and declared himself President of a military Government.

headline: Four Ex-Chase Officials Form Investment Bank
abstract: LEAD: Four former senior executives of the Chase Manhattan Corporation have decided to start their own investment banking firm, to be known as R. P. Urfer & Company.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Cipher Data Products Inc., San Diego, a maker of digital magnetic tape drives, said its chairman, Don M. Muller, had resigned to accept the position of chairman, president and chief executive at Optotech Inc., Colorado Springs.

headline: Panel Urges Hong Kong Stock Reform
abstract: LEAD: A Government-appointed committee recommended today that foreign and corporate brokers, as well as business executives, should have a greater role in running Hong Kong's young, notoriously unconventional stock market.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Time Ad Incentive Plan Is Extended for a Year
abstract: LEAD: Time Inc. has extended its two-year-old advertising incentive program called the Maximum Advertising Exposure Plan for another year.

headline: SANCTIONS WORRY FOES OF NORIEGA
abstract: LEAD: Panamanians opposed to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega reacted with a mixture of puzzlement and cynicism today to President Reagan's decision to force American companies and individuals to withhold taxes and other fees from the military Government.

headline: Oil Prices Stabilize on Hopes for a Production Agreement
abstract: LEAD: Oil prices steadied around the world today as spokesmen for several oil-producing nations said they had not abandoned hope of cooperating with the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries on steps to reduce production and bolster prices.

headline: Pope Leaves Austria; Death Plot Is Reported
abstract: LEAD: As Pope John Paul II ended his Austrian tour today with warm thanks to President Kurt Waldheim, a news report said a new plot by Turkish extremists to assassinate the Pope had been foiled in Vienna.

headline: Both Sides Claim Texaco Victory
abstract: LEAD: The management of Texaco Inc. asserted today that it had won its proxy battle with Carl C. Icahn, the oil company's largest shareholder.

headline: Less Mortgage Delinquency
abstract: LEAD: The proportion of Americans falling behind in their mortgage payments fell in the first three months of this year, continuing a steady decline that began in 1985, a banking industry group said today.

headline: HIJACKERS TOOK ON WEAPONS IN IRAN, EX-HOSTAGES SAY
abstract: LEAD: The pro-Iranian gunmen holding a Kuwaiti airliner acquired a substantial arsenal of weapons and explosives while the hijacked jumbo jet spent three days in Iran last week, several passengers released here said today.

headline: Patents; Method of Assessing Cattle Characteristics
abstract: LEAD: A system to measure animals, intended primarily for determining the physical and genetic characteristics of beef cattle, has been invented for Applied Genetics International Inc. of Cody, Wyo. Norman J. Hayes of Cody was granted patent 4,745,472 this week.

headline: Careers; Attracting Students to The Sciences
abstract: LEAD: ''WE'RE not nerds,'' Harold J. Raveche, the president-elect of the Stevens Institute of Technology, said last week, taking aim at the stereotype perpetuated in some popular films.

headline: Toronto Sun Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: The Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation said today that it had agreed in principle to acquire Bowes Publishers Ltd. of Edmonton, Alberta. Bowes publishes 14 newspapers and 6 magazines in Alberta, British Columbia and Ontario. The company will pay $28.2 million for 60 percent of the outstanding shares of Bowes, which is privately owned.

headline: Syrian Forces on Alert in Beirut
abstract: LEAD: Seven thousand Syrian troops in southern Beirut were put on alert today as clashes between Shiite Moslem militias intensified in the suburbs nearby.

headline: Pentagon Awards 2 Contracts on MX
abstract: LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Company and the Rockwell International Corporation won Pentagon military contracts to build a railroad car and computer software to mobilize the MX nuclear missile. A contract for $167 million went to Westinghouse to design and build a railroad launching car for the 10-warhead intercontinental missile by mid-1992, the Air Force announced.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  Economic and Social Council

headline: Market Place; Quiet Redemption Of Bearer Bonds
abstract: LEAD: ONE of Wall Street's anachronisms will be replayed today, when newspapers around the country are full of legal advertisements announcing redemptions of tax-exempt bonds.

headline: Meese Links Embassy Riot to Traffickers
abstract: LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d said today that anti-American riots in Honduras this week in which five Hondurans died demonstrated ''the tremendous power of the narcotics traffickers and what they are apparently trying to orchestrate.''

headline: American Standard Files for Offering
abstract: LEAD: American Standard Inc., which is 95 percent owned by the ASI Acquisition Company, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for about $1.12 billion of debt securities to be offered through the First Boston Corporation.

headline: A Zaire Commuter: 6 Miles on Foot
abstract: LEAD: The sun pounds down mercilessly on the dirt road as Mutombo Kinaoudi trudges past Kintambo Cemetery, where the tropical vegetation swirls around and shrouds most of the simple stone markers.

headline: Santo Domingo Journal; At 80, the Master Builder Is Busy (and Boastful)
abstract: LEAD: In his first three elected terms as President, Joaquin Balaguer went on a building spree that forever changed the face of this country. He laid down roads and bridges, schools and housing projects, libraries, museums, theaters, parks and sports complexes.

headline: Apple Buys Software Unit
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had purchased Orion Network Systems Inc., a small company in Berkeley, Calif., that makes software allowing non-I.B.M. computers to communicate over networks with I.B.M. machines. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Patents; A Method to Improve Resource Allocation
abstract: LEAD: Scientists at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., were granted three patents this week for methods of improving the efficiency of allocation of industrial and commercial resources.

headline: Soybean Prices Go Still Higher
abstract: LEAD: Soybean and corn prices soared further yesterday as one of the worst dry spells of the century continued to shrivel crops and create bottlenecks on the Mississippi River, the major transport artery for most of the nation's oilseeds and feed grains.

headline: U.S. Escorts Gulf Tankers
abstract: LEAD: United States warships escorted three Kuwaiti oil tankers northward through the Persian Gulf today after reports that Iranian gunboats were sighted near the Strait of Hormuz, maritime officials said. The convoy was the first since Washington announced on Friday that it would protect neutral ships in the gulf.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Brent J. Bissell has been named senior vice president, general managerj at McCann-Direct, Troy, Mich.

headline: Life Beyond the Kremlin
abstract: LEAD: They are Europeans. They are Asians.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; A Taunton Assignment For Lintas: Vos Direct
abstract: LEAD: Taunton Press of Newton, a 13-year-old publisher whose magazine titles include a quartet of sophisticated how-to books, has assigned its direct marketing needs - formerly done in-house - to Lintas: Vos Direct, which ultimately is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: Koppers Bid Extension
abstract: LEAD: Beazer P.L.C. of Britain is expected to extend the deadline of its tender offer in its hostile takeover attempt of the Koppers Company, people familiar with the deal said last night. The $1.85 billion tender offer is scheduled to expire tomorrow.

headline: Market Place; Revising Realty Partnership Plans
abstract: LEAD: SPONSORS of limited real estate partnerships are like badly wounded soldiers. Having been dealt a blow by the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and by further tax changes last year, the sponsors are ever so slowly recovering.

headline: Joint Chefs' Head Skeptical on Noriega
abstract: LEAD: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff predicted today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, would not give up power as early as Washington wants.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Top Remington Officer In Ad for New Shaver
abstract: LEAD: Remington Products is bringing out a new device, allowing Victor K. Kiam 2d, the chief executive officer, to get in front of the camera again and tell consumers about it.

headline: Warner Signs Lorimar Pact
abstract: LEAD: Warner Communications Inc. and the Lorimar Telepictures Corporation announced today that they had signed a definitive agreement for Warner to acquire Lorimar, producer of ''Dallas'' and other hit TV shows, in a stock swap.

headline: Ecuador Crash Kills General
abstract: LEAD: A small military plane that experts think might have been struck by lightning slammed into a Quito mountainside in a storm Friday evening, killing all 11 people aboard, including Ecuador's air force commander, officials said today. Among the dead was an Israeli military attache, Col. Shabtai Ben-Shoua.

headline: Taiwan Trade Surplus
abstract: LEAD: Taiwan's trade surplus reached a four-year low in March, officials said today. They said the decline should help to ease the island's trade frictions with the United States. The surplus fell to $160 million (American), from $990 million in February and $1.45 billion a year earlier. March exports totaled $4.51 billion, up a bit from $4.31 billion in February, but imports came to $4.35 billion, a sharp rise from $3.32 billion.

headline: Senators to Inquire If the C.I.A. Trained Honduran Torturers
abstract: LEAD: The Senate Intelligence Committee will review allegations that Honduran soldiers trained by the Central Intelligence Agency joined units that tortured civilians, the committee's chairman said today.

headline: Strategies for the End of an Era
abstract: LEAD: FOR American business, the Reagan era had its own distinctive marks: regulation was out, mergers were in and Federal officials were passive in enforcing the thousands of Government rules that executives often see as nettlesome. But with Mr. Reagan's remaining term reduced to seven months, some of the most astute of corporate

headline: Black Labor Congress Plans to Challenge Pretoria
abstract: LEAD: South Africa's major black trade union federation is to hold a three-day work stay-away next month, apparently in defiance of Government restrictions.

headline: LEADERS OF SENATE POSTPONE DEBATE ON MISSILE TREATY
abstract: LEAD: Senate Democratic and Republican leaders said today that the new missile accord will not be brought to the Senate floor until the United States and the Soviet Union resolve important differences over monitoring compliance with the pact.

headline: Real Estate; A Municipal Complex for New Haven
abstract: LEAD: NEARLY eight years after a tightening of municipal purse strings halted construction of a new city hall in New Haven, the ambitious project has resumed.

headline: Mexican Inflation Slows
abstract: LEAD: Prices in Mexico rose 3.1 percent in April, which was less than the 5.1 percent increase in March, the Banco de Mexico reported today. Inflation in the 12 months ended April 30 was 161.3 percent, the central bank added.

headline: Business People; Bone Marrow Company Names Chief Executive
abstract: LEAD: Arthur J. Benvenuto's extensive experience in the pharmaceutical field and in top management led to his selection as chairman, president and chief executive of Marrow-Tech Inc., the company said Monday.

headline: Calvin's Old City Carps About U.N.
abstract: LEAD: Revolutionaries have always appreciated Geneva's calm. Calvin, Voltaire, Rousseau and Lenin all lived here. But their ideas were exported, to rock the thrones of kings and bishops in other parts of Europe.

headline: Justices Allow the States To Curb Gasoline Prices
abstract: LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled by 8 to 0 today that Puerto Rico may regulate the price of gasoline, and that the 50 states are free to do the same if they choose.
