headline: Renaissance Picks Editor
abstract: LEAD: Robert Manning, 68 years old, former editor in chief of The Atlantic, has been named editor in chief of Renaissance, the Magazine for Living Well, which is expected to seek an audience of readers 55 and over who are both sophisticated and affluent.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Product News Reports Introductions
abstract: LEAD: Because the New Product News under the new ownership of Gorman Publishing has changed the way it reports introductions, it doesn't make sense to compare monthly 1988 reports with those of previous years. However, the May declined dramatically from April, although last year May was up from April. The May 1988 figure was 883 compared with

headline: Big Gains in Treasury Issues Pared
abstract: LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices posted sharp early gains yesterday that were pared by afternoon bouts of profit taking. Dealers attributed the early gains to relief that the Producer Price Index rose an unexpectedly moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in April.

headline: Edelman Group Has 7.6% of Payless
abstract: LEAD: Asher B. Edelman, the New York investor, said that he and Sutherland Lumber-Southwest Inc. of Kansas City, Mo., headed a group of investors that had acquired 2.56 million shares, or 7.6 percent, of Payless Cashways Inc., an operator of a chain of building materials stores, also based in Kansas City.

headline: Aranyaprathet Journal; For Innocents Scathed by War, a Sort of Self-Help
abstract: LEAD: For several thousand Cambodian refugees and poor Thai villagers struggling to survive along a border pockmarked by war, the unending battle for Cambodia has exacted a particularly heavy price. Wounded in battle, blown up by land mines, struck down by epidemic diseases or born with birth defects, they have become a handicapped minority in a small world already full of suffering and death.

headline: 100 of Chernobyl's Evacuees Said to Have Sneaked Home
abstract: LEAD: About 100 people who were evacuated from Chernobyl have sneaked back to their homes in areas where radiation levels are still above normal, the official press agency Tass said today.

headline: Canada Sees Acid-Rain Talks
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada, completing a two-day state visit here, said today that President Reagan had agreed to a high-level discussion of Canada's plan to reduce acid rain that crosses the border between the two countries.

headline: Intermedics Agrees To Bid From Sulzer
abstract: LEAD: Intermedics Inc. a leading manufacturer of cardiac pacemakers and orthopedic implants, has agreed to be acquired by Sulzer Brothers Inc., a subsidiary of Sulzer Brothers Ltd. of Switzerland, in a cash tender offer worth about $800 million. Sulzer's tender offer of $43 a share for each of the Angleton,

headline: Report on Drought Due
abstract: LEAD: New projections of how much damage the drought has done to this year's harvests will be issued in two weeks by the United States Department of Agriculture. The special forecast will be in the department's regular crop report on July 12 and will include new figures adjusted for damage done by this year's heat and drought, Assistant Secretary Ewen M.

headline: Goodrich Stake Held by Goldsmith
abstract: LEAD: The British financier Sir James Goldsmith has acquired a stake in the B. F. Goodrich Company but is not interested in a takeover, Goodrich said. Goodrich issued a statement in response to a report published in USA Today that at least one corporate raider, and possibly two, had acquired stakes in Goodrich.

headline: New Twists in Search for Capital
abstract: LEAD: Wall Street's October crash and subsequent doldrums have not slammed the door on new stock offerings, but investor skittishness is forcing many companies that want new capital to consider alternatives.

headline: Trump Sale Of Resorts Collapses
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump's deal to sell his controlling interest in Resorts International Inc. to Merv Griffin collapsed today, and the men immediately resumed their feud over the Atlantic City hotel-casino company.

headline: Buyers of Braniff To Sell Some Units
abstract: LEAD: An investor group formed by Paine Webber Group Inc. to acquire Braniff Inc. said that it had entered into an agreement to sell some of the airline's airport leasehold interests and rights to American Airlines Inc., a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation. The group said the the sale was ''part of a new operating strategy designed to strengthen Braniff's competitive position in the air travel market.

headline: Reagan Widely Chided On Soviet Rights Issue
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan was widely criticized here today for having attributed human rights abuses in the Soviet Union to bureaucratic inertia, but most of his political critics said this one mistake did not undermine his stern lectures in the first days of the summit about the Soviet treatment of dissidents.

headline: A Soviet Day To Remember Past Victories
abstract: LEAD: When he left Moscow to fight in Germany more than 45 years ago, Vasily Bakumenko knew why he, then just 16 years old, was going to war. ''For Stalin, for Stalin,'' said the veteran, now 61 years old. ''We were so sure. We wrote it on our tanks and our helmets. For Stalin.''

headline: Blast Damages U.S. Frigate in Gulf
abstract: LEAD: An underwater explosion damaged a United States Navy frigate in the central Persian Gulf today, wounding at least 10 crew members and partially flooding the ship. There were no fatalities, and the ship headed under her own power toward Bahrain.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Faster Computers: Race Is On
abstract: LEAD: The race to create ever-faster computers has spawned almost two dozen small high-tech companies that are exploiting breakthroughs in software programming and hardware design to create radically different computers.

headline: Former Pilot Says Waldheim Saved Him From Nazi Killers
abstract: LEAD: A former British fighter pilot was quoted today as saying that Kurt Waldheim, now President of Austria, saved his life and those of other Allied prisoners during World War II by keeping them from Nazi executioners.

headline: Hewlett Net Rises by 25%
abstract: LEAD: Buoyed by strong sales of its new products, the Hewlett-Packard Company reported today that earnings were up 25 percent in the quarter ended April 30.

headline: Short Period of Rate Stability Seen
abstract: LEAD: After rising steadily since early March, interest rates are likely to stabilize at close to their current levels for the next few weeks. But most credit market analysts assert that the pause will be temporary, and that yields will rise further later in the quarter.

headline: New Threat to A.H. Robins's Plan
abstract: LEAD: A coalition of Dalkon Shield claimants, lawyers and consumer and health advocacy groups yesterday called on all women with Dalkon Shield claims against the A. H. Robins Company to vote against the company's proposed reorganization plan.

headline: Economic Scene; Pressures to Cut Military Spending
abstract: LEAD: ECONOMIC pressures are driving both the Russians and Americans to reduce costly military programs. On the Soviet side, the downslide of the rate of economic growth, which has been going on since the 1950's, threatens the Government's military strength, its leadership of the Communist countries and even its ability to control its rim countries, like

headline: Snyder General Adds Allis Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Snyder General Corporation agreed today to acquire the Allis-Chalmers Corporation's air quality control subsidiary for $245 million cash, the two companies announced.

headline: Pretoria and Mozambique in Pact
abstract: LEAD: Mozambican and South African officials agreed at a meeting in Maputo today to revive a nonaggression pact prohibiting support for guerrilla groups operating from each other's territories.

headline: Rights Measure Disturbs Hopes for Soviet Trade
abstract: LEAD: While President Reagan was holding out hope for increased Soviet-American trade at the Moscow summit meeting, Congress was weighing action that would make it more difficult for the Administration to reduce barriers to Soviet imports.

headline: Eastern Loss Seen From Safety Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, said today that the Federal safety investigation of Eastern Airlines would cause the carrier to post a loss for the current quarter.

headline: Texas Bank Unsure of Rescue Cost
abstract: LEAD: The recapitalization of the First Republicbank Corporation is likely to be completed this year but the amount of aid that will be needed from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation is impossible to estimate, Albert V. Casey, the banking company's chairman and chief executive, told reporters today.

headline: New Leader Reported At China Central Bank
abstract: LEAD: A Hong Kong newspaper has reported that a 50-year-old Soviet-trained engineer, Li Guixian, has been chosen to head China's central bank, the People's Bank of China.

headline: Malaysia in Cocoa Talks
abstract: LEAD: Malaysia will consider joining the International Cocoa Organization after talks were held between a cocoa organization delegation and Malaysia's Minister of Primary Industries, Lim Keng Yaik, the organization said today.

headline: Article 073688 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: In a deal that will create the nation's largest grocery store chain, Lucky Stores Inc. agreed today to accept a sweetened takeover bid from the American Stores Company for $65 a share, or $2.51 billion in cash.

headline: House Defeats G.O.P. Bid To Amend Law on Contra Aid
abstract: LEAD: A surprise attempt by House Republicans to amend a 1983 law banning the use of the C.I.A.'s contingency fund to finance future covert military aid to the Nicaraguans contra rebels failed today.

headline: Market Place; Analysts Favor Big 3 Auto Stocks
abstract: LEAD: Despite surprisingly robust car and truck sales so far this year and some stronger-than-expected earnings, investors have largely been undervaluing the shares of the Big Three domestic automobile companies, according to a growing number of analysts who follow the industry.

headline: DeBartolo Case Delayed
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a hearing in Federal court in Washington with attorneys representing the real estate developer Edward J. Debartolo Sr., his son and his company had been indefinitely postponed because of an agreement by the attorneys to cooperate fully with the

headline: A New Effort in Japan To Change Tax System
abstract: LEAD: Japan's ruling party formally approved a plan today for the most sweeping overhaul of the tax system in 38 years, its second effort in a year to tackle an issue that has proved to be political dynamite.

headline: Paine Webber Banker Looking for a Change
abstract: LEAD: W. Peter Slusser, who built the mergers and acquisitions department at Paine Webber Inc., is planning to practice his investment banking skills elsewhere, at either an existing firm or one he establishes.

headline: Apple Computer
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. announced a reorganization of its sales and marketing organization aimed at increasing sales overseas and to American corporations. The Cupertino, Calif., personal computer company said it would divide its domestic sales and marketing effort into six divisions, all reporting to Charles M.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Atlantic Financial Federal-West Virginia, Charleston - the state's largest savings and loan association and a unit of Atlantic Financial Federal, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. - named Patrick A. Bond president.

headline: Penchina's Morale Gets a Lift
abstract: LEAD: PENCHINA, SELKOWITZ, a creative little agency in the $20 million class, has just finished a project for the mighty Unilever United States that has been very good for morale.

headline: Prices of Bonds and Notes Drop
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes sagged in quiet trading yesterday although the Government's borrowing needs at next week's quarterly refunding will be somewhat less than had been anticipated.

headline: Farm Lender Revises Policy
abstract: LEAD: Long-awaited Federal regulations to overhaul the lending policies of the Farmers Home Administration are expected to cost $8.7 billion and push as many as 65,000 farmers into liquidation or foreclosure, the agency, a part of the Agriculture Department, said.

headline: Cyprus to Buy A Copper Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Inspiration Resources Corporation, a leading producer of metals and agricultural products, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Inspiration Consolidated Copper Company subsidiary to the Cyprus Mineral Company, for about $125 million.

headline: Panama's Crisis Threatening Major Farmers With Extinction
abstract: LEAD: This country's large private farmers, who helped make Panama self-sufficient in agriculture more than 15 years ago, are on the brink of financial oblivion as a result of the crisis over the continued rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

headline: Argentina Will End Most Curbs on Prices
abstract: LEAD: Ending its latest unsuccessful effort to halt inflation through wage and price controls, Argentina announced today that most price controls would be lifted April 16.

headline: Hanson Trust Names A New Vice Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Hanson Trust P.L.C., the British industrial giant, has named Martin G. Taylor, a longtime Hanson executive, as a vice chairman.

headline: Korean Strikes Disrupt Hyundai's Operations
abstract: LEAD: The management of the Hyundai Motor Company locked out 20,000 striking workers today and said there was little chance of quickly settling the strike for higher wages.

headline: Bhopal Issue Of Sabotage
abstract: LEAD: A report from a consulting firm hired by the Union Carbide Corporation said today that sabotage by a disgruntled employee, not negligence, had caused the deadly gas leak at a subsidiary's plant in Bhopal, India.

headline: Oil Group's Ecuador Pact
abstract: LEAD: A United States-Dutch consortium has signed a contract with the Government to explore for and produce oil in Ecuador's eastern Amazon River basin, the Government said.

headline: Ford Bonuses Rise Sharply
abstract: LEAD: The top two executives of the Ford Motor Company, which had record profits of $4.6 billion in 1987, received multimillion-dollar bonuses last year, the company's proxy statement disclosed today.

headline: Seeing Dollar Signs In Searching the Stars
abstract: LEAD: LYNNE PALMER mentioned that versatility is important if you're a professional astrologer. You could see that right away in her Manhattan living room. In one nook, she had a tape recorder set up to record her client readings. Lying on the coffee table was a sampling of the 14 books she had written, including ''Use Astrology and Change Your Name'' and ''Nixon's Horoscope.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD: Bank of New York Company reached agreement with Irving's preferred shareholders to waive a ''poison pill'' provision that would block a takeover. It must win a proxy fight at Irving's annual meeting today to drop the remaining barriers.  [ D1. ]

headline: U.S. AIDE HOPEFUL ON ANGOLA TALKS
abstract: LEAD: The leaders of the United States and the Soviet Union may make progress toward resolving the conflict in Angola when they meet later this month in Moscow, a State Department official said today.

headline: The Metamorphosis at Primerica
abstract: LEAD: Gerald Tsai Jr., chairman of the Primerica Corporation and architect of its transformation from the American Can Company, continues to wheel and deal, selling subsidiaries to reduce debts incurred during its rapid expansion into the insurance and securities businesses.

headline: Chicago Bank's Money Is Back
abstract: LEAD: The First National Bank of Chicago has recovered the last of the nearly $70 million embezzled in a fund transfer scheme, according to officials of the bank. The remaining $19.8 million was returned by the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, along with $37,046 in interest, they said Tuesday.

headline: Market Place; Investors Ignore Wal-Mart Gains
abstract: LEAD: BETWEEN an industry like retailing that loves self-promotion and a Wall Street that has learned to be cautious, even the most glowing example of success can have a difficult time finding recognition.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Watch Means a New Song for TV
abstract: LEAD: AFTER an exhaustive search of old songs to find the right timely tune to introduce a new higher-priced Citizen watch, Lee Garfinkel and Alan Chalfin of Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver came up with ''It Takes Time.'' Louis Armstrong recorded it in the 1940's.

headline: Marine Midland Car Loans Back $254 Million Offering
abstract: LEAD: This year's volume of asset-backed securities could outpace last year's total of $9.98 billion, with the number of issuers and types of assets expanding. Already the assets backing securities include car loans, credit cards, trade receiveables and leases for computers and automobiles.

headline: J.&J. Ends Playtex Talks
abstract: LEAD: Johnson & Johnson said today that it had ended negotiations to acquire Playtex Family Products.

headline: Afghan Islamic Parties: 7 in Search of a Leader
abstract: LEAD: The Afghan guerrilla alliance is entering a crucial period when, with the Soviet army withdrawing, it may have a chance to seize and govern the country though it is not a unified liberation movement under a generally accepted leadership.

headline: Debt
abstract: LEAD: American Express Credit Corp. has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a $1 billion shelf offering of debt securities and warrants to purchase debt securities.

headline: U.S. SAID TO IGNORE NORIEGA DRUG ROLE
abstract: LEAD: A former State Department official testified today that the Reagan Administration passed up an opportunity in 1986 to foster opposition to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian military leader.

headline: A.T.&T. Computer Sales Are Rising
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's sales of computers are on the rise, ending more than a year of stagnant or declining sales, the new president of A.T.&T.'s Data Systems Group said. Robert M. Kavner said in an interview that the group's sales were ''growing dramatically'' and that the business was ahead of its financial plan for 1988.

headline: Unisys, Sun Microsystems and Apollo Up
abstract: LEAD: The Unisys Corporation, the nation's second-largest computer manufacturer after I.B.M., said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 35.5 percent from the period a year earlier. The company said earnings had exceeded expectations and attributed the gains to cost-cutting measures as well as strong sales of work stations, document processors and entry-level and medium-range mainframe computers.

headline: Iran Says It Killed Many Iraqis in New Drive
abstract: LEAD: Iran said today that its troops had killed or wounded 2,700 Iraqi soldiers in a major new drive into northeastern Iraq.

headline: Suchard Increases Stake in Rowntree
abstract: LEAD: Jacobs Suchard S.A., a Swiss food and confectionery maker, raised its stake in the British confectioner Rowntree P.L.C. to 29.9 percent, the maximum allowed under British law short of a full takeover bid. Jacobs Suchard has paid an estimated $:450 million (about $841 million) for the Rowntree shares, which it has acquired gradually since getting a 14.9 percent stake on April 13.

headline: Investors at Lear Oppose Stock Plan
abstract: LEAD: A group of investment partnerships that controls 10.4 percent of the preferred stock of the Lear Petroleum Corporation said they would oppose the terms under which the British Petroleum Corporation has agreed to redeem Lear's preferred shares. The redemption is part of BP America's merger agreement with the Dallas-based natural gas transport concern.

headline: Dow Rises 2.15 Points, To 1,968
abstract: LEAD: The stock market failed to shake off its worries about interest rates and inflation yesterday although the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 37.80 points on Wednesday, managed to regain 2.15 points to close at 1,968.00.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; HIGH-PROTEIN DRINK
abstract: LEAD: Marty Liquori, 39, one-time track star who is now a leader in the fitness industry and a sports broadcaster, has agreed to become a marketing consultant and spokesman for Go!, a high-protein milk drink concocted by Dr. J. Robert Cade, who invented Gatorade. He signed the contract with Phoenix Advanced Technology whose Nutri-Products subsididary has Go!

headline: Human Rights Lawyer Is Killed in Philippines
abstract: LEAD: One of the Philippines' most respected human rights lawyers has been shot dead, the police said this weekend.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Scott Paper Search Is Down to 3 Agencies
abstract: LEAD: The Scott Paper Company, which started a search for a new agency March 1 and has been totally open about its progress since, announced yesterday that it had cut the field to three from five and should have a winner by June 1.

headline: Detroit Papers' Petition
abstract: LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese said today that he expected to issue a ruling soon on a request to grant a joint operating agreement to The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press. The News, owned by the Gannett Company and The Free Press, owned by Knight-Ridder Inc., have both said they are losing money and cannot continue to publish without the operating agreement.

headline: Proxy Fight Ends at Irving And Each Side Says It Won
abstract: LEAD: The chairmen of the Irving Bank Corporation and the Bank of New York each predicted victory yesterday after a proxy contest at Irving's annual meeting.

headline: Europe Inc.
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Nucorp Case Acquittals
abstract: LEAD: A jury in San Diego yesterday found the defendants not guilty in a securities fraud case involving Nucorp Energy Inc.

headline: N. W>. Ayer to Open Dallas Office for Penney
abstract: LEAD: In order to better serve its client J. C. Penney, the giant retail chain that has moved its headquarters to Dallas, N. W. Ayer will open a full-service office there on June 1. It will be staffed largely by indigenous personnel.

headline: Tracy-Locke to Handle Dial's New Products
abstract: LEAD: Tracy-Locke, Dallas, a subsidiary of the Omnicom Group, has gotten a new job from the Dial Corporation, for which it began doing new product work earlier this year. It has been appointed agency of record for all of Dial's spot TV and spot radio buying for consumer products.

headline: Members Only to Begin Get-Out-the-Vote Ads
abstract: LEAD: Next Oct. 17, Members Only, a leading manufacturer of men's outerwear, will begin a three-week, $1 million-a-week advertising campaign aimed at getting out the vote for the national elections.

headline: Haitian Chief Surprised By Coup, Brother Says
abstract: LEAD: As Haiti's new military Government began organizing itself, details of the coup that returned Lieut. Gen. Henri Namphy to power began to emerge today. There were indications that the general himself might have been among the most surprised by the events Sunday night.

headline: For Anguilla, Tie to London Is Prosperity
abstract: LEAD: For six months, the Government of this little British possession in the Caribbean has been trying to find 11 good men or women who would like to become members of the Anguilla Police Force.

headline: Pivotal Days For France
abstract: LEAD: In a watershed parliamentary election, France's voters have effectively invited their politicians to abandon an ideological confrontation between right and left and to give the country pragmatic, middle-of-the-road government.

headline: Swedish Justice Chief Quits Over Inquiry on Palme Death
abstract: LEAD: Justice Minister Anna-Greta Leijon resigned today over a secret investigation she authorized in the murder of Prime Minister Olof Palme. The resignation averted a confidence vote that threatened to bring down the Government.

headline: Previous Reagan-Gorbachev Summits
abstract: LEAD:  GENEVA Nov. 19-21, 1985

headline: Texas Bank Loss Put at $1.5 Billion
abstract: LEAD: The deeply troubled First Republicbank Corporation today estimated a loss of $1.5 billion for the first quarter, mainly because of increased reserves for escalating problems with its real estate loans. That estimate is three times what analysts had anticipated.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 3 Companies Being Acquired
abstract: LEAD: There is a rush on to acquire sales promotion companies, and it must be a reflection of the fact that larger slices of the marketing pie are being diverted to that discipline.

headline: S.E.C. Backs Bid to Restore Confidence in O-T-C Market
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a series of proposals by the National Association of Securities Dealers aimed at restoring public confidence in a stock trading system that was nearly paralyzed by customer orders during the October stock market crash.

headline: F.D.A. Move Aids Tiny Company
abstract: LEAD: For years the cervical cap has been a cause celebre for a relatively small group of American feminists and health professionals. But this thimble-shaped birth control device has been little known beyond its circle of enthusiasts.

headline: Mark Turken Begins 'Restaurant Channel'
abstract: LEAD: Mark Turken thinks, breathes and dreams restaurants. And so might you if you had an ad agency with 125 restaurant clients, as he does at 250 West 57th Street.

headline: No-Lose Road Game for White Sox
abstract: LEAD: In this city where politics is considered a big-time sport, Jerry Reinsdorf and Eddie Einhorn are proving themselves major league players.

headline: Election's Price in France: Values Above All
abstract: LEAD: The word is on every politician's lips: ''valeurs,'' or values. Sensing a popular backlash against their traditional discourse, French politicians of the right and the left are appealing to values rather than dwelling on economic or social issues The emphasis on values suggests the fluidity of a campaign in which President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, has managed to cast himself as an almost nonpartisan, essentially conservative figure.

headline: Cooper Says It Is Seeking Buyers
abstract: LEAD: The Cooper Companies said that the board of directors had decided to seek a buyer for the whole company or for any or all of its businesses individually. The decision follows an announcement last week by the Federal Trade Commission that it will seek to block Cooper's proposed sale of its contact-lens business to the Schering-Plough Corporation because it would reduce competition in soft contact lenses.

headline: Japan, Under Pressure, Is Raising Foreign Aid
abstract: LEAD: Under pressure to spend more of its wealth to help developing countries, Japan today approved a $50 billion foreign-aid plan for the next five years that will probably make it the world's No. 1 donor.

headline: New Future For Queens Warehouse
abstract: LEAD: WHEN a group of developers bought a former Gimbels warehouse in Long Island City in 1986, their plan was to transform the huge five-story structure into a mixed-use commercial building primarily for office and furniture design tenants.

headline: Pretoria Pass Law Dies, but Spirit Lives
abstract: LEAD: Two years after the Government abolished its pass laws controlling the movements of South Africa's blacks, those whose presence in white areas was considered illegal no longer face arrest, but many others remain trapped in the other legal restraints of apartheid.

headline: Trade Chief Replaced In Canadian Shuffle
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has shuffled his Cabinet with major changes in the trade and immigration portfolios.

headline: Hanoi Move Raises U.S. Hope For Regional Gains at Summit
abstract: LEAD: American officials said today that Vietnam's pledge to withdraw 50,000 troops from Cambodia had raised their hopes for progress on a range of regional disputes at the Moscow summit talks.

headline: Dominican Republic Tourism Surges
abstract: LEAD: Fountains gush on the perimeter of the driveway and lights flash along the rim of the long pink cement canopy of the Jaragua Hotel - the latest and by far the plushest resort to open in the Dominican Republic.

headline: Industrial Output Up 0.4% in May
abstract: LEAD: A boom in the manufacture of business equipment and a pickup at automobile plants helped lift the nation's industrial production by a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in May.

headline: Signs of Strength Keep Cropping Up
abstract: LEAD: More signs of strength in the economy emerged. The unemployment rate in March fell to 5.5 percent, the lowest in a decade. The decline of one-tenth of a percentage point means that 6.8 million people are unemployed, 137,000 fewer than in February. The leading indicators' index climbed nine-tenths of 1 percent in February, after posting declines in three of the four preceding months.

headline: BOMB WOUNDS 10 IN JOHANNESBURG
abstract: LEAD: Ten people were wounded today when a bomb exploded in a downtown Johannesburg amusement arcade. The blast was another in a series of urban guerrilla attacks that appear to have been conducted without regard for civilian casualties.

headline: JUDGE RULES P.L.O. CAN RETAIN OFFICE
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that the United States Government could not force the Palestine Liberation Organization to close its observer mission to the United Nations in New York.

headline: Japan May Join Air Venture
abstract: LEAD: Japan and the United States are expected to explore the possibility of jointly developing a supersonic airliner that could fly between Tokyo and New York in two and a half hours, a Japanese Government spokesman said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Peanut Butter Is Topic Of an Ad Controversy
abstract: LEAD: The May report from the national advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus, the advertising industry's self-policing unit, discloses that there was a heated controversy between Procter & Gamble and the Best Foods division of CPC International over peanut content in crunchy peanut butter.

headline: Santo Domingo's Labor-Cost Lure
abstract: LEAD: New blacktop roads curve past carefully manicured lawns and low-rise, pastel-painted buildings that suggest a small university campus.

headline: New Position for Solomon
abstract: LEAD: Peter J. Solomon was named yesterday to head the new merchant banking division of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which plans to invest primarily in leveraged buyouts.

headline: Sales of Domestic Vehicles Climbed 36.3% in Early May
abstract: LEAD: Sales of new American-made cars and light trucks were up 36.3 percent in early May from the comparable period in 1987.

headline: Bolivar's Treasures Go Home to Venezuela
abstract: LEAD: In his lifetime, Simon Bolivar was a known as a military hero, a political dreamer and a legendary lover. But since his death in 1830, the Venezuelan-born Liberator has gradually assumed the stature of a demigod in the country that he helped to free from Spanish rule.

headline: Japan-U.S. Trade Rift
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Japan remained far apart today in talks on United States access to the Japanese market for everything from semiconductors to citrus and beef.

headline: Proxmire Assails Report on Stock Fall
abstract: LEAD: Senator William Proxmire strongly criticized the White House working group on the stock market collapse today, calling the report it issued last week ''pitiful'' and ''very disappointing.''

headline: 2 Act to Lift Stake In Henley Concern
abstract: LEAD: Two Middle Eastern businessmen -Toufic Aboukhater of Lebanon and Said Khoury of Kuwait - said they plan to seek Federal approval to raise their stake in the Henley Manufacturing Company to more than 15 percent, from 12.9 percent.

headline: Ad Agencies' Obsession With Winning Awards
abstract: LEAD: The One Show, the pinnacle of advertising awards ceremonies, takes place this Thursday night, with writers and art directors from more than 600 agencies vying for 45 ''Gold Pencils.'' Just as an Oscar can resurrect a struggling studio and bring fabulous fees to a star, a Gold Pencil can bring new clients to an ad agency and inflated salaries to the honored individual.

headline: Ex-Im Bank Record Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Government agency that assists United States exports reported today that it had lost a record $460.9 million in 1987 and said its financial condition would remain bleak for several years.

headline: Hutton and 2 Ex-Officers Censured by Big Board
abstract: LEAD: E. F. Hutton & Company and two former officials have been censured by the New York Stock Exchange, which accused them of violating exchange rules and securities laws in an illegal check-overdrafting scheme at the firm in the early 1980's, the exchange announced yesterday.

headline: Shamrock's Deal
abstract: LEAD: Shamrock Holdings Inc., unsuccessful in a takeover bid for the music and video retailer Wherehouse Entertainment last year, has agreed to buy Show Industries, parent of a rival California chain, Music Plus, for undisclosed terms. But analysts said Shamrock probably paid about $40 million for the 54-store chain, based on the $118 million price for which Wherehouse was eventually sold.

headline: Rift on Noriega Deepens as Bush And Treasury Chief Oppose Deal
abstract: LEAD: American officials said today that there is a deepening rift within the Reagan Administration over how to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in Panama.

headline: Moscow Summit: Unmaking History and Debating Rights; Soviet Pupils Spared Exams While History Is Rewritten
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has canceled final secondary-school history examinations, which had been scheduled to begin today, until textbooks can be brought up to date with the candid approach to history advocated by the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: Noriega Is Seen at an Advantage As Washington Shifts Approach
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration's new approach to Panama's leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, is perceived in Panama as a risky move that may not resolve the country's political crisis.

headline: Is Cable Cornering the Market?
abstract: LEAD: EVERY Tuesday night, Sheldon Levin, the owner of a children's store in Birmingham, Ala., watches wrestling matches on ESPN. His wife, Tracy, likes movies on Home Box Office and their 5-year-old daughter is a devotee of Nickelodeon, the children's programming service. The Levin's monthly cable bill is $50.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Carlisle Cos., Cincinnati, appointed Robert J. Deffeyes president of its newly formed Memory Products Group, a marketer of complementary computer storage products.

headline: Less Investing by Foreigners
abstract: LEAD: Spending by foreign investors on United States business enterprises last year declined from the record 1986 level but remained well above the levels of earlier years, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD: Economic and Social Council  Meets at 10 A.M.  SOCIAL (SECOND) COMMITTEE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  Trusteeship Council  Meets at 10:30 A.M.

abstract: LEAD:                  THE ECONOMY               Gross National Product   IV Q'87   III Q'87   Year Ago        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $3,880.8   $3,835.9   $3,702.4               Real G.N.P. headline: Iran Says It Defeated Iraqi Counterattack At Northern Frontier
abstract: LEAD: Iran said today that its Revolutionary Guards had repulsed an Iraqi assault in the Mawat region of Kurdistan along the two nations' northern frontier, killing or wounding 3,000 soldiers.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''From an inflationary concern, we may be closer to full employment than we wis but you can't say that from a social point of view.'' - Roger Brinner, an economist at Data Resources.

headline: Options Trading Drops
abstract: LEAD: Trading volume in options at the Chicago Board Options Exchange dropped 41.8 percent in May from a year earlier, totaling 8,115,634 contracts, the exchange said. Volume in the Standard & Poor's 100-stock index options, the most active contract at the exchange, fell 41.9 percent in the period, to 4,452,905 contracts, while individual equity option volume slipped 42.9 percent, to 3,323,689 contracts, the options exchange said.

headline: Noriega Loses Support Among Poor
abstract: LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega portrays himself as the champion of Panama's poor and black, but in this large working-class municipality favored by the regime there is little affection for the general.

headline: Japan Warning On Builders
abstract: LEAD: Japan's construction minister, Ihei Ochi, said Friday that Japan might scrap the construction agreement reached in May with the United States if the United States blocks foreign participation in Federal construction projects.

headline: Farrar, Straus Thrives On Success of 2 Novels
abstract: LEAD: The backbone of publishing is backlist books, those that will still be around years after this season's best sellers have been remaindered. But best sellers are also important, providing not just prestige but help for a publisher's large overhead.

headline: New Obstacles Bog Down Nicaragua Peace Effort
abstract: LEAD: Less than two weeks after contra guerrilla leaders agreed to a cease-fire with the Sandinista Government, new obstacles threatened to slow the Nicaraguan peace process.

headline: For 2 Exiles in Ohio, Incredible Scenes in Moscow
abstract: LEAD: For Yuri and Olga Medvedkov, exiles at home in their new land, the scenes that flickered over the television screen from Moscow this week seemed difficult to believe.

headline: Bear Stearns Earnings Up In Quarter but Fall in Year
abstract: LEAD: The Bear Stearns Companies yesterday reported a 29.1 percent increase in earnings for the fourth fiscal quarter. But the firm's profits for the year dropped 17.9 percent, hurt by October's stock market collapse and higher expenses.

headline: 13 Hostages Are Freed By Rebels in Colombia
abstract: LEAD: Leftist guerrillas today released 13 of the 15 foreigners and journalists they kidnapped last week. The rest were expected to be freed soon.

headline: P.L.O. Agrees on $50 Million to Finance Uprising
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization have overcome sharp differences and set aside $50 million to support the six-month-old Arab uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories, Palestinian representatives said today.

headline: G.&W. Net Rises 1.1%
abstract: LEAD: Gulf and Western Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 1.1 percent on a 13 percent increase in revenues.

headline: Gurkhas Kill 2 Communists
abstract: LEAD: Gurkha militants kidnapped and beheaded two members of the Communist Party of India (Marxist), the police said today.

headline: U.S. Subpoena In Hughes Case
abstract: LEAD: Albert D. Wheelon, who resigned last week as chairman and chief executive of the Hughes Aircraft Corporation, has been named in a subpoena related to a Justice Department investigation of the Los Angeles-based military equipment contractor, a person familiar with the inquiry said today.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Michigan State Building Authority is tentatively offering $78.7 million of revenue bonds. The underwriters are led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  A major shift in U.S. trade policy has won wide support, with President Reagan and Congress agreeing that the U.S. should protect American industries and workers at the expense of free trade. That sentiment is clear despite the dispute over the trade bill that Congress has passed and Mr.

headline: Assad and Shultz Discuss Hostages
abstract: LEAD: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria promised Secretary of State George P. Shultz today that he would continue his efforts to win the release of American hostages in Lebanon. He again spurned an American attempt to bring him into direct negotiations with Israel as part of a regional peace plan.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; King Ranch Appoints An Outsider Chairman
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to shore up the many businesses linked to their south Texas cattle empire, the estimated 100 stockholding members of the King Ranch have turned over the reins to a board of outside directors.

headline: Israelis Recall 16,450 Who Died in War
abstract: LEAD: In former battlefields, in cemeteries, in the schools they attended and at the Wailing Wall, the most sacred Jewish site, Israelis remembered their 16,450 war dead today as they began a three-day holiday marking their 40th year of independent statehood.

headline: Vietnam Picks New Premier; Food Shortages Are Reported
abstract: LEAD: A longtime revolutionary who reportedly directed purges against corruption in Vietnam's ruling Communist Party was chosen Prime Minister today, the Hanoi radio announced.

headline: Latin American Solution Is Seen for Panama
abstract: LEAD: A former Venezuelan President, who has played an active role in trying to end the Panamanian crisis, has asserted that Latin American mediation now offers the best hope of persuading Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to step down from power.

headline: Split Senate Panel Refuses to Back Sanctions Against Mexico
abstract: LEAD: A bitterly divided Senate Foreign Relations Committee refused today to recommend sanctions against Mexico for its involvement in drug production and trafficking.

headline: F.T.C. Ruling On Reynolds
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the reinstatement of a complaint against an R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company advertisement that played down the health hazard from smoking.

headline: ISRAEL BEGINS ITS CAMPAIGN ON ONE ISSUE
abstract: LEAD: The West Bank seems far removed from this cement-block development town just north of the Negev. But a visit from Foreign Minister Shimon Peres made clear that the Palestinian uprising is a blazing political issue for virtually every Israeli.

headline: Cole-Haan to Nike For $80 Million
abstract: LEAD: Nike Inc., based in Beaverton, Ore., agreed to acquire Cole-Haan, a manufacturer of dress and casual shoes, from Cole-Haan Limited Partnership, a private company. The purchase price is about $80 million, plus the repayment of $15 million in debt.

headline: New Irving Proposal By Bank of New York
abstract: LEAD: Rebuffed in its attempt to replace the Irving Bank Corporation's board, the Bank of New York Company yesterday announced a new step in its eight-month battle to acquire Irving.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST saturday, april 16, 1988
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: McDonnell Douglas Gets Big S.A.S. Order
abstract: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today nell Douglas Corporation said today that it had received a $1.5 billion order from the Scandinavian Airline System for 61 MD-80's, its most popular passenger aircraft.

headline: U.S. to Urge Allies to Use East Bloc Loans as Lever
abstract: LEAD: The United States is telling its NATO allies that they should not provide loans or other financial help to Eastern Europe unless countries there first make political changes to replace authoritarian rule with democracy.

headline: Beazer Extends Bid for Koppers
abstract: LEAD: BNS Inc., seeking to take over the Koppers Company for $1.7 billion, extended its hostile tender offer until midnight Wednesday and said it controls more than three-quarters of the Koppers shares. BNS, led by Beazer P.L.C., a British construction company, and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said about 73.2 percent of outstanding common shares and about 68.7 percent of outstanding preferred shares had been tendered as of

headline: Release of Ex-Prisoners By Hanoi Is Discussed
abstract: LEAD: The Vietnamese Foreign Minister said today that Vietnam and the United States had begun discussions on the fate of tens of thousands of former Vietnamese political prisoners and their families.

headline: Menu at the State Dinner
abstract: LEAD: About 100 guests were present tonight at the Kremlin for the state dinner given by Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his wife, Raisa, for President Reagan and his wife, Nancy. Here is the menu, as provided by the Soviet press agency Tass.  Fresh Caviar  Puff Rasstegay  Assorted Fish With Lemon  Stuffed Turkey Fillet With Fruits  Fish Soup a la Suzdal  Asparagus Cream  Pike-Perch Baked With Crabmeat  Loin of Veal Stewed With Vegetables

headline: Israeli High Court Overrules Rabbis by Installing Woman
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Supreme Court overruled the nation's rabbis today by ordering the appointment of the first woman to a religious council that administers synagogues and ritual baths.

headline: Sallie Mae Offers $400 Million Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $400 million of floating-rate notes due on Dec. 8 through various securities dealers. The new floating-rate note is priced at par to yield about 55-hundredths of a percentage point more than the bond-equivalent rate of the 91-day Treasury bill.

headline: Excerpts From the President's Talks to Artists and Students
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's speech to Soviet cultural and artistic figures today, and from his speech to students at Moscow State University and a question-and-answer session with them.  Remarks to Artists

headline: Company News; Fort Howard Bid Weighed
abstract: LEAD: The Fort Howard Corporation, a paper products company, said yesterday that some of its managers intend to explore the possibility of acquiring the company in a leveraged buyout with the help of third parties. The company, based in

headline: Ethiopian and Somali Forces Withdrawn Under Agreement
abstract: LEAD: Ethiopian and Somali armies have completed a disengagement of forces along their border in accordance with the peace agreement signed by the two former enemies earlier this month, Ethiopia said today.

headline: Taiwan Trade Talks End
abstract: LEAD: United States trade negotiators ended four days of talks in Taiwan Friday, saying they had reached no agreement on the vital issues of copyright, tariff cuts and access for United States financial institutions.

headline: S.E.C. Discloses Insider Scheme Worth Millions
abstract: LEAD: In a court filing suggesting that blatant insider trading is far from dead, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that a 24-year-old junior analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company had sold confidential information on at least 25 proposed corporate takeovers.

headline: I.B.M. to Market Image Processing
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it plans to enter the image processing market, providing image storage and retrieval systems for large corporate users. I.B.M. introduced a set of component products ranging from data base management software to an optical disk storage system that will be marketed under the name Imageplus.

headline: KUWAIT CALLED ON TO FREE PRISONERS
abstract: LEAD: A man identified as one of the three members of Kuwait's royal family held hostage on the hijacked Kuwaiti jetliner said today that he hoped his Government would yield to the gunmen's demands to end the two-week ordeal.

headline: Prudential-Bache Is Leader In 2 Tax-Exempt Offerings
abstract: LEAD: In the competitive market yesterday, Prudential-Bache Securities was lead underwriter for the groups submitting the winning bids on tax-exempt bonds issued by the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, and the Florida State Board of Regents.

headline: A New Twist For National Print-Ad Idea
abstract: LEAD: DALE LANG, who in 1968 created the Media Networks Inc. concept that allowed national magazines to compete locally for the advertising dollar, is going to try it again with a new twist.

headline: Some Progress Reported at Southern Africa Talks
abstract: LEAD: Representatives of the United States, South Africa, Cuba and Angola reported some progress in negotiations over the weekend toward ending 13 years of war in Angola and South-West Africa.

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Is Losing Its President
abstract: LEAD: Peter F. McSpadden, the top Saatchi & Saatchi DFS executive on both the RJR Nabisco and Northwest Airlines accounts, will be leaving the company around September, a highly placed agency executive confirmed yesterday.

headline: Gray Areas
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: 3 Executives Are Indicted
abstract: LEAD: Two former marketing executives of the Anheuser-Busch Companies and a former supplier to the beer maker were indicted by a grand jury on charges of mail fraud, conspiracy and Federal tax offenses.

headline: Gibbons Green's Deal With Lucky
abstract: LEAD: Lucky Stores Inc. disclosed that it would pay the New York investment firm Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen Ltd. $20 million as a ''breakup fee'' if Lucky Stores canceled the $2.4 billion merger agreement between the two parties in favor of a higher bid.

headline: Hachette's Plans For Grolier Inc.
abstract: LEAD: Hachette S.A., the Paris-based publishing company that is trying to acquire Grolier Inc., said that if its offer succeeded it would sell Grolier's educational toy unit to the Walt Disney Company for $52 million. Grolier, which publishes encyclopedias and is based in Danbury, Conn., rejected as inadequate the initial $21-a-share offer by

headline: Article 946788 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: With little more than a week remaining before Carl C. Icahn takes on Texaco Inc. in a proxy fight at its annual stockholders meeting, the company announced yesterday that it would spend nearly $1.7 billion, only part of it in cash, to buy back stock by year's end.

headline: Carbide Plea to India Judge
abstract: LEAD: Lawyers for the Union Carbide Corporation have asked District Court Judge M. W. Deo to remove himself from hearing India's $3 billion suit against the company. The suit charges negligence in the 1984 Bhopal gas leak disaster.

headline: CORNUCOPIA OF HERESIES BURSTS INTO SOVIET PRESS
abstract: LEAD: Here are a few thoughts on how to make the Soviet Union more democratic: Curb the powers of the K.G.B. Abolish the system of internal passports. Create new political organizations to compete with the Communist Party. Publish the party's secret budget. Print transcripts of meetings of the ruling Politburo.

headline: How to Succeed as 'Attila the Hun'
abstract: LEAD: After receiving advice from Lee Iacocca, Donald Trump, T. Boone Pickens and many other captains of industry and high finance, business executives will soon be receiving management tips from Attila the Hun.

headline: New Famous Amos Owner Wants Bigger Market Share
abstract: LEAD: ''Mental real estate'' is how Jeffery B. Baer, a Denver investor and entrepreneur, described the reason for his family's acquisition of the Famous Amos Chocolate Chip Cookie Corporation ''It needs to be developed,'' Mr. Baer, Amos's new chairman, said after the Friday announcement. ''It's not a piece of ground, but the principle is the same.

headline: Lomas & Nettleton
abstract: LEAD: The Lomas & Nettleton Financial Corporation is making a $200 million debt offering through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. The 10 3/4 percent subordinated notes due in 1993 are priced at par, to yield about 2.25 percentage points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Underwriters said the issue is noncallable and rated Ba-2 by Moody's and BBB by S.&P.

headline: British Raise Rate on Loans
abstract: LEAD: Britain's commercial banks, heeding a signal from the Bank of England, today announced an increase of half a percentage point in their base lending rate, to 9.5 percent.

headline: Senate Avoids Vote on Keeping Forces in Gulf
abstract: LEAD: The Senate today blocked formal authorization of the continued presence of American military forces in the Persian Gulf under provisions of the 1973 War Powers Resolution.

headline: Roundtable Picks Chief
abstract: LEAD: The Business Roundtable, a group of about 200 chief executives of major corporations, yesterday elected Edmund T. Pratt Jr., chairman and chief executive of Pfizer Inc., as its chairman. He succeeds Roger B. Smith, chairman and chief executive of the General Motors Corporation, who headed the organization for two years.

headline: GERMANS ARE WARY OF JEWISH SCANDAL
abstract: LEAD: In the week since the news broke that the much-honored head of West Germany's main Jewish organization evidently helped himself to millions in money intended for victims of the Nazis, the dominant reaction among politicians and newspapers has been a nervous circumspection.

headline: Philippines Renegade Hints at New Coup Try
abstract: LEAD: The fugitive leader of an attempted coup hinted strongly today that he would try again.

headline: Japan in Pact On Beef and Citrus Trade
abstract: LEAD: After years of bitter wrangling, Japan and the United States agreed this morning on measures that would significantly expand Japan's market for American beef and oranges.

headline: The Race to Commercialize Substitutes
abstract: LEAD: Allied-Signal Inc. is the second largest domestic producer of chlorofluorocarbons. Marylyn I. Montgomery, vice president and general manager of Allied-Signal's Genetron business, and Bernard Sukornick, director of fluorochemicals research, talked with the Business Forum editor, Joel Kurtzman, about why Allied-Signal plans to continue production of chlorofluorocarbons as it seeks suitable substitutes.

headline: Navistar Plan Cited at Trial
abstract: LEAD: The Navistar International Corporation's sale of its money-losing Wisconsin Steel unit in 1977 was part of a strategy to leave the steel business, not an attempt to avoid pension obligations to workers, according to a company lawyer.

headline: McGraw-Hill to Sell Stake in Japan Venture
abstract: LEAD: McGraw-Hill Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 49 percent stake in Nikkei/McGraw-Hill Inc., a joint-venture publishing company in Japan, for $283 million.

headline: Texaco Contests Some Bankruptcy Fees
abstract: LEAD: Requests by financial and legal professionals for more than $50 million in fees for their work on Texaco Inc.'s huge bankruptcy proceeding provoked name-calling and bickering yesterday at the Federal Bankruptcy Court here.

headline: Da Lat Journal; Among the Faded Snapshots, a Middle Class Dies
abstract: LEAD: Duong Quang Trong is missing in action. His name appears on no list, because in Vietnam there are no comprehensive records of the casualties of war. They are too numerous to count, and there are more urgent tasks.

headline: Soviet Relinquishes Afghan Province
abstract: LEAD: Soviet officials said today that Russian troops had completed their withdrawal from a key eastern Afghan border province that has served as a buffer protecting the area around this capital city from guerrillas based in Pakistan.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, which makes electrical appliances and personal-care products, said negotiations to sell its Thermco Systems Inc. unit to BTU Engineering of Billerica, Mass., had been ended because of opposition to the proposed merger by the antitrust division of the Justice Department.

headline: Dollar Off a Bit After Selling Spree
abstract: LEAD: The dollar rose again early yesterday but finished slightly lower after a late wave of selling by traders.

headline: P.L.O. Persuades Hijackers of Jet to Back Off Threat of 'Massacre'
abstract: LEAD: The hijackers of a Kuwaiti airliner vowed on Sunday to carry out a ''slow, quiet massacre'' of their passengers, but negotiators persuaded them to pull back from their threat.

headline: Akzo-Du Pont Deal Ends 11-Year Fight
abstract: LEAD: The Dutch chemical company Akzo N.V. and E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company announced a surprise deal today ending what Akzo called ''the biggest industrial patents battle of this century.''

headline: In Diamond Diplomacy, First Round to the Yanks
abstract: LEAD: Today, in the fifth inning, at his home field at the auto factory of Lenin's Komsomol, Aleksei Koshevoy, a 24-year-old pitcher, stepped on home plate and into sports history, the bane of trivia buffs yet unborn.

headline: Coated Sales in Chapter 11
abstract: LEAD: Coated Sales Inc., a specialty textile maker in disarray since it announced big inaccuracies in its financial reports, said today that it had filed in New York for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 29, 1988:          TUESDAY        Becton, Dickinson   Palco Ent        WEDNESDAY        Fieldcrest Cannon   Stanhome Inc        General Dynamics   Stanley Works        Louisville G&E   LS Starrett Co        Natl Convenience Stores   USF&G Corp        Pennwalt Corp        THURSDAY        Allegheny Power   Lucky Stores        Atlantic Energy   SPS Technologies        Bear Stearns   Wal-Mart Stores        Brown Group   Washington National        FRIDAY        Chubb Corp

headline: Water Crisis Imperils India's Farms and Cities
abstract: LEAD: For several weeks now, New Delhi has been struggling to assure itself of enough water this summer for its seven million citizens.

headline: Proposed Insider-Trading Bill Worries Wall St. Lobbyists
abstract: LEAD: The securities industry and its lobbyists are up in arms over a proposed insider-trading law that is quietly being circulated among leading members of the House.

headline: Hornby Reports Manitowoc Stake
abstract: LEAD: Hornby Trading Inc., an investment company controlled by the Belzberg family of Canada, reported in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had purchased a 5.1 percent stake in the Manitowoc Company and said that it might try to seek control of the shipping crane manufacturer.

headline: Court Vindicates 2 Stalin Victims Who Were Close Allies of Lenin's
abstract: LEAD: Two Bolshevik revolutionaries who were executed on charges of treasonous activities after the first of Stalin's show trials in 1936 were cleared today, the newspaper Izvestia reported.

headline: Santa Fe Shareholders Reject 'Poison Pill' Plan
abstract: LEAD: Shareholders of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation voted today to recommend overturning a ''poison pill'' anti-takeover defense instituted by the company's management.

headline: Procurement Hearings Open; Pentagon Criticized in House
abstract: LEAD: Senior officials of the Defense Department marched up Capitol Hill today to assert that the Pentagon's system for procuring weapons works well. They ran into sharp criticism from liberal Democrats and an occasional shot from conservative Republicans, too.

headline: Reagan Says He Was Moved By Contacts With Russians
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan said today that his summit meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev had accomplished ''a good deal of important work'' and that he had found his contacts with the Soviet people in his four days here ''deeply moving.''

headline: McGraw-Hill Acquisition
abstract: LEAD: McGraw Hill Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the scientific and technical book unit of Macmillan Inc. Terms were not disclosed. The book unit has more than 200 scientific and technical titles that are geared to the university, graduate and professional markets. They will be part of the McGraw-Hill Book Company's college, professional and international group.

headline: U.S. Disputes Afghan On Soviet Adviser Issue
abstract: LEAD: The United States today disputed the assertion of the Afghan President, Najibullah, that Soviet military advisers can stay in his country under the terms of a settlement signed in Geneva this month.

headline: Shultz Finds Shamir Still Opposed to Peace Plan
abstract: LEAD: As Palestinians staged a general strike in the occupied territories to protest his visit, Secretary of State George P. Shultz pressed his proposal for Arab-Israeli peace talks today with Israeli leaders. He came away without the endorsement he says he is urgently seeking, but an American official said there was ''a sense of some movement'' in the official

headline: J. C. Penney Sells New York Building
abstract: LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company said it had sold its Manhattan quarters at 1301 Avenue of the Americas for $350 million to a partnership consisting of two national developers - Tishman Speyer Properties Inc. of New York and Trammell Crow Real Estate Investors of Dallas. William R. Howell, Penney's chairman, said the sale would result in a $150 million after-tax gain, to be recorded in August, when the closing is scheduled.

headline: Will the Trade Gap Grow?
abstract: LEAD: The announcement of February's $13.8 billion trade deficit - the largest in six months - sent a shock through the economy. The stock market fell sharply and the dollar dropped too. How should the trade figures for February be understood? Are they part of a trend, or just an aberration?  Carl B.

headline: Accountant Disclosure
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today unanimously approved new rules requiring public companies to disclose more details about their disputes with accounting firms.

headline: Afghan Vacuum: The U.S. Is Wary of Rushing In
abstract: LEAD: With Soviet troops poised to begin their withdrawal Sunday, Afghanistan faces a period of turmoil in which the United States is preparing to play an ambiguous military and political role.

headline: Bitter Trade Debate Near in Ottawa
abstract: LEAD: Seven months after turning Canada's economic policy around by signing a free-trade agreement with the United States, the Government here is entering a decisive phase of its battle for the agreement at home.

headline: Setting Precedent, Estonia Allows A Non-Communist Front to Form
abstract: LEAD: Authorities in the republic of Estonia, in an important precedent for other regions of the Soviet Union, have permitted the creation of the first large-scale political group outside the Communist Party.

headline: Botswana Arrests 2 South Africans in Clash
abstract: LEAD: The Botswana police arrested two white South African commandos early today after a gun battle in which three policemen were wounded, the Government of the neighboring black-ruled nation said today.

headline: Kurdish Chief Gains Support In U.S. Visit
abstract: LEAD: Early this year, after Iran accused Iraq of using chemical weapons again in Kurdish-held border areas, Jalal Talabani slipped through the mountains into Iran to bring the story firsthand to the capitals of the Middle East, Europe and the United States.

headline: Muscovites, in Poll, Are Split On What Their Future Holds
abstract: LEAD: After three years of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's leadership, about half of the Muscovites say they have yet to see tangible benefits from his program of economic change, according to a poll of Moscow residents conducted for The New York Times and CBS News.

headline: Uprising Is the Agenda at Arab Summit
abstract: LEAD: As Secretary of State George P. Shultz concludes another Middle East peace mission, Arab leaders are expected to give strong moral, political and financial support this week to the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories.

headline: Reagan to Nominate Envoy
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan will nominate Deputy Assistant Secretary of State William Graham Walker as ambassador to El Salvador, the White House said today. Mr. Walker would succeed Edwin G. Corr.

headline: Boeing Gets Order For 30 Jetliners
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company has received a $1.4 billion order for 30 jetliners from the International Leisure Group, the parent company of Air Europe Ltd. of Britain. The order consists of 22 of the company's 757-200's and eight of its 737-400's. The 757's, powered by the RB211-535E4 engines of Rolls-Royce P.L.C., will be delivered beginning in 1989.

headline: Cathay Pacific Financing
abstract: LEAD: Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd. has asked Paine Webber Asia Ltd. to arrange $100 million in financing for aircraft leasing, The Hong Kong Economic Journal quoted the bank as saying. It said the money will be used to finance a Boeing 747-300 jumbo jet to be delivered in July. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Soviet Loan From West
abstract: LEAD: Moscow has arranged a new loan for 3.5 billion marks, or $2.1 billion, from the West and is likely to make additional requests for help in modernizing its industries, the head of West Germany's largest commercial bank said today.

headline: P.I.P. Accepts New Buyout Offer
abstract: LEAD: Postal Instant Press, a franchiser of short-term printing and copying centers, said it had agreed to a sweetened buyout proposal of $17.41 a share, or $69.3 million, from an investor group consisting of management and Golder Thoma & Cressey, a Chicago leveraged buyout concern. In February, the group made an initial bid of $17.

headline: European Plea to Japan
abstract: LEAD: A visiting member of the European Parliament, Bernhard Salzer, urged Japan today to open its construction market to Europeans as it has promised to do for American contractors in an accord reached this week.

headline: After NBO Stores' Sale, Founder Has 3d Career
abstract: LEAD: Two significant events occurred recently at NBO Stores Inc., one of the area's largest men's clothing discounters.

headline: U.S. and Soviet Would Suspend Arms Shipments After an Accord
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration and the Soviet Union intend to suspend all arms deliveries to Afghanistan after the conclusion of an agreement of a Soviet troop withdrawal, knowledgeable officials said today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Stores Co., Salt Lake City, said it was willing to negotiate the price of its $1.74 billion takeover offer for Lucky Stores Inc. if it was provided with confidential financial data that the supermarket chain has provided other parties.

headline: United Brands Starts 2 Offerings
abstract: LEAD: The United Brands Company, Cincinnati, said it had begun two offerings worth a total of $212.5 million. A $125 million offering of 11 7/8 percent subordinated debentures is priced at par and due in 2003. A United Brands affiliate, the Great American Communications Company, is offering $87.5 million of 10 1/2 percent debentures priced at 88.45 and due in 2004.

headline: Rodale to Sell Magazine
abstract: LEAD: Rodale Press Inc. said this week that it had reached an agreement to sell its Practical Homeowner, a monthly magazine, to an investment group headed by Harry C. Egner, former president of Citicorp Publishing and publisher of Signature magazine. Rodale, which is based in

headline: New Soviet Motto: Down With Slogans!
abstract: LEAD: In a quiet attack on urban blight and public cynicism, Moscow and other Soviet cities have begun methodically dismantling the huge political slogans that are among the best-known features of the Soviet skyline.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * A.L. Laboratories, Inc., Fort Lee, N.J., which makes pharmaceuticals, animal health products and nutritional beverages, appointed Charles A. Baker to the newly created post of executive vice president and chief operating officer.

headline: Thousands of Hindu Workers Flee Punjab as Sikhs Step Up Violence
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of Hindu migrant workers from eastern India have fled Punjab after more than 50 of them were killed last week by Sikhs, the state's top police official said today.

headline: Irving Seeks More Talks
abstract: LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation said yesterday that its board had told its management and financial advisers to negotiate with the Bank of New York Company and with Banca Commerciale Italiana to get the best terms possible in the bidding for Irving. But Bank of

headline: Ms. Magazine Adds an Editor
abstract: LEAD: Ms. magazine yesterday announced the appointment of Marcia Ann Gillespie as executive editor, a new position.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; MAGAZINE INDUSTRY CAMPAIGN
abstract: LEAD: DETECTING weaknesses in its archfoe, television, the magazine industry will mount a huge attack - a $50 million advertising campaign - during the remainder of the year. And it will be pro-magazines rather than anti-television.

headline: Sandinistas' Economic Shift Falls Short, Opponents Say
abstract: LEAD: Opposition leaders in Nicaragua describe economic measures decreed this week by President Daniel Ortega Saavedra as steps in the right direction, but say they fall far short of what is necessary to set the country on the road to recovery.

headline: Beazer, Shearson Get Summonses
abstract: LEAD: Brian Beazer, the British industrialist, and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. faced a new barrier against their $1.7 billion hostile bid for the Koppers Company when a Federal judge in Los Angeles today summoned them to a contempt of court hearing on June 6. Koppers filed papers Thursday in United States District Court in Los Angeles accusing the Beazer group and Shearson, a unit of the American Express

headline: Lucky Rejects Takeover Offer
abstract: LEAD: Lucky Stores Inc. today rejected an unsolicited $1.74 billion bid from the American Stores Company as inadequate and said it would consider reorganizing or selling the company.

headline: Layoffs at Foley's
abstract: LEAD: Foley's Department Stores said it would lay off 5 percent of its work force, or about 800 employees. Foley's, which was acquired last month by the May Department Stores Company, said the layoffs would affect executives as well as hourly workers. ''It's an attempt to get our operating costs down,'' said Dan Hagan, a Foley's vice president.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Radio Backs Ads in USA Weekend
abstract: LEAD: USA WEEKEND, the innovative Sunday supplement of the Gannett Company, has still another inducement to lure national advertisers into its clutches.

headline: Company News; California Rule Raises Questions
abstract: LEAD: The California statute that has temporarily derailed B.A.T. Industries' $4.3 billion takeover bid for Farmers Group Inc. is a little-used law that is likely to create obstacles for other companies seeking to do business in the state, regulators and lawyers said today.

headline: FLOW OF REFUGEES IS SAID TO DECLINE
abstract: LEAD: The violence that marked the enforcement of a Thai policy of turning back Vietnamese arriving by boat was limited to a few weeks in February, diplomats and refugee officials say. They say the violence has been substantially reduced or eliminated as the number of Vietnamese in Thai waters drops sharply.

headline: Army Believes Israeli Girl Was Killed by a Guard
abstract: LEAD: An Israeli girl whose death brought fierce cries for vengeance against Arabs was not stoned to death, but killed by a bullet from the rifle of a Jewish settler guarding her, the army said today. Senior army commanders said they believed that the guard fired the fatal shot in panic.

headline: Texas Instruments Net Down; Compaq Up
abstract: LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc., a major manufacturer of computer chips, today reported a slightly lower net income for the first quarter, while the profits of Compaq Computer Corporation, a rapidly growing computer maker, nearly doubled. The companies said demand surged for their major products.

headline: Brazil Car Exports Soar
abstract: LEAD: Brazil's motor vehicle exports soared by 72 percent in value in the first quarter of this year, industry figures released today showed. The National Association of Automotive Vehicle Manufacturers said exports from January to March were worth $757 million, compared with $440 million in the first quarter of last year.

headline: Manila Journal; The Belles of St. Scho: Anything but Cloistered
abstract: LEAD: In the blue-and-white uniforms of their convent school, a white flag with a dove of peace fluttering above their heads, the little group of students from St. Scholastica's College stood out from their fellow protesters, tough, sometimes masked marchers bearing militant red banners.

headline: South Africa Apparently Shifting Loyalty to Support Mozambique
abstract: LEAD: Apparently reversing alliances, South Africa is negotiating to train and equip as many as three battalions of Mozambican Government troops, a South African official asserted here today.
