headline: Ailing Brazil Is Divided On Economy
abstract: LEAD: With Brazil caught in its worst economic crisis in decades, the Government and a special Constitutional Assembly are at loggerheads over how to change the country's development strategy.

headline: CNW to Sell Unit
abstract: LEAD: The CNW Corporation said it had agreed to sell its snowplow manufacturing unit, Douglas Dynamics Inc, to Park-Kenilworth Industries for $100 million. Park-Kenilworth is a new holding company affiliated with the Grabill Corporation, a closely held suburban Chicago company. Douglas Dynamics is the nation's largest manufacturer of medium-size snowplows, sold under the Western and Fisher brands, for use on four-wheel-drive pickup trucks and utility vehicles.

headline: Hong Kong Rates
abstract: LEAD: The Hong Kong Association of Banks said on Saturday that it had decided to leave interest rates unchanged at its regular weekly meeting. The banks' prime lending rate is currently 7 1/2 percent.

headline: U.S. Panama Curbs Questioned
abstract: LEAD: Several American companies with operations in Panama said yesterday that they had just received details about the Reagan Administration's sanctions and that they were unsure how to comply with an executive order halting all payments to the Panamanian Government.

headline: Election Could Splinter the French Right
abstract: LEAD: Deep and possibly momentous fissures are opening within France's loosely united rightist parliamentary majority as President Francois Mitterrand, a Socialist, remains a heavy favorite in Sunday's presidential election.

headline: Connecticut Prices $75 Million Issue
abstract: LEAD: The State of Connecticut yesterday tentatively priced $75 million of special tax-obligation bonds for transportation projects.

headline: In a More Open Soviet Society, Freedom Can Sprout, Then Vanish
abstract: LEAD: When Lev M. Timofeyev's daughter was assigned a school essay entitled ''The Happiest Day of My Life,'' the 14-year-old focused on the day in February 1987 when her father came home from prison as a wave of political dissidents was released from Soviet prisons.

headline: New President At Texas Bank
abstract: LEAD: The First City Bancorporation of Texas said today that Robert D. Richley, head of a rapidly growing bank company in San Diego, had been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Houston-based banking company. Mr. Richley, who is 44 years old, will be responsible for First City's $6.9 billion commercial and consumer lending portfolio.

headline: Pre-Summit Talks on Africa
abstract: LEAD: The Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Chester A. Crocker, will meet with the Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Anatoly L. Adamishin, this week for talks on Africa in advance of the Moscow summit meeting in May, the State Department said today. The officials will meet on Thursday and Friday in London.

headline: Mcorp Expects $58.2 Million Loss in First Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Mcorp, the second-largest bank holding company in Texas, said today that it expected a $58.2 million loss for the first quarter, nearly as much as its $59.5 million loss in the last quarter of 1987.

headline: Your Money; How to Cut Back As Costs Increase
abstract: LEAD: If it seems a lot harder to make ends meet, that is not surprising. Living costs for an upper-middle-income family have risen 9 percent in the last year, according to a survey of the 24,000 members of the Atlanta-based International Association for Financial Planning, the largest professional group in the financial-planning industry.

headline: Coniston Discloses Macmillan Stake
abstract: LEAD: Coniston Partners, the investment firm that recently lost a proxy fight with Gillette Inc., said yesterday that it holds a 4.9 percent stake in Macmillan Inc., the publishing company in the throes of a takeover battle.

headline: The Bitter Battle Between Doctors and Chain Stores
abstract: LEAD: TEN years ago, private optometrists and ophthalmologists prescribed and fit 80 percent of all lenses. Today, that figure has shrunk to less than 50 percent, in the face of competition from high-volume retail chains and phone and mail order companies. The largest of the these is Pearle Health Services, a retail chain which fits and sells lenses at 1,300 storefronts in 45 states and recruits optometrists directly from optometry schools.

headline: Police Say 3 Large Drug Groups Joined Forces in Italian Ring
abstract: LEAD: All three of Italy's major underworld organizations have worked together in the trans-Atlantic drug trade, indicating that the New York Mafia families had more extensive contacts here than previously thought, senior Italian police officials said today.

headline: DEATHS REPORTED IN BULGARIA IN TURKISH PROTESTS IN '84-85
abstract: LEAD: Contradicting three years of official denials, a Bulgarian journalist has said that about 40 people died in clashes between militiamen and the country's ethnic Turkish minority.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD: General Assembly  Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.  SPECIAL SESSION ON DISARMAMENT - COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE - 6 and 7 P.M.  COMMITTEE ON THE PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 3 P.M.

headline: 2 Aviation Companies Indicted in Iran Sales
abstract: LEAD: A West German franchisee of the Beech Aircraft Corporation and an Arizona aviation company have been charged with illegally exporting sophisticated military navigational equipment to Iran between 1983 and 1987, according to Federal grand jury indictments unsealed today in San Diego.

headline: Crime Parley Lures a Thief
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Minister said today that his car was stolen while he was attending a conference here on crime. The Minister, Emmerson Munangagwa, told of the theft in a speech during the closing session of a two-day conference on bribery, corruption, fraud and theft. He told the 200 delegates at the meeting, which drew judges and police officers, that the car was stolen on Tuesday, the first day of the meeting.

headline: More Jews Reported Leaving Soviet Union
abstract: LEAD: Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union reached a seven-year high in May as 1,145 Jews were allowed to leave, a resettlement agency said today.

headline: Aquino Begins a Visit to Europe
abstract: LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino left today for a weeklong visit to Switzerland and Italy, a journey her aides said symbolized the country's returning stability.

headline: At Electronic Emporiums, It's the PC Pie
abstract: LEAD: IT used to take at least 30 minutes to make a pizza and far longer to deliver it. So, calling pizza a ''fast food'' was a bit of a misnomer.

headline: Official Says U.S. Wants to Pay U.N.
abstract: LEAD: Responding to pleas by European allies and the United Nations Secretary General, a senior official said today that the Reagan Administration wanted to resume paying the full American share of the United Nations budget.

headline: IRAN IS ALIENATING LEBANON'S SHIITES
abstract: LEAD: An increasing number of Lebanon's Shiite Moslems, among whom Iran has enjoyed wide popularity, have become hostile toward Teheran, which they blame for relentless factional fighting in the southern suburbs of Beirut.

headline: Patents; Reactor Control Rod
abstract: LEAD: A temperature-responsive nuclear reactor shutdown control rod was patented this week for the Department of Energy. Konstantin Bilibin of North Hollywood, Calif., was granted patent 4,734,252. Objects of the invention are described as offering sufficient compactness for contemporary reactors and the opportunity for an operator to reset the device when the coolant is at or below normal temperature.

headline: Macmillan Will Split Into 2 Parts
abstract: LEAD: In a move that caught few Wall Street professionals by surprise, Macmillan Inc., the publishing and information company, took strong defensive moves yesterday in response to a takeover offer from the Robert Bass Group of Texas.

headline: Japan-U.S. Trade Talks Lag
abstract: LEAD: Japan and the United States remain very far apart in negotiations on the beef and citrus issue, the United States trade negotiator, Michael Smith, said today. Mr. Smith, the deputy United states trade representative, held informal talks with Japanese Agriculture Ministry officials on Thursday that failed to produce results.

headline: ARCO Lifts Profit by 68%
abstract: LEAD: ARCO's first-quarter profit rose 68 percent, mainly because of higher margins from chemical operations and its refining and marketing business, the company reported today.

headline: In French Town, Le Pen Hits a Nerve
abstract: LEAD: Last Sunday, municipal officials and war veterans in this Communist-governed town west of Paris went to the monument to the dead to remember those deported to Nazi extermination camps. As the wreaths were being placed, angry and frightened citizens voted in large numbers for Jean-Marie Le Pen, a presidential aspirant who has dismissed the camps as a ''minor detail'' in the history of World War

headline: Henley Group Lifts Stake in Santa Fe
abstract: LEAD: The Henley Group Inc. reported that it had raised its stake in the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation to 16.7 percent, from 15.7 percent, through open market purchases of $24.85 million in additional shares.

headline: Angolans and South Africans In Congo for Talks on Peace
abstract: LEAD: Senior Angolan and South African officials arrived here tonight for direct talks to explore a regional settlement to the conflict in Angola and the dispute over neighboring South-West Africa.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: 7 ALLIED NATIONS TO AVOID DISCORD AT SUMMIT TALKS
abstract: LEAD: Wary of rattling the financial markets or upsetting the economy during the American election campaign, officials of the leading industrial democracies say they plan to focus on several noncontentious issues at their annual economic summit conference.

headline: Word of an Ill Khomeini Stirs U.S. Policy Debate
abstract: LEAD: A recent Central Intelligence Agency report that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini is suffering from liver cancer has rekindled a debate within the Reagan Administration over whether the Iranian leader has long to live and over what effect his death would have on the future of the Islamic republic.

headline: Scott Paper Chooses Bloom and Weightman
abstract: LEAD: The Scott Paper Company has chosen two agencies from the three finalists that were in the running for its business: the Bloom Agency of New York and the Weightman Group of Philadelphia.

headline: Fox Executive Given New Post of President
abstract: LEAD: Jonathan L. Dolgen, executive vice president at Fox Inc., has been named to the new post of president. He will report directly to the chairman, Barry Diller.

headline: Poland Rejects Notion of Another 'Marshall Plan'
abstract: LEAD: Poland's Communist leadership has rejected plans being discussed in the West under which it said Poland was being asked to make deep changes in its political system in exchange for a large infusion of financial aid.

headline: PENTAGON INQUIRY HEARS OF PAYOFFS FROM CONTRACTORS
abstract: LEAD: A major Federal investigation of bribery at the Pentagon centers on allegations that Defense Department procurement officials accepted payoffs from military contractors and their consultants in exchange for confidential information on Government contracts, law-enforcement officials said today.

headline: Pepperell Under Pressure To Raise Bid for Stevens
abstract: LEAD: West Point-Pepperell needs to raise its bid significantly for J. P. Stevens & Company if it wants to thwart a competing $64-a-share offer from Odyssey Partners that expires today at midnight, professional traders said yesterday.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * The Drackett Company to the UniWorld Group for advertising its Nutrament drink to the black and Hispanic markets.

headline: Polish March Lauds Heroes Of '43 Ghetto
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of Poles defied a Government ban today and marched amid opposition banners through the wartime Warsaw ghetto area to commemorate the 1943 uprising there.

headline: INVESTING; Fund Managers Ride High - at Last
abstract: LEAD: AFTER many embarrassing years of lagging the broad market indexes, the average mutual fund manager has beaten them for the second quarter in a row. In the latest quarter, ended March 31, the primary reason was the improved performance of the stocks of the smaller-capitalized companies, analysts said.

headline: Advertising; WPP Acquires Henley, British Marketing Firm
abstract: LEAD: Undaunted by the commotion in the Colonies, Britain's WPP Group has bought the Henley Center, a London specialist in strategic marketing analysis. The purchase price could be as much as $34.9 million, depending on earnings until August 1992.

headline: Major Shake-Up in Pakistan
abstract: LEAD: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq dissolved the National Assembly today, dismissed his Prime Minister and accused the lawmakers of failing to maintain law and order in Pakistan.

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''It's the kind of day when anything you bought went up. Just don't overstay your welcome.'' - Norman J. Shapiro, manager of equity trading at New Japan Securities on the market's 74.68 gain.

headline: Moscow Summit: Unmaking History and Debating Rights; REAGAN PRESSES GORBACHEV ON CHURCH AND CIVIL RIGHTS; 'SERMONIZING' ANNOYS HOSTS'
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev publicly clashed over human rights issues today as the President, quoting Alexander Solzhenitsyn, appealed for increased civil and religious liberties in the Soviet Union.

headline: Amdahl Offering A New Computer
abstract: LEAD: The Amdahl Corporation next week will announce its most powerful mainframe computer ever, surpassing all other machines compatible with the mainframe computers of the International Business Machines Corporation, analysts say. Amdahl would not comment about the announcement, which it has scheduled for Tuesday.

headline: NICARAGUA DETAINS OPPOSITION CHIEFS
abstract: LEAD: About two dozen opposition leaders were detained today as they sought to visit a union hall where construction workers are conducting a hunger strike.

headline: Talks on Beef Might Resume
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Japan will probably resume negotiations on beef and citrus trade next week in Tokyo, United States trade officials said today.

headline: Japan to Lead Plane Project
abstract: LEAD: Japanese military contractors will take the lead in a joint United States-Japan project to design an advanced jet fighter based on the General Dynamics Corporation's F-16, a spokesman for Japan's Defense Agency said today.

headline: Ford Chairman Backs Tax Idea
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Ford Motor Company on Monday endorsed the idea of a national value-added sales tax as a method of reducing the United States trade deficit and the Federal budget deficit.

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nations's 420 money market mutual funds decreased to $1.43 billion, to $276.80 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 112 institutional funds were down $2.57 billion, to $75.76 billion. Assets of the 210 general purpose funds were up $781.7 million, to $83.64 billion.

headline: An Irving 'Poison Pill' Eliminated
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of New York Company said last night that it had reached an agreement with more than two-thirds of the Irving Bank Corporation's 15 preferred shareholders to waive a ''poison pill'' provision that would prevent the takeover of Irving.

headline: Affair of State Is Captivating Venezuelans
abstract: LEAD: With Venezuelans as transfixed as they might be by a steamy television soap opera, a long-running drama of passion, politics and power set in the Presidential Palace of Miraflores here is at last building towards its denouement.

headline: Ford's New Hiring Is First Since 70's
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it was hiring new hourly workers at several United States plants for the first time in a decade. A spokesman, Tom Foote, said Ford had a ''smattering of new hires'' at plants in Plymouth, Wixom and Milan, Mich., and in St. Paul. He said the auto maker was running out of laid-off workers who have first rights to any jobs that become available.

headline: Hungarians March to Protest Rumanian Plan
abstract: LEAD: Tens of thousands of Hungarians marched to the Rumanian Embassy on Monday to protest plans by President Nicolae Ceausescu to destroy more than half of the villages in Rumania, many populated by ethnic Hungarians.

headline: Greenspan Sees Merit In Program Trading
abstract: LEAD: In Congressional testimony yesterday, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, strongly endorsed program trading and stock-index arbitrage, two of the most controversial stock trading strategies.

headline: Soviet Offer on Arms Spurned
abstract: LEAD: The United States today rebuffed a Soviet proposal for an exchange of data on conventional forces in Europe, calling it a ''fruitless'' exercise that would perpetuate a 13-year stalemate.

headline: Papal Remains Are Stolen
abstract: LEAD: Thieves have stolen the remains of a 13th-century Pope, Celestine V, from a church where they were kept in a glass-lidded coffin, the police said today. Nobody has taken responsibility for the robbery, discovered by a nun who spotted the glass lid propped against a wall at the Basilica of Our Lady of Collemaggio in the town of L'Aquila, east of Rome.

headline: Sale at Tenneco Brings Several Bids
abstract: LEAD: Tenneco Inc., the nation's 10th-largest oil company, said it had received several offers for its oil and gas operations since putting them up for sale last month. Analysts said the units could bring between $5 billion and $7 billion. A Tenneco spokesman declined to identify the bidders, except to say that an offer had been received from Gulf Financial Resources Inc., a Houston investment firm financed by

headline: Salvador Ruling Party Picks Candidate for '89
abstract: LEAD: The governing Christian Democratic Party has chosen a wealthy businessman, Julio Adolfo Rey Prendes, as its candidate in next year's presidential elections.

headline: AFGHANS IN EXILE LOSING INFLUENCE TO REBELS IN FIELD
abstract: LEAD: As the Afghan insurgents stand on the brink of a military victory against the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul, political power is shifting from the seven rival guerrilla parties based here to the commanders operating inside Afghanistan.

headline: Bondholders Sue Brands and E-II
abstract: LEAD: A group of institutional bondholders sued American Brands Inc. and E-II Holdings Inc. in Federal District Court yesterday charging that American Brands fraudulently told bondholders in January that it planned to operate E-II as a subsidiary. The holders are asking for an undetermined amount of damages.

headline: Gandhi Faults Islamic Rule for Kabul
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India has declared that if the Moslem guerrillas took power in Afghanistan they would fuel a resurgence of Islamic fundamentalism that would destabilize the region.

headline: Pleasing the Teen-Ager Who Buys the T-shirt
abstract: LEAD: YOU can't judge a company by its trademark, but customers do anyway - and for that reason, among others, companies spend millions of dollars each year making sure their trademarks convey the intended message. From commercial characters as lively as Cap'n Crunch to dignified corporate logos, trademarks shape the identity of a company and its brands.

headline: Perils of Polling In Soviet Union
abstract: LEAD: The Institute for Sociological Research, a branch of the Soviet Academy of Sciences, has been conducting polls since 1969. But it is unaccustomed to asking sensitive questions.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Campbell Soup Co., Camden, N.J., said it had sold its Pietro's chain of 65 pizzerias in the Northwest to a company formed by Dimeling, Schriber & Daglish of Philadelphia. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Progress Seen in Nicaragua Talks
abstract: LEAD: Sandinista and contra leaders said today that their peace talks were making progress.

headline: Irish and British End An Extradition Dispute
abstract: LEAD: After a five-month disagreement over procedures, Ireland has agreed to resume extraditing people suspected of terrorist acts to Britain, the British Attorney General's office said Friday.

headline: India's Advertising Industry Surges
abstract: LEAD: A once-flagging advertising industry is booming in India. It has become fiercely competitive and one of the country's fastest-growing economic sectors.

headline: Market Place; Profit Surprise Gives ARCO Lift
abstract: LEAD: THERE is nothing like a pleasant earnings surprise - for example, management telling analysts that profits will be better than expected - to help the price of a stock in an uncertain market.

headline: Desert Partners
abstract: LEAD: Desert Partners L.P. disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it needs the approval of Merrill Lynch & Company and Elders Investment Ltd. of Australia before it can sweeten its $42-a-share hostile tender offer for the USG Corporation. Desert Partners' latest offer, valued at $2.2 billion, has been rejected by the USG board as inadequate.

headline: Advertising; Children's ad Position Filled
abstract: LEAD: Helen Boehm, a former City University of New York faculty member, is joining the Council of Better Business Bureaus as head of the Children's Advertising Unit. It is part of the National Advertising Division, the investigative arm of the ad industry's self-policing operation.

headline: China Grain Rise Seen
abstract: LEAD: China's grain production may increase by as much as 25 percent, to around 500 million metric tons, by the year 2000 from an average of 394 million tons in the 1980's, an Agriculture Department report said Monday. ''Area sown to grain probably will decrease over the next 12 years, but improved yields could boost total output,'' the report said.

headline: U.S.-Japan Venture Seen
abstract: LEAD: Japan and the United States are near an agreement on a project to double Japanese imports of American goods in three years, an official at the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The campaign, known as

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 421 money market mutual funds decreased $850.6 million, to $273.93 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 114 institutional funds decreased $2.10 billion, to $73.14 billion. Assets of the 210 general-purpose funds were up $1.01 billion, to $83.24 billion.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: Nancy Beck, Cynthia Perry, Maureen Sage and Angelika Thiel have been promoted to senior vice presidents, management directors, at FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Kirshenbaum Account
abstract: LEAD: National Consumer Information Services, a recently formed data base company, has selected the 11-month-old Kirshenbaum & Bond of New York to handle its $2.5 million advertising account. It is the agency's biggest single assignment. The client, based in San Francisco, plans to provide consumers with product information.

headline: SAINTHOOD FOR 117 OUTRAGES VIETNAM
abstract: LEAD: The canonization in June of 117 Vietnamese and foreign Roman Catholic martyrs persecuted by 17th- and 18th-century Vietnamese rulers, has provoked angry protests from Hanoi, worsening already unstable relations between the Vatican and Vietnam.

headline: Dow Off 22.05; Most of Loss in Final Hour
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices sagged yesterday, with most of the losses coming in the last 40 minutes of trading, as blue-chip issues were hit by program trading related to index arbitrage.

headline: Talking Deals; Developer Plays A Waiting Game
abstract: LEAD: LARRY SILVERSTEIN, the New York City real estate investor whose 7 World Trade Center skyscraper in lower Manhattan remains 86 percent empty, seems almost unwilling to rent out his building - except on his terms.

headline: Japanese Suspect in Investigation Into Jersey Bombs Is Denied Bail
abstract: LEAD: A Japanese man arrested with three powerful homemade bombs on the New Jersey Turnpike was ordered held without bail today as the authorities continued investigating possible links between the suspect and a left-wing terrorist group.

headline: Westinghouse Cuts
abstract: LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it would cut 380 jobs from its energy systems business, which now employs about 7,000 people, because of tougher worldwide competition. All but 100 of the jobs to be cut are in the Pittsburgh area, where 4,000 of the 7,000 energy jobs are located.

abstract: LEAD: Three United States Air Force F-16 jet fighters crashed over West Germany today, bringing the number of crashes to five in three months and insuring a new outcry from West Germans against low-level training flights over their land.

abstract: LEAD: * Aer Lingus announced that its chief executive, David Kennedy, would take early retirement at the end of the year to pursue interests in the private sector.

headline: Bonn Trade Surplus Cut
abstract: LEAD: West Germany announced today that its current account and trade data for March were better than expected.

headline: Texas Picks Up the Pieces
abstract: LEAD: TEXANS are proud of the way they stand apart from other Americans. But something new is happening and Texans are embracing it with a fervor generally reserved for barbeque and cowboy boots: In the shadow of this decade's spectacular boom-and-bust cycles in oil and real estate, the state's economy is beginning to look like the rest of the nation's.

abstract: LEAD: * Norman Black has been appointed executive vice president of Ally Gargano/MCA Advertising, a unit of Marketing Corporation of America.

abstract: LEAD: The Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti lost the showdown today in his battle for Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest company.

headline: Programs' Role In Jan. 8 Selloff
abstract: LEAD: Computerized program trading played a key role in the 140.58-point decline of the Dow Jones industrial average on Jan. 8, the Securities and Exchange Commission has reported to Congress.

abstract: LEAD: John Nittoli, former publisher of the defunct RX Being Well magazine, is now president of Healthteam Communications in New York, which publishes two magazines - Heart Beat and Doctors' Orders.

headline: Don't Write Off Junk Bonds
abstract: LEAD: ''JUNK BONDS'' - is there an empirical basis for the nasty-name-calling about the high-yield financing that raised more than $150 billion for growth companies over the past decade? Can investment-grade companies that issue ''non-junk bonds'' still be considered ''quality'' if they lay off workers and lose markets to foreign competitors?

headline: Economic Scene; Soft Case Against Index Arbitrage
abstract: LEAD: IF the big players are unhappy with the New York Stock Exchange's new restrictions on index arbitrage, they aren't advertising it. There was hardly a peep of protest on April 6 when the so-called collar slipped into place for the first time, temporarily denying the arbitragers use of the exchange's high-speed computers.

headline: Fighting Narcotics: U.S. Is Urged to Shift Tactics
abstract: LEAD: No President has spoken out more against drugs than President Reagan. No Administration has signed more anti-drug treaties or spent more money to stem the flow of drugs into this country.

headline: Pritzkers Transfer Stake in Ramada
abstract: LEAD: Members of the Pritzker family of Chicago have transferred their 7.2 percent stake in Ramada Inc. to the HCC Corporation, a holding company under their control that has been licensed by gambling regulators in Nevada and New Jersey. The Phoenix-based Ramada has been the subject of takeover rumors, and the Pritzkers, who also control the Hyatt Corporation and Braniff Inc., have said that they were discussing a possible acquisition of

headline: Montedison In Joint Venture
abstract: LEAD: Montedison S.p.A., the chemicals group based in Milan, and Ente Nazionale Idrocarburi, the Italian state energy company agreed today to a major joint venture in a bid to compete in international markets.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Advest Group Inc., Hartford, a diversified financial services company, said it had agreed in principle to acquire Lyons, Zomback & Ostrowski Inc., a financial consulting and corporate finance firm. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Boeing's Net Rises 15.3%
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company today reported higher earnings in the first quarter despite lower sales. The company attributed the improved profits primarily to lower research and development costs in its core businesses of commercial aircraft, aerospace and computing. These factors were partly offset by increased costs in its de

headline: Military Chip Contract Awards
abstract: LEAD: The Pentagon selected four contractor teams today to develop a new type of high-speed, gallium arsenide computer chip.

headline: Turk Visits Greece in Effort to End Years of Hostility
abstract: LEAD: The Prime Ministers of Greece and Turkey began a three-day meeting today at this seaside resort, seeking to overcome decades of hostility and resentment that have sometimes brought their nations to the brink of war.

headline: Israeli Patrols Keep West Bank Quiet
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army had predicted major demonstrations in this Arab city and other spots around the occupied territories today, the last Friday of the monthlong Moslem holiday of Ramadan.

headline: Uniroyal Goodrich Sets 2-Part Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Uniroyal Goodrich Tire Company is offering $415 million of debt securities in two parts through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

headline: Status of Major Insider Investigations
abstract: LEAD: While Wall Street digests the lastest insider trading scandal, it is also waiting to hear the outcome of several other major insider cases or investigations. These include the sentencing of an investment banker, Martin A. Siegel, and a trading executive, Boyd L. Jefferies. Both are believed to be cooperating in providing information to the Government in exchange for lighter sentences.

headline: Bid for Irving Is Withdrawn
abstract: LEAD: As expected, the Bank of New York withdrew its offer for the Irving Bank Corporation after Irving declined to accept it yesterday.

headline: Dover Journal; Will the Port Boom Again? Just You Wait and See
abstract: LEAD: For 14 weeks, this port town with its white cliffs has been the center of a strike by British seamen who work on English Channel ferries. It is the bitterest industrial conflict in Britain since Rupert Murdoch crushed Fleet Street's print unions in early 1986.

headline: GLOBAL BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * China will soon allow foreign banks to open branches in large coastal cities, Li Guixian, the governor of the People's Bank of China, said. Currently, foreign banks can open new branches only in special economic zones in south China. The New China news agency quoted Mr. Li as telling a meeting of bankers that China should reform its foreign exchange system, letting coastal cities borrow more short-term foreign exchange, allowing a limited number of individuals to deal in foreign exchange and allowing companies to open foreign exchange accounts.

headline: Nynex Profit Increases 4%
abstract: LEAD: The Nynex Corporation, one of the ''Baby Bells'' born of the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company several years ago, yesterday reported first-quarter net of $311.1 million, or $1.55 a share, up 4 percent from $299.2 million, or $1.47 a share, in the corresponding period a year ago.

headline: Taking Dark Eyes and Making Them Green or Blue
abstract: LEAD: STARTING from zero five years ago, sales of colored contact lenses grew to $45 million last year. These include both tinted lenses, which can change the color only of light eyes, and Wesley-Jessen's opaque lenses, which use dots of color on a clear lens to make even brown eyes green or blue. They are thought to have buoyed sales of all types of lenses and accounted for about half of the industry's growth in recent years.

abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of United Nations Resolution 242, which was approved by the Security Council on Nov. 22, 1967:

headline: Arbitrage Move Reassessed
abstract: LEAD: Bear, Stearns & Company announced yesterday that it was re-examining its suspension of stock-index arbitrage trading. The firm suspended such program trading both for its own accounts and for its customers last week.

headline: Crazy Eddie Loss
abstract: LEAD: Crazy Eddie Inc., now under the control of a new board backed by Entertainment Marketing Inc., said it expects to report additional, significant losses for the fourth quarter ended Feb. 28. The company said the latest losses were caused by insufficient sales, a soft consumer electronics market, adjustments arising from the new management's completion of its evaluation of the company and certain business practices and policies of prior management.

headline: Tony O'Reilly Astride Two Worlds; At Heinz, a Bottom-Line Leader
abstract: LEAD: BY textbook definition, the H. J. Heinz Company should be a pretty tense place. Its managers are constantly asked to squeeze yet another penny out of costs. Subsidiary presidents must vie at planning meetings for capital resources. Annual earnings and growth goals are ambitious, yet a good portion of each executive's compensation depends on meeting them.

headline: USG Suitor Alters Terms Of Its Bid
abstract: LEAD: In the latest round in its battle to gain control of the USG Corporation, Desert Partners L.P. said yesterday that it would pay $45 a share in cash for 39 million outstanding shares if a friendly deal could be worked out.

headline: Retail Sales Declined 0.6% in April
abstract: LEAD: Retail sales fell six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the first setback in six months, but economists said they were not particularly concerned because the March figure was revised upward significantly.

headline: Bear Stearns Revamps Its Top Management
abstract: LEAD: The Bear Stearns Companies announced yesterday that it had dismantled its system of co-presidents and named one of them, James E. Cayne, to be president. The other, E. John Rosenwald Jr., was elected vice chairman. Alan C. Greenberg remains chairman and chief executive.

headline: Inquiry Latest Blow to McDonnell
abstract: LEAD: Even before the Federal investigation of possible fraud and bribery in military procurement reached the doorstep of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation last week, John F. McDonnell, the company's new chairman and chief executive, had plenty to worry about.

headline: Panel of Pension Managers To Hold Talks at Big Board
abstract: LEAD: A new committee comprising the executives of some of the nation's largest corporate and state pension funds will meet today at the New York Stock Exchange, with discussions likely to center on the capital requirements of specialists, trading liquidity, coordination of margin and clearing between the stock and futures markets in

headline: Bahrain Ruler Backs U.S. Gulf Raids
abstract: LEAD: Seated in a cavernous meeting hall in his palace, the diminutive, white-robed ruler of Bahrain expressed no qualms about the display this week of American firepower in the Persian Gulf.

headline: Israel Weighs Appeal by U.S. Arab
abstract: LEAD: A Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolence had his day in court today and vowed that if the Israeli Government succeeded in deporting him, he would convert to Judaism and move back to Israel under the Law of Return.

headline: The Media Business: Advertising; Beber Silverstein Wins Sogrape Account
abstract: LEAD: The New York office of Miami-based Beber Silverstein & Partners has become agency for Sogrape USA, a marketer of imported wines, whose best-known brand is Mateus Wines of Portugal. The account, billing about $3 million, was formerly at Rubin Reid Noto & Ehrenthal.

headline: Chemical Fire Pollutes Loire
abstract: LEAD: The Government cut off drinking water to 200,000 people after cancer-causing pollutants from a chemical fire flowed into the Loire River, the authorities said today. An explosion and fire Wednesday night at the Protex factory in Auzouer-en-Touraine, 15 miles northeast of Tours, injured one person and sent phenol and metallic pollutants into the Brenne, a tributary of the Loire.

headline: MDI Says Holders Block Takeover
abstract: LEAD: MDI Mobile Data International Inc. accused its two largest shareholders of collaborating to thwart a takeover attempt by Motorola Inc.'s Canadian unit. MDI Mobile's president, Barclay Isherwood, said that Glenayre Electronics Ltd. of Vancouver, British Columbia, and Lincluden Management Ltd. of Oakville, Ontario, had a ''hidden agenda'' aimed at controlling M

headline: Soybeans and Grains Climb On a New Surge of Buying
abstract: LEAD: A new surge of buying hit the soybean and grain futures pits at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, lifting all the expiring spot May soybeans and soybean products to contract highs. The expiring wheat and corn contracts also posted sharp gains.

headline: Indonesia's Debt to Rise
abstract: LEAD: Indonesia's total external debt is projected to hit $50 billion this year, with debt repayments by Southeast Asia's largest nation forecast to rise sharply, the World Bank said today. But it said that a Government program to wean the economy away from dependence on oil was working, with non-oil exports expected to increase rapidly, and that the debt picture was not as serious as in many other heavily indebted nations.

headline: Economic Scene; User-Friendly Technical Fixes
abstract: LEAD: WITH prices stable, the trade deficit improving and the Reagan boom perking into its sixth year, the performance of the American economy is confounding the doomsayers. Well, not quite all the doomsayers. Productivity growth, the most important measure of the economy's ability to sustain prosperity in the long run, has been drifting south for two decades.

headline: Drexel Burnham to Move To New Headquarters in '93
abstract: LEAD: A year and a half after it abandoned plans to move into 7 World Trade Center, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that in 1993 it would move to a new world headquarters building to be built on West Street, just north of the Vista International Hotel in lower Manhattan.

headline: Giving Amax New Life Is 'a Ball' for President
abstract: LEAD: ''I've had a ball,'' said Allen Born yesterday, describing his three years as president and chief executive of Amax Inc., the large metals company based in Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Diplomatic Handyman: Diego Cordovez
abstract: LEAD: A talent for waiting and a sense of humor have helped bring Diego Cordovez success in his six-year search for an Afghan settlement.

headline: Stocks Slip In Slow Day; Dow Drops 6.63
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices slipped in desultory trading yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average posted its first loss in six sessions.

headline: Koppers May Sell Parts of 2 Units
abstract: LEAD: The Koppers Company said it had been negotiating with third parties to sell portions of its chemical and construction materials divisions but that no one had emerged who was interested in buying the entire company, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Pittsburgh-based concern is exploring its options in light of the $1.69 billion hostile tender offer from Beazer P.L.C.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: Debt

headline: Dexter Names A President
abstract: LEAD: The Dexter Corporation, one of the oldest American companies, yesterday named K. Grahame Walker president and chief operating officer. Mr. Walker, 50 years old, succeeds

headline: Deposed Panamanian Favors Outside Force
abstract: LEAD: The deposed President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, said in an interview broadcast today that one solution to the crisis here would be for ''a multinational force'' to invade the country and oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

headline: Dublin Journal; Calling London Urgently! (for Abortion Advice)
abstract: LEAD: Irishwomen lately are finding a critical telephone number scribbled on the walls of public restrooms, as if the need for abortion counseling were to be considered a scrofulous underworld indulgence.

headline: Corning Net Off 17.4%
abstract: LEAD: Corning Glass Works said today that its profit had fallen 17.4 percent in the first quarter from a year ago, when it had a one-time gain stemming from an accounting change. For the quarter ended March 27, Corning reported a profit of $37.1 million, or 83 cents a share, compared with $44.9 million, or 97 cents a share, a year ago, when it had a $14.2 million accounting gain.

headline: Hungary Hardens Its Line Against Internal Critics
abstract: LEAD: The Hungarian leadership is taking a tougher stand against people who criticize the Communist Government, in an action that appears designed to reaffirm central control over discussion of economic and political change.

headline: An Expectant Air Hits Muscovites, Who Also Face Struggles at Home
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan arrives in Moscow on Sunday to find a city dressed up in new foliage and fresh whitewash, a people curious and expectant but distracted by the political struggles going on in their country.

headline: Pretoria Suggests a Black Electoral Role
abstract: LEAD: President P. W. Botha today raised the possibility of constitutional changes that could pave the way for black participation in the national Government and in the election of the President.

headline: S.E.C. Cites Endotronics
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has accused Endotronics Inc. of reporting millions of dollars of phony sales between 1985 and 1987 in violation of security laws. In charges filed Tuesday in

headline: I.B.M.'s New 10-Year Notes Are Priced to Yield 9.194%
abstract: LEAD: In its first long-term debt offering in more than two years, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday priced $500 million worth of 9 percent 10-year notes through a syndicate led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

headline: American May Buy 100 Boeing 757 Planes
abstract: LEAD: American Airlines is considering buying about 100 Boeing 757 airplanes, an order that could be valued at more than $4 billion to the Boeing Company.

headline: Azerbaijani City Shut By Armenian Strikers
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of Armenians in the Azerbaijan republic stayed away from work today in a general strike that shut factories and mass transportation in a city at the center of an ethnic dispute, a resident of the area said.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., and Union Carbide Corp., Danbury, Conn., tentatively agreed to form a joint venture that would supply technology, products, engineered systems and services to the oil and gas industries.

headline: Former Hutton Manager Loses Suit Against Bell
abstract: LEAD: A Federal jury yesterday rejected a suit by a former E.F. Hutton branch manager who had contended that Griffin B. Bell, the former Attorney General, defamed him in a report on an illegal check-kiting scheme in which Hutton engaged.

headline: Dr Pepper/7-Up Stake to Be Sold
abstract: LEAD: Hicks & Haas, the leveraged buyout specialists active in the soft-drink industry, announced today that it had agreed to sell a 49 percent share in what will become the Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies to the merchant-banking arm of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. for $600 million. An agreement in principle to merge the Dr Pepper Company and the Seven-Up

headline: Job Cuts at G.M.'s Opel
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's West German unit, Adam Opel A.G., said Tuesday that it plans to cut 5,200 jobs by 1991 as part of a cost-saving program. The move comes as all of G.M.'s European operations are under pressure to reduce expenses and bolster the auto maker's profitability on the Continent.

headline: First City Offer Extended
abstract: LEAD: Failng again to win approval of investors holding at least 70 percent of bonds of the First City Bancorporation of Texas, an investor group headed by A. Robert Abboud confirmed today that it had extended its exisitng offer for all outstanding public debt until 5 P.M. next Tuesday.

headline: Rhodes Agrees To Be Acquired
abstract: LEAD: Rhodes Inc., a furniture retailer with 90 stores in the Southeast, said today that it had agreed to be acquired by Green Capital Investors for $242.4 million.

headline: Saatchi Expansion
abstract: LEAD: The British-based Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the world's largest advertising agency, said it had agreed to aquire the Los Angeles-based Corporate Planners and Coordinators Inc., an estate consulting concern. The purchase was the latest in a series of acquisitions by Saatchi in a drive to diversify beyond advertising and build up a global presence.

headline: First Interstate Standby Credit
abstract: LEAD: First Interstate Bancorp announced today that it had established a $500 million standby credit facility with a syndicate of 17 major international banks.

headline: Volvo Denies Any Interest in Pillsbury
abstract: LEAD: The food division of Sweden's diversified car maker A.B. Volvo is not negotiating to buy the Pillsbury Company, a spokesman said. ''We have not been talking to Pillsbury, and we are not talking to Pillsbury,'' said Bjorn Allguren, public relations director at Volvo's Provendor A.B.

headline: Decades Later, Soviet Journal Prints a Rebuttal by Einstein
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet journal has published a response by Albert Einstein to an attack on him that the journal printed in 1947.

headline: Varig Survives in Difficult Region
abstract: LEAD: Given the troubles of airlines across Latin America, Helio Smidt seems remarkably confident that Varig will emerge unscathed from the inflation, recession and labor unrest buffeting the region.

headline: Airliner Sales To East Seen
abstract: LEAD: European and United States aircraft groups are likely to get the go-ahead within the next few weeks for substantial sales of their high-technology airliners to East bloc countries, diplomatic sources said today.

headline: Hackers Raid U.S. Lab File
abstract: LEAD: Unknown computer raiders searched a file at the Government's Jet Propulsion Laboratory last month, but did not learn any secrets, a laboratory manager said this week.

headline: Text of the Soviet-Afghan Statement on Accord
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of a joint statement issued yesterday after a meeting between Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and Najibullah, the Afghan leader, in the Soviet Central Asian city of Tashkent, as released in translation by the Tass press agency:

headline: A Chill Over the Hot New 'Hybrids'
abstract: LEAD: LAST year, executives at the Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco began looking for new ways to attract deposits. One proposal caught their attention: Given the bank's involvement in the California Gold Rush, why not offer a certificate of deposit with an interest rate pegged to the price of gold?

headline: Honduras Says Sandinistas Destroyed a Village, Killing 2
abstract: LEAD: Nicaraguan troops destroyed a village in a remote part of eastern Honduras, killing two Hondurans and wounding 17 in a ''perverse and cowardly'' incursion on April 13, the Honduran military said today.

headline: Case and Gandalf
abstract: LEAD: The data communications company Case Group P.L.C. repeated its rejection of a hostile takeover bid of $:58 million ($105.6 million United States) from Canada's Gandalf Technologies. Case said Gandalf's formal document relating to the offer, issued Tuesday, did nothing to change its initial view. Case said the offer significantly undervalued the company and the future of its business.

headline: 3 British Servicemen Are Killed In I.R.A. Attacks in Netherlands
abstract: LEAD: Three British servicemen were killed and three wounded in a bombing and a shooting in the Netherlands today, and the Irish Republican Army said it had carried out the two attacks.

headline: Panel Limits Role of States In Electric Sales to Utilities
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission voted yesterday to revoke the authority of New York State, and presumably all other states, to require utilities to buy electricity from small producers at prices above the prevailing wholesale cost or the utilities' own generating cost.

headline: CONSUMER RATES
abstract: LEAD: In percent          Tax-Exempt Bonds   7.87        Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index               Money Market Funds   6.28        Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield               Bank Money Market Accounts   5.68        Bank Rate Monitor               Home Mortgage   10.34        Federal Home Loan Bank, national average               Unsecured Personal Loans        Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity        Chase Manhattan, New York   13.90        Continental Illinois, Chicago   14.00        Bank of America, San Francisco   17.25

headline: Cocoa Prices Weaken
abstract: LEAD: Cocoa prices reacted to prospects of a world surplus by falling today to their lowest levels in nearly six years. Cocoa beans for May delivery fell by $30, to $1,692 a metric ton. Gill & Duffus, international merchants, today forecast 1987-88 world production of 2.1 million tons, up 6 percent from 1986-87, with record crops expected in the Ivory Coast, Brazil and Malaysia.

headline: Canadian Pacific Sells Certificates
abstract: LEAD: Canadian Pacific Ltd. offered $100 million of 10-year equipment trust certificates yesterday. The 9.45 percent notes, which mature on May 1, 1998, are noncallable for seven years. They were priced at 99 7/8 to yield 9.47 percent, or 60 basis points over the current yield on Treasury securities of similar maturity.

headline: Guerrillas Say Support for Cambodia Government Is Eroding
abstract: LEAD: Support for the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia is eroding steadily among both civilians and Government troops, guerrillas operating from bases on the Thai border say.

headline: Making Europe a Mighty Market
abstract: LEAD: THE battle between Europe and ''non-Europe'' is coming to a head. With less than five years to go before a self-imposed deadline, the European Community is racing to remove the hundreds of trade barriers that bedevil its 12 member countries.

headline: CBS-TV Sets Restructuring
abstract: LEAD: The CBS Broadcast Group yesterday announced a restructuring of its television network, with the creation of two new units, one for marketing and one for affiliate relations.

headline: China's Private Sector
abstract: LEAD: China said Friday that it had more than 225,000 private companies and that they were increasingly important to economic growth. The Worker's Daily said these companies employed more than 3.6 million workers and accounted for 1 percent of the nation's industrial production. China's Communist leaders began a series of economic changes in 1978, encouraging growth in the private sector.

headline: Gardening Surging As Ex-City Dwellers Find Joy in the Dirt
abstract: LEAD: There was a time when a spring Sunday morning would find Thomas Dawson, a 37-year-old lawyer, having brunch in Manhattan. But that was before he and his family abandoned city life for the suburbs. Now he spends those mornings pricing new shrubs, spreading fertilizer or weeding the garden of his Westport, Conn., home.

headline: British Board Presses Effort To Find Nazis
abstract: LEAD: Government investigators have been sifting through more than 50 letters that have arrived in response to an unusual advertisement headlined ''War Criminals, Evidence Wanted,'' which appeared in British newspapers last weekend.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  Economic and Social Council

headline: Pinochet Looking to Extend Tenure
abstract: LEAD: Facing a strong electoral challenge to his 15-year presidency, Gen. Augusto Pinochet is said by supporters to have begun searching for a strategy to assure that he remains in power after a coming plebiscite.

headline: Congress Plans Sanctions to Force Change in Haiti
abstract: LEAD: Six months after a massacre halted presidential elections in Haiti, United States officials and lawmakers say that there has been no progress toward democracy in the impoverished Caribbean country and that Congress will take new steps to force change.

headline: Puzzle for Salvador Rebels: Turning War to Power
abstract: LEAD: Salvadoran Marxist guerrilla commanders are involved in a major re-evaluation of strategy at what appears to be a key moment in their eight-year war against the Government, according to rebel officials and diplomats who monitor the guerrillas.

headline: Poland Is Said to Free Some Leaders in Strike
abstract: LEAD: Communist authorities today released Janusz Onyszkiewicz, a spokesman for the outlawed Solidarity union, and 11 strike leaders jailed in connection with Poland's recent wave of unrest, opposition representatives said.

headline: Company Items On Cable TV
abstract: LEAD: Investors News Release Watch, a new service that will offer corporate news briefs four times a day on cable television, was announced yesterday by PR Newswire and the Financial News Network, which will provide the service.

headline: TLC Group Studies Beatrice Units' Sale
abstract: LEAD: The TLC Group, a New York investment company controlled by the financier Reginald F. Lewis, said that it was exploring the sale of three European operations of the Beatrice International Company. The group has retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to explore the sale of the Beatrice International Bottling Group, based in the Netherlands and Belgium, and two British operations - Beatrice Poultry and the Callard & Bowser

headline: Too Little Money, Too Many Disputes
abstract: LEAD: WHEN Robert McNamara was president of the World Bank, he claimed he had the best job in the world. No one is likely to make that claim for the presidency of the World Bank's regional counterpart, the Inter-American Development Bank - at least not now.

headline: Talking Business with Vasey of Merrill Lynch; New Creativity In Underwriting
abstract: LEAD: After the stock market collapse in October, financing flowing from Wall Street to American corporations began to dry up. Although the underwriting business had a sharp rebound in the first quarter of this year - jumping 58 percent from the previous quarter - the results still lagged behind the heady days before the market collapse.

headline: Redken's Founder Hopes To Take Company Private
abstract: LEAD: Paula Kent Meehan, an actress who once played a hatcheck girl on the ''77 Sunset Strip'' television series, founded Redken Laboratories Inc. out of frustration. Allergic to regular hair spray, she sought out products she could use.

headline: Rumania Trade Status
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan has signed an order withdrawing trade concessions from Rumania under the most-favored-nation program. The order that Mr. Reagan signed Tuesday was a formality since Rumania informed the State Department earlier this year that it would not seek a renewal of its special status, which expires this Sunday.

headline: Suspect in Murder of Drug Agent Is Seized in U.S. Trap in Honduras
abstract: LEAD: Springing a trap at dawn in Honduras, the United States today arranged the capture and arrest of a key suspect in the murder of an American drug agent in Mexico, law enforcement officials said tonight.

headline: U.S. Sees Progress on Verification Issues
abstract: LEAD: American and Soviet arms control experts have made some progress toward resolving their differences over verifying the new accord on medium-range nuclear missiles, American officials said today.

headline: Meese, in Colombia, Confers on Drugs
abstract: LEAD: Amid tight security, Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d met today with the President of Colombia to discuss a surge in narcotics-related terrorism here and American efforts to extradite Colombian suspects in cocaine-trafficking cases.

headline: Yields Rise Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Yields on money market mutual funds, certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were slightly higher in the week ended yesterday.

headline: Chief Financial Officer Is Named by Salomon
abstract: LEAD: Salomon Inc. named a chief financial officer yesterday and announced a stock repurchase program to help its share price.

headline: In Analyst Programs, Access to Inside Data
abstract: LEAD: Programs for financial analysts, like the one that Stephen Sui-Kuan Wang Jr., worked in at Morgan Stanley & Company, have flourished at major Wall Street investment houses since the heyday of the bull market.

headline: SEVERAL GARRISONS ARE SAID TO FALL TO AFGHAN REBELS
abstract: LEAD: Afghan Army garrisons along the Pakistani-Afghan border, weakened by Soviet troop withdrawals, are rapidly crumbling in the face of assaults by heavily armed guerrillas, Afghan rebel officials and Western diplomats say.

headline: Japan's Military Past Comes Back to Haunt Again
abstract: LEAD: The Foreign Ministry's chief spokesman said today that Japan's relations with its Asian neighbors had suffered ''quite severe'' damage as a result of repeated incidents in which senior officials played down Japanese wartime aggression.

headline: An Expensive Consolidation For Continental Airlines
abstract: LEAD: A year after it bought People Express and Frontier Airlines, Continental Airlines is still struggling to smooth out its operations and there have been times when it has been short of cash.

headline: 28.02 Rise Puts Dow At 2,090.19
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rose broadly in moderate trading yesterday, lifting the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest level since last October's market collapse.

headline: Soviet Survivor Relives 'Doctors' Plot'
abstract: LEAD: To wait was Yakov Rapoport's way, and his only weapon. His memory wound itself protectively around the days in early 1953 that took him from the top ranks of Soviet medicine to a prison cell and back. When he returned, he kept silent, he kept waiting, and he kept remembering.

headline: Ardshiel Chief's Path Took Many Turns
abstract: LEAD: Ardshiel Inc., a small New York-based investment banking firm, has maintained a low profile despite the colorful career of its chairman and president, Henry Brown Turner.

headline: Jacobs Considers Bid for Acme Steel
abstract: LEAD: An investment group led by the Minneapolis-based corporate raider Irwin L. Jacobs has purchased a 8.3 percent stake in the Acme Steel Company and said it is considering a bid for control of the steelmaker based in Riverdale, Ill.

headline: What They Ate At Spaso House
abstract: LEAD: Pietro Valot, the chef at Spaso House, the American Ambassador's residence, prepared the meal for the dinner there tonight. Here is the menu.  Lobster Bisque  Supreme of Chicken With Truffle Sauce  Cherry Tomatoes With Fleurons  Carrot Souffle  June Peas  Mixed Green Salad  Brie

headline: Dow Up 9.94 in Light Pre-Holiday Trading
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices ended moderately higher yesterday in light pre-holiday trading.

headline: Fairfax Executives Purchase Ms. and Sassy
abstract: LEAD: A group of executives of John Fairfax Ltd. said yesterday that it had exercised an option to buy Ms. and Sassy magazines from the publishing concern, the second largest in Australia.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Chrysler Corp., Detroit, will postpone the debut of its Italian-made Maserati TC sports car until July.

headline: Trade Bill's Chances Grow Without Plant-Closing Item
abstract: LEAD: Chances have improved for passage of a second, slimmed-down trade bill if the Senate, as expected, upholds President Reagan's veto of the original legislation, lawmakers and lobbyists said today. The Senate plans to vote Wednesday.

headline: Texaco Up Only to $50 Despite Bid
abstract: LEAD: Although Carl C. Icahn said on Wednesday that he was willing to pay $60 a share for all the Texaco stock he does not own, Texaco rose only $3.125 yesterday, to $50 a share. The relatively mild reaction reflected skepticism either that Texaco's board would respond favorably to Mr. Icahn's offer or that Mr.

headline: Bhopal Hearing Delayed
abstract: LEAD: District Court Judge M. W. Deo canceled today's hearing on the Bhopal gas disaster, the United News of India reported, but set an April 23 deadline for outlining a hearing schedule in the case. Lawyers for both the Union Carbide Corporation and India's Government said they had not yet received copies of a higher court's ruling on Judge Deo's order that Carbide pay interim relief to victims.

headline: John Paul, in Sermon, Takes Note of Unrest
abstract: LEAD: Commenting on the labor unrest in his homeland, Pope John Paul II said today that Poland would not be independent until its people were free to determine their future.

headline: Patents; Three Army Engineers Develop a Generator
abstract: LEAD: A manually operated electrical generation system, which has a stirrup and is nicknamed the Big Foot, has been patented for the Army. Patent 4,746,806 was awarded this week to three staff engineers at the Harry Diamond Laboratories maintained by the Army at Adelphi, Md.

headline: Panel to Study OPEC Issues
abstract: LEAD: OPEC's new secretary general, Subroto, will supervise a special team to study basic problems within the organization, the Indonesian energy minister, Ginanjar Kartasasmita, said today.

headline: RETURN OF EX-FINANCIAL CORP. CHEIF
abstract: LEAD: You can't keep Charles W. Knapp down.

headline: Hachette to Buy Magazine Publisher
abstract: LEAD: In its second big deal in American publishing this week, Hachette S.A. of France agreed yesterday to pay $712 million for Diamandis Communications Inc., owner of Woman's Day, Car and Driver, Popular Photography and other consumer publications. The acquisition of the New York-based company will make

headline: Macmillan Rejects Bid Of $1.9 Billion by Bass
abstract: LEAD: Macmillan Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected the investor Robert M. Bass's offer to acquire the company for $73 a share in cash, or $1.9 billion.

headline: American Express Earnings Fall 15.3% as Revenue Rises
abstract: LEAD: The American Express Company reported yesterday that its earnings dropped 15.3 percent in the first quarter while revenues rose 31 percent.

headline: Banking Law Voided in Texas
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge today struck down a Texas law that prevented banks from opening branches statewide.

headline: I.B.M. Gives Lord, Einstein Short-Term Assignments
abstract: LEAD: Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners has received advertising assignments from the International Business Machines Corporation, the largest client of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein.

headline: Making Trade Data More Precise
abstract: LEAD: In addition to the traditional work of foiling drug smugglers and collecting more than a half-billion dollars a year in import duties, A. Robert Beikirch has a new priority: helping to improve America's trade statistics.

headline: SOME INDIA TROOPS LEAVING SRI LANKA
abstract: LEAD: India began withdrawing a small contingent of its more than 50,000 troops from Sri Lanka today, declaring it was justified by recent gains in quelling the Tamil insurgency on the island.
