headline: A New Look at Trade
abstract: LEAD: FOR centuries, trade statistics have tracked the course of human history. Exports and imports have documented the rise and fall of civilizations. They marked the progress, for example, of mercantile Britain and Germany as well as the emergence of the United States and Japan as industrial giants.

headline: Seabrook Forecast
abstract: LEAD: The Public Service Company of New Hampshire will not flatly predict if its Seabrook nuclear power plant will ever operate, but its estimate for financial planning purposes has slipped again - to Jan. 1, 1990. That is 18 months later than Public Service's previous written planning assumption, although company officials told state regulators last year that the date had slipped at least to April 1989.

headline: Personal Income Up 0.3% in May
abstract: LEAD: Americans' personal income and spending grew modestly in May, but economists said consumer spending would likely weaken this summer as wages lagged behind inflation.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bathroom Journal Fails, But a New Idea Is Due
abstract: LEAD: The Bathroom Journal has gone down the tube. But the disaster has taught a valuable lesson to Michael Cohen, public relations man turned publisher.

headline: East Bloc Reacts to Summit: Much Praise, Some Criticism
abstract: LEAD: Moscow's closest Eastern European allies reacted today with unbridled enthusiasm to the results of the Moscow summit meeting, though there was some reserve toward the role played by President Reagan and an accusation that the West had exploited Eastern bloc opposition groups to foment social unrest.

headline: Moscow Summit: Preaching to the Unconverted; A Mighty Russian Pulpit for Reagan
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan came to Moscow determined to press the human rights issue and encourage greater change in Soviet life. But it is clear that if he pushes too hard, he runs the risk of embarrassing Mikhail S. Gorbachev and thus slowing the very transformations he wants to encourage. Nevertheless,

headline: The Media Business: Advertising; Sharp Electronics Plans Systemwide Campaign
abstract: LEAD: Sharp Electronics, the Japanese company whose unit sales of many office products top the industry, is prepared to mount a $12 million umbrella advertising campaign that for the first time will unite its business systems divisions.

headline: Rights-Abuse Charges Disputed by Colombia
abstract: LEAD: Government officials, politicians and a national human rights association today disputed a report by Amnesty International that accused the Colombian armed forces of condoning human rights abuses.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Four Promotions At DFS Compton
abstract: LEAD: Judith Damin, Stephen Dolleck, Teresa L. Gallo and Norman J. Weill have been promoted to executive vice presidents in the creative department of Saatchi & Saatchi's DFS Compton.

headline: Chock Full o'Nuts Stake Purchased
abstract: LEAD: Martin D. Gruss, the New York investor, and companies that he controls told the Securities and Exchange Commission they had purchased the equivalent of a 10 percent stake in the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation and said they might seek control of the New York-based coffee concern.

headline: Renco Set to Buy LTV Steel Plants
abstract: LEAD: The LTV Steel Company said it had signed a contract to sell its steel plant in Warren to the Renco Group Inc. of New York. Terms of the sale, which includes LTV's Republic Drainage Products Company in Canton and its six plants, were not disclosed.

headline: Sematech's Weary Hunt for a Chief
abstract: LEAD: Sematech, the ambitious industry research consortium designed to restore the ability of the American semiconductor industry to compete with the Japanese, is having difficulties finding a chief executive.

headline: Million Black Workers Boycott South Africa Jobs
abstract: LEAD: More than a million blacks stayed away from work today at the start of a three-day nationwide protest called by the two biggest trade union federations against a South African Government crackdown on anti-apartheid groups in February.

headline: Tokyo Journal; Making the Grade in College: Major in Table Tennis
abstract: LEAD: When Hiroshi Yamamoto goes for his first job interview and is asked what he did in four years of college, he plans to look his potential employer in the eye and tell him the truth: he played table tennis.

headline: Hungary Assails Rumania on Village Razings
abstract: LEAD: Hungary has charged that a vast program in Rumania to consolidate villages is intended to erase the Hungarian heritage in areas of Transylvania that were severed from Hungary after World War I. The Hungarian Foreign Ministry, which has not made a formal statement on the matter to the Rumanian Government, has given foreign reporters translations of articles from Hungary's Government-controlled press.

headline: Hungarians Hail Wide Broom Used to Sweep Out Old Guard
abstract: LEAD: Politically active Hungarians, supporters and critics of the Government, today welcomed the removal of Janos Kadar from the Communist Party leadership and expressed open elation over the sweeping character of what some called a ''housecleaning.''

headline: MARKET PLACE; Automotive Parts Continue to Gain
abstract: LEAD: THE auto industry's expansion, now in its sixth year, has far exceeded analysts' expectations. Detroit's good fortunes have also helped the auto makers' suppliers, a far-flung crowd of thousands of companies, dozens of which are publicly traded.

headline: Article 597188 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers announced yesterday that it had imposed a fine of about $250,000 and other sanctions against Blinder, Robinson & Company, a Denver-based securities firm, for charging ''excessive and fraudulent markups'' on the cost of some securities.

headline: Drexel Challenges Book On Its 'Junk Bond' Role
abstract: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. has squared off against Simon & Schuster Inc. and The American Lawyer magazine in a verbal battle over a soon-to-be-published book that is highly critical of the huge investment firm.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Crystal Brands Inc., a manufacturer of sportswear and costume jewelry, said its board had approved the acquisition of Trifari Krussman & Fishel Inc., the jewelry unit of Hallmark Cards Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; PEOPLE MAGAZINE HAS DEAL WITH WALT DISNEY
abstract: LEAD: People magazine, one of the Time Inc. stable, has made a two-pronged money-making deal with the Walt Disney Company pegged to Mickey Mouse's 60th birthday.

headline: Stocks Fall Broadly as Dow Drops 20.62
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices retreated broadly yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.62 points, to 2,054.59.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Amev N.V., the Netherlands, a diversified financial services company whose American arm is Amev Holdings Inc., said Frans Roos had retired as chairman and would be succeeded by J. L. M. (Hans) Bartelds.

headline: Ethiopia, Pressing War on Rebels, Bars Aid Workers in Drought Area
abstract: LEAD: The Ethiopian Government today ordered all foreign relief workers to immediately leave the drought-stricken provinces of Eritrea and Tigre because of its escalating war against rebels.

headline: Copyright Battle Lost by Interlego
abstract: LEAD: The Danish makers of Lego toy bricks lost a four-year legal battle to stop Tyco Toys Inc. of Moorestown, N.J., from making Lego-like products. A British court dismissed an appeal by Denmark's Interlego A/S of a Hong Kong court ruling on copyright infringement. ''This is a tremendously significant victory for the company,'' Tyco's general counsel, Michael Kennedy, said in New

headline: Leaks at Bhopal Reported
abstract: LEAD: Minor acid leaks from a storage tank at the Union Carbide Corporation's closed plant at Bhopal, India, were detected on two days this week, the Press Trust of India reported today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Travel Fox Assignment Back at Original Shop
abstract: LEAD: For a while there it looked as if Kirschenbaum & Bond had taken on both the Travel Fox and Jump brands of athletic shoes by Hongson. The brands had been handled by Hall & Cederquist.

headline: Out of the Barrio and Into the Mainstream
abstract: LEAD: BUSINESSES owned by Hispanics are now moving out of Latin neighborhoods and into the mainstream, especially in cities with large Hispanic populations. According to the United States Hispanic Chamber of Commerce, Hispanic businesses numbered about 340,000 last year and had revenues of about $20 billion.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Aequitron Medical Inc., Minneapolis, a maker of medical electronic equipment, said George A. Jackson, chairman, president and chief executive, plans to resign. He will remain chairman until a successor is named. He will then continue as a director.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Two Vice Chairmen Named at Thompson
abstract: LEAD: The J. Walter Thompson Company, which has been struggling along of late without a vice chairman, has been given two by its chairman and chief executive, Burton J. Manning. The former executive vice presidents are particularly important because they will serve in place of a chief operating officer.

headline: Tax Watch; A Stressful Time For Taxpayers
abstract: LEAD: DESPITE all the confusion and worry over the numerous changes wrought by the Tax Reform Act of 1986, taxpayers and accountants appear to be weathering this tax-filing season in better psychological shape than might have been expected.

headline: Syrians Delay Move in Beirut
abstract: LEAD: The Syrian Army delayed its deployment in southern Beirut today while Syrian and Iranian officials met in Damascus to discuss ways to avert a head-on collision between the Syrians and the Iranian-backed Party of God.

headline: Algerians Say Talks On Hijacked Jetliner Appear Deadlocked
abstract: LEAD: Negotiations for the release of the crew and passengers of the Kuwaiti Boeing 747 airliner hijacked 13 days ago seem to have reached an impasse, and Algerian officials expressed exasperation today at the deadlock.

headline: A RETAIL BATTLE OF TITANS ENDS
abstract: LEAD: Following are the highlights of the battle for Federated Stores waged between Macy and Campeau.  Jan. 25, 1988: Campeau Corporation of Canada begins a $4.2 billion, $47-a-share takeover bid for Federated Department Stores Inc.  Jan. 26: Federated files suit in Columbus, Ohio, seeking to block the Campeau tender offer.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Applied Solar Energy Corp., City of Industry, Calif., a maker of photovoltaic devices, said Arthur Douglas Ritchie, executive vice president and chief operating officer, had resigned for personal reasons. A replacement has not yet been named.

headline: Hewlett-Packard In Zenith Accord
abstract: LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would purchase and market a version of the Zenith Data Systems' Supersport 286 Model 20, a battery-operated portable computer based on the 80286 microprocessor of the Intel Corporation. Terms were not disclosed, but Hewlett-Packard said the accord was an extension of a relationship under which it has provided support for Zenith Data Systems, a subsidiary of the Zenith Electronics

headline: TUNISIAN FORESEES A GRAND ALLIANCE
abstract: LEAD: Ismail Khelil, the Central Bank Governor, deals not from crystal balls, but he does have a dream that one day the poor nations of North Africa will be linked economically by their own version of the European Community.

headline: Alco Receives McKesson Bid
abstract: LEAD: The McKesson Corporation today topped an earlier bid by indicating its intent to offer $30 a common share in cash, or about $510 million in all, for the Alco Health Services Corporation, a drug wholesaler based in Valley Forge, Pa.

headline: Texas Air Faces Official Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Texas Air is facing a Government inquiry into its financial condition and its compliance with safety standards. Texas Air, the nation's largest airline company, said there was ''no credible basis'' for challenging it on safety issues. The company also said that it believed political pressure from labor unions had led to the investigation.

headline: U.S. Signs a U.N. Document That Seeks an End to Torture
abstract: LEAD: The United States today signed a United Nations document deploring torture. The document, known as the Convention Against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, was adopted by the General Assembly in 1984.

headline: Staley Continental
abstract: LEAD: Staley Continental Inc., the corn syrup maker based in Rolling Meadows, Ill., urged its stockholders not to tender shares to Tate & Lyle P.L.C. until its board had reviewed the British company's increased offer of $35 a share. Tate & Lyle, Britain's second-largest sugar producer, raised its unsolicited offer by $3 a share on Wednesday.

headline: POPE, IN URUGUAY, GIVES HIS BACKING TO POLISH STRIKES
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II today voiced his full approval of strikes by Polish workers, insisting that the crisis in his homeland could be solved only through fundamental political changes leading to democracy.

headline: Iraq Says It Repulsed Offensive
abstract: LEAD: Iran and Iraq today both reported heavy fighting in northeastern Iraq where Iran mounted an offensive this week. The two sides also reported new Iraqi missile attacks on Teheran, the Iranian capital.

headline: Israeli Court to Hear Arab-American's Appeal
abstract: LEAD: Israel's High Court turned down prosecution and defense requests today and ordered that Mubarak E. Awad, a Palestinian-American advocate of nonviolence, be kept in jail for two weeks until a hearing can be held on his expulsion.

headline: Company News; Texas Air to Consider Restructuring Eastern
abstract: LEAD: The Texas Air Corporation's chairman, Frank Lorenzo, said yesterday that the company was studying ways to restructure its troubled Eastern Airlines subsidiary but had no plans to sell the operation.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * James H. Feeney and Edward D. Ricci have been named executive vice presidents at Ally & Gargano, where James H. Hanzlik and John McFadden have been named senior vice presidents.

headline: GORBACHEV AND AFGHAN LEADER SAY WAY SEEMS CLEAR TO START SOVIET TROOP PULLOUT BY MAY 15
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union and Afghanistan said today that they believed the last barriers to a negotiated settlement of the war in Afghanistan had been eliminated.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Armtek Corp., New Haven, Conn., a maker of automotive and industrial products, said its board approved the sale would sell of its Armstrong tire subsidiary to the Italian tire maker Pirelli for $190 million.

headline: Arafat Regaining Supremacy in Embattled Beirut
abstract: LEAD: Five years after they were routed by opponents within the Palestine Liberation Organization, guerrillas loyal to the P.L.O. chairman, Yasir Arafat, are regaining supremacy in refugee districts in Lebanon.

headline: Reagans' Dinner in Moscow Draws Diverse Soviet Crowd
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, entertained Mikhail S. Gorbachev, his wife, Raisa, and a variety of Soviet officials, artists and athletes tonight with dinner at the American Ambassador's residence here.

headline: Panama War of Nerves: A Risk of Overreaction
abstract: LEAD: In resisting the State Department's push for stronger action to force Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power in Panama, the Defense Department is warning that military restraint is needed if other forms of American pressure are to be effective.

headline: Stock Prices Rise Sharply
abstract: LEAD: The stock market soared, surprising experts. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 74.68 points, or 3.82 percent, to close at 2,031.12. Page D1.

headline: Chief Named at Infinity
abstract: LEAD: The Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, a New York-based concern that owns several radio stations, said yesterday that its board had named Mel Karmazin president and chief executive of the company. Mr. Karmazin succeeds Gerald Carrus as president. The company said Mr. Karmazin's position as chief executive, a newly created position, would include responsibilities that he has held for for some time.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Fed May Limit Check Fees
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board agreed today to consider barring banks from charging a fee for honoring checks on the same day they are presented for payment.

headline: Japanese Arrested by Manila Is Said to Plot Toronto Raid
abstract: LEAD: A suspected Japanese guerrilla captured in the Philippines last week had been setting up a base for attacks on the economic summit conference in Toronto and the Olympic Games in Seoul, a Japanese Embassy official said today.

headline: Talking Deals; The CBS Rumors On Network Sale
abstract: LEAD: FROM book publishers to cable television stations to magazine groups, media properties are high on the takeover target list these days. But for many of these deals there are no textbook examples and coming up with a price tag that both sides view as fair is difficult.

headline: Cambodia Conscripting Border Labor
abstract: LEAD: SITE 2, Thailand, March 29 -

headline: Blockers Gets Permit
abstract: LEAD: CA. Blockers Inc. said today that the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms had granted the company's Keeney Tobacco Corporation a tax permit allowing it to make and sell cigarettes. The company said it would now be able to start production of its cigarette containing the additive N-Bloctin, which is intended to block the cancer-causing action of nitrosamines from cigarette smoke.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Famous Amos Cookies Sold
abstract: LEAD: The Baer family of Denver said today that it had acquired the Famous Amos Chocolate Chip Cookie Corporation for undisclosed terms. Wally Amos, the former Hollywood agent who opened his first cookie store in 1975, will remain a significant shareholder and director.

headline: PATENTS; Toy Robot Developed
abstract: LEAD: A toy robot was patented this week for Marvin Glass & Associates, Chicago. The human-shaped robot carries tiny vehicles that fit in its head, torso or limbs. Patent 4,740,187 was obtained by Russell G. Rasmussen and Harry Disko. The robot has been manufactured by a licensee under the trade name Matchbox.

headline: The Export Edge
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Iran Says Iraqi Missile Killed 15 in Holy City
abstract: LEAD: Fifteen civilians were killed when an Iraqi missile hit the Iranian holy city of Qum early today, according to the Iranian news agency.

headline: Senate Acts Against Mexico Over Drugs
abstract: LEAD: The Senate voted tonight to impose sanctions against Mexico on the ground that it had failed to cooperate fully with the United States in halting the drug traffic across its borders.

headline: Ex-Hostage Urges Dealing to Free Captives
abstract: LEAD: A former hostage said today that he and two other Frenchmen were freed by captors in Lebanon because the public pressured France to negotiate with Iran, and he urged Americans and Britons to put the same kind of pressure on their Governments.

headline: Car Bombing Kills 4 In Southern Beirut; 2 Syrians Wounded
abstract: LEAD: A car bomb exploded today in the predominantly Shiite Moslem southern suburbs of Beirut, killing 4 people and wounding at least 20 more, including 2 Syrian soldiers.

headline: Inquiries Into Crazy Eddie Find False Financial Data
abstract: LEAD: The new management of Crazy Eddie Inc. has disclosed that Federal criminal and civil investigations have found that all the company's financial statements before last November are inaccurate.

headline: U.S. Says Afghan Insurgents Have Captured Strategic City
abstract: LEAD: State Department officials today reported heavy fighting in Afghanistan and said the guerrillas there had apparently captured a second provincial capital.

headline: 200 Hurt in Protests on Taiwan
abstract: LEAD: More than 200 people were injured and scores were arrested on Friday night during battles between police officers and rock-throwing demonstrators, the police said today.

headline: Tate & Lyle Adds $3 To Its Offer for Staley
abstract: LEAD: Tate & Lyle P.L.C. raised its offer today for Staley Continental Inc. to 1.42 billion, or $35 a share.

headline: T.W.A. to Add McDonnell Planes
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., said that the airline would acquire $500 million worth of McDonnell Douglas Corporation MD-80 aircraft. Mr, Icahn said T.W.A. was in the final stages of negotiations and should soon announce an order for 20 to 25 MD-80 jets. Mr. Icahn made the statement while discussing T.W.A.

headline: Belfast Journal; The Laurels of Peace Were Green (for a Season)
abstract: LEAD: When the two Nobel laureates lost their aura a decade ago and the throngs of peace marchers drifted away from the ghettos, there was no shortage of critics to gloat over the failure of ''the fur coat brigade.''

headline: McDonnell Sued by U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The Government has joined in a lawsuit contending that the McDonnell Douglas Corporation overcharged the Army by as much as $175 million in developing the Apache attack helicopter.

headline: NATO Talks Shift to Brussels As Danes Call Vote on A-Arms
abstract: LEAD: The Danish Government said today that NATO nuclear planning talks scheduled for next week would be switched from Denmark to Brussels because Denmark has called an early election over the question of allowing nuclear weapons in its ports.

headline: Quake Jolts Greek Island
abstract: LEAD: An earthquake registering 5 on the Richter scale shook the Greek island of Kefallonia on Monday, the Athens Seismological Institute reported. The epicenter of the quake was in the Ionian Sea, 185 miles northwest of Athens. No casualties or damage were reported.

headline: U.S. Links Men in Bomb Case To Lebanon Terrorist Group
abstract: LEAD: Three men arrested last October as they tried to bring a bomb into the United States are members of a Lebanon-based terrorist group and were planning an attack in America, law-enforcement officials said today.

headline: Option Cost Rise Sought
abstract: LEAD: In response to increased volatility experienced during the October market collapse, the Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that it had proposed raising margins on its equity and index options.

headline: A Broadway Impresario Whose Hit Is Food
abstract: LEAD: Steven W. Jenkins has a food attitude. He can't stand little jars of jelly with gingham around the lid. Factory-made cheeses make him moan. Ask for fresh ''bazzle'' rather than ''baysil'' and he will charge you an additional 10 cents a bunch for what he considers your mispronunciation.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Kill One Arab And Wound 8 in Gaza Rallies
abstract: LEAD: Israeli troops killed a Palestinian and wounded eight others in the Gaza Strip today during stone-throwing protests against Israeli rule, residents said.

headline: MACMILLAN REVAMPING IS BLOCKED
abstract: LEAD: A Delaware Chancery Court judge yesterday temporarily blocked a planned restructuring by Macmillan Inc. as it was about to begin.

headline: Trade Bill Options: Pass, Fail or Punt
abstract: LEAD: For the last 15 years, Representative William D. Ford, whose constituents are blue-collar and white-collar auto and steel workers in the western suburbs of Detroit, has been trying to legislate prior notice of factory shutdowns or layoffs.

headline: Article 626188 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The 11-week battle for control of Federated Department Stores Inc. will produce one of the biggest paydays Wall Street has ever seen. Investment banks and law firms expect to collect at least $200 million.

abstract: LEAD:           THE ECONOMY               Gross National Product   I Q'88   IV Q'87   Year Ago        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $4,668.7   $3,880.8   $3,735.2               Real G.N.P. headline: Advertising; Esquire Ads Poke Fun at Nonreaders
abstract: LEAD: WHILE working for their new client, Esquire magazine, Richard Kirshenbaum, 26 years old, and Jonathan Bond, 30, founders of the Kirshenbaum & Bond agency, came to the conclusion that describing the wondrous but complex Esquire Man would be too difficult for mere mortals. Instead they will use Esquire's promotional advertising to say what he is not.

headline: A Japanese View of World War II Is Attacked
abstract: LEAD: A Cabinet minister's declaration last week that Japan was not an aggressor in World War II has brought expressions of outrage from Japan's Asian neighbors.

headline: 18 Drown in Bay of Bengal
abstract: LEAD: At least 18 fishermen drowned Saturday after their boats capsized in the Bay of Bengal off the port of Chittagong, The Bangladesh Observer reported today.

headline: Ethiopia's President Admits the Rebels Are Forcing 'Grim Battles'
abstract: LEAD: In a rare acknowledgment of the growing threat posed by rebels, President Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia said today that Government forces were fighting ''grim battles'' against insurgents in the northern provinces of Eritrea and Tigre, Radio Ethiopia reported.

headline: Filipinos Fill The Visa Line To Get to U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Late one recent night, after a week of surveillance, the Manila police rounded up 55 suspicious people who had been sleeping under the tropical baliti trees outside the United States Embassy.

headline: Seoul to Pay for More of U.S. Military Cost
abstract: LEAD: South Korea agreed today to pay for more of its own defense and the United States agreed to deploy additional American forces during the Olympic Games to ward off terrorism.

headline: Gorbachev Aide Urges an Alternative to the Party
abstract: LEAD: A key adviser to Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for creation of a nationwide ''popular front'' that would be a political alternative to the Communist Party.

headline: Deposed Haitian Chief Lands In Miami and Pleads for Aid
abstract: LEAD: Leslie F. Manigat, who was ousted as Haiti's President on Sunday, arrived today and appealed to the United States to back his effort to mobilize opposition to the military leader who deposed him.

headline: Your Money; Power of Attorney Fills Many Needs
abstract: LEAD: WHEN Richard and Lee Allan returned to their Manhattan apartment last Sunday evening, they found a disturbing message on their telephone-answering machine: a resident at the hospice of St. Vincent's Hospital, where Mrs. Allan works, had taken a turn for the worse. Could Mr. Allan, a professor at Brooklyn Law

headline: Top U.S. Bond Yield Rises to 9.34%
abstract: LEAD: Treasury securities dealers marked down prices of bills, notes and bonds yesterday in a largely futile effort to attract investors. While the mood was decidedly bearish, dealers noted that sellers were almost as scarce as buyers.

headline: S.E.C. Said To Broaden Its Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission is examining securities trading records at six brokerage firms in its insider trading investigation of an investor from Taiwan and a young Wall Street analyst, people with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday.

headline: Arkansas Best Suitor Gets Takeover Lesson
abstract: LEAD: Emanuel R. Pearlman, the would-be acquirer of the Arkansas Best Corporation, had been in the takeover business all of 48 hours when he got a strong dose of what lies ahead. The target company ignored his phone calls. The newspapers gave his $230 million deal short shrift. And he balks at the suggestion that he is a corporate raider.

headline: IN TIME FOR SUMMIT MEETING
abstract: LEAD: After four months of political infighting and debate, the Senate today gave President Reagan a victory he had been waiting for: an overwhelming vote of approval for the treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles based on land.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  Security Council  Meets at 10:30 A.M. on Tunisian complaint against Israel.  Economic and Social Council  CHILDREN'S FUND - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Irving Takeover Fight Unresolved
abstract: LEAD: As the deadlines draw near for the Bank of New York Company's hostile bid for the Irving Bank Corporation, neither company shows signs of giving up.

headline: Bank Fraud Guilty Plea
abstract: LEAD: Edwin L. Cox Jr., the son of a Dallas business leader and a former operator of farming, cattle and energy ventures, said today that he would plead guilty to Federal fraud charges involving an $80 million loan from a forerunner of the First Republicbank Corporation.

headline: Beijing Sends Out Police to Thwart Student Protest
abstract: LEAD: The authorities sent hundreds of policemen onto the streets of the capital today to thwart a threatened protest march by Beijing University students to the city center.

headline: Majority Stake Bought In Hasselbart & Mitten
abstract: LEAD: Leo J. LeFort, William C. Waldman and John Ragsdale, the key executives of Hasselbart & Mitten Advertising and Arocom Marketing Group of Fairlawn, Ohio, which collectively bill more than $50 million, have acquired the majority interest in the companies from the estate of the late Robert Mitten, founder and chief executive, who died in

headline: Leveraged Buyout Of Lumex Studied
abstract: LEAD: Cincinnati-based Surgical Appliance Industries, which holds a 9.3 percent stake in Lumex Inc., said today that it is considering a possible leveraged buyout of the company. Lumex manufactures heath-care and rehabilitation equipment from its headquarters in Bay Shore, L.I.

headline: Guerrillas in Colombia Kidnap Five Foreigners
abstract: LEAD: Leftist guerrillas kidnapped four foreigners today and took responsibility for the kidnapping of a French diplomat, officials said.

headline: Raise Oil and Gas Prices Now
abstract: LEAD: WE need to pay greater attention to the strategic value of America's oil and gas resources. Energy users must conserve. Producers, transporters, distributors and regulators must run more efficient industries. And owners must exert more responsibility to be sure domestic resources are managed better.

headline: Lawyer Guilty In Note Scheme
abstract: LEAD: A French lawyer has been convicted in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges of trying to sell worthless Indonesian promissory notes to an undercover New York City detective, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said.

headline: Chip Maker's Stock Is Heavily Traded
abstract: LEAD: Shares of the National Semiconductor Corporation, a computer chip and systems manufacturer, were heavily traded on Wall Street after a mutual fund group disclosed that it owns 5.3 percent of the company's stock. While the stock price for National Semiconductor, based in Santa Clara, Calif., closed only 12.5 cents higher, at $13.375, on the New York Stock

headline: Wroclaw Journal; Police Draw the Curtain, but the Farce Still Plays
abstract: LEAD: In this city of brick churches and provincial purposefulness, the streets and the public imagination have been seized by a street theater group called the Orange Alternative. The Communist authorities' reaction has been to ask, ''But is it art?''

headline: Canada Plans New Ministry
abstract: LEAD: The Canadian Government, moving to bolster the country's research efforts, has introduced in Parliament a bill to establish a new ''superministry'' to promote development of science and technology.

headline: Iceland Currency Halt
abstract: LEAD: Iceland's central bank stopped all foreign currency transactions today as the Government began talks on a devaluation, Government officials said. They said the freeze was necessary because of increasing currency speculation amid rumors that the currency, the crown, would be devalued.

headline: Tractor Sales Are Rolling Again
abstract: LEAD: This is planting season in the upper Midwest, and for the first time in years Neil Horning is having trouble supplying all the tractors and other equipment that farmers need to get their crops in.

headline: Violent Clash in Bangladesh
abstract: LEAD: The police clashed today with demonstrators protesting a constitutional amendment that made Islam the state religion. The authorities said 50 people suffered minor injuries. The demonstrations coincided with a one-day strike called to protest the new law, passed Tuesday by Parliament and signed into law by President H.

headline: Ambitious Eradication Goals and Withering Obstacles
abstract: LEAD: Perhaps the most ambitious goal of a Cabinet-level internal report on drug strategies is to cut in half coca leaf production in Latin America over the next five years.

headline: Machine-Tool Orders Down 14.6% in March
abstract: LEAD: Orders for American-made machine tools fell 14.6 percent in March from the previous month, to $254.40 million, according to a report scheduled to be released today by the industry's trade association.

headline: STOCKS REBOUND AND DOW RISES BY 25.24
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rebounded yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 25.24 points, to 2,109.17.

headline: Thatcher Is Challenged On Gibraltar Shootings
abstract: LEAD: Amnesty International has demanded additional details from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on the shooting of three unarmed Irish terrorist suspects in Gibraltar by the British Army.

headline: ONE STRIKE ENDS, BUT 2D POLISH MILL REMAINS CRIPPLED
abstract: LEAD: Pressure eased on the Government of Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today after workers at the steel and armaments plant here accepted a Government pay offer and ended a one-day strike.

headline: Beazer Cites Tally Of Koppers Shares
abstract: LEAD: The British building group Beazer P.L.C. said that it had been offered more than half the shares of the Koppers Company, the Pittsburgh-based construction materials concern, under a hostile takeover offer of $1.7 billion. But a United States District Court order is keeping Beazer from acquiring the shares, a company spokesman said.

headline: Stock Exchange Loses Economist to Kaufman
abstract: LEAD: Roger Kubarych, who became chief economist at the New York Stock Exchange two years ago, has left to become an economics analyst with Henry Kaufman & Company, a consulting firm.

headline: Mid-April Vehicle Sales Rose by 1.9%
abstract: LEAD: Mid-April sales of new American-made cars and light trucks rose 1.9 percent from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

headline: U.S. BARS PROPOSAL TO LIMIT ACID RAIN
abstract: LEAD: On the eve of a visit by Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, the Administration has rejected a proposal that the United States limit the flow of nitrogen oxide pollution across the border to Canada, Administration officials said today.

headline: Jacobs Offers To Buy Minstar
abstract: LEAD: Irwin L. Jacobs, the chairman and chief executive of Minstar Inc., has made good on earlier hints that he would take the company private by offering $29 a share, or about $369 million.

headline: Salvador Rebels Turning to Civilian Targets
abstract: LEAD: Leftist guerrillas appear to have hardened their tactics in recent days by killing a mayor and two other civilians and warning that they will attack other civilian targets.

headline: Spanish-Language TV: An Even Better Reception
abstract: LEAD: SPANISH-LANGUAGE radio and television stations have proliferated steadily over the years. Now, through an influx of corporate advertising money, such stations are becoming more profitable and are giving non-Hispanic stations and networks competition.

headline: New Yorkers & Co.; The Profit Motive Was Not Motivation
abstract: LEAD: After a string of jobs in the public sector stretching over two decades, Peter C. Goldmark jumped across the line into private business in 1986 to take a senior management job with the Times Mirror Company. Now, after only two years, he is leaping back out of it, this time to experience the world of private, nonprofit organizations as president of the Rockefeller

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, said its board had adopted a defense against hostile takeover bids. BankAmerica said the plan would give holders of each common share the right to buy one-hundredth of a share of a new series of preferred stock at an exercise price of $50.

headline: Patents; Chewing Gum Candy
abstract: LEAD: Chewing gum candy, to be prepared by mixing a chewing gum base with candy syrup, was patented this week for the Warner-Lambert Company of Morris Plains, N.J. Robert Huzinec, a former research scientist with the company, was granted patent 4,741,905. A company spokesman said that the product was not yet being commercially marketed.

headline: Sassy: Like, You Know, for Kids
abstract: LEAD: Can a new magazine that uses teen-age jargon and focuses on subjects ranging from sex, makeup and clothes to sex, makeup and clothes make it in today's market? The answer so far appears to be yes.

headline: Alabama Power To Offer Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The Alabama Power Company is offering $150 million in first-mortgage bonds due in 2018, won in a bidding by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley & Company.

headline: Glaxo Holdings Picks Chairman of U.S. Unit
abstract: LEAD: A management succession that began two years ago wound up yesterday with Dr. Ernest Mario taking over as chairman and chief executive of Glaxo Holdings Inc., a pharmaceutical company that has become the fourth largest in the United States in terms of retail pharmacy sales.

headline: Paraguay Rebuff 'Astonishes' Vatican
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican expressed ''astonishment'' today at Paraguay's cancellation of a papal encounter with civic leaders as tensions continued to build between the Roman Catholic Church and the Paraguayan leader, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner.

headline: A Buffeted First Boston Regroups
abstract: LEAD: After a lengthy strategy review and stormy internecine feuding, Peter T. Buchanan, First Boston's chief executive, announced on Jan. 21, ''There will be no fundamental change in First Boston's strategic direction.''

headline: U.S. Vehicle Sales Post 11% Rise
abstract: LEAD: Late March sales of American-made cars and light trucks were up about 11 percent from the comparable period last year, the eight domestic manufacturers reported today.

headline: Economic Scene; Paying for Failure Of Savings Units
abstract: LEAD: WILL the Federal Home Loan Bank Board be able to raise enough cash to keep the savings and loan industry afloat? The liquidation this week of two relatively small California thrift institutions, at a cost of $1.35 billion, did not dampen the regulators' upbeat rhetoric. Bank board insiders still argue that, with a little luck, the net cost of closing or merging insolvent savings and loan associations can be kept to $25 billion.

headline: Jordan, McGrath Tries Unusual Magazine Ad
abstract: LEAD: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor has come up with an imaginative concept for its client Procter & Gamble's Bounty Microwave towels that is intended to attract reader attention in the cluttered environment of women's service magazines.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Amerace Corp., Hackettstown, N.J., a maker of electrical cable, connectors and component devices, named its chief executive, Joseph J. Incandela, to the additional post of chairman. He is succeeding Thomas Shepherd, who will continue as a director and chairman of the the executive committee.

headline: DeBartolo and Bilzerian Under S.E.C. Scrutiny
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether Edward J. DeBartolo Sr., the nation's largest developer of shopping centers, secretly aided takeover bids by the Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian by buying shares on his behalf and providing other support.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.          Monday        U.S. Productivity   First Quarter (rev.)        Tuesday        Consumer Credit   April        Wednesday        None        Tursday        None        Friday        Producer Prices   May

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:  The Economy

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Walker Scotch Ads: Image Is All
abstract: LEAD: FOR the first time in memory, Johnnie Walker Red will go through the fall and holiday season without advertising support.

headline: Afghan President Plans Visit To Arms Conference at U.N.
abstract: LEAD: The Afghan leader, Najibullah, will come to New York next month for a General Assembly session on disarmament, a United Nations official said today.

headline: Brooke Partners Sets 2 Offerings
abstract: LEAD: Brooke Partners L.P. is offering $160 million in 13 1/2 percent senior subordinated reset notes due in 1997 at par through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

headline: Gaza Woman Dies After Tear Gas Attack on Home
abstract: LEAD: A 70-year-old Palestinian woman died after a tear gas canister was tossed into her Gaza Strip home by Israeli soldiers today, according to army and other reports.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Richard H. Anderson, Diana F. Kramer and Frederick P. Massin, have been promoted to executive vice presidents of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton.

headline: Both Sides Confident At Gillette
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of Gillette Company shareholders turned out for an annual meeting today to vote in a proxy contest that is viewed as a referendum on the company's future.

headline: U.S. Trying New Tack To Undermine Noriega
abstract: LEAD: Reagan Administration officials, disappointed over their failure to dislodge Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as Panama's leader, said today that they were now aiming their efforts at weakening his hold on the loyalty of the military.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: Boeing Canada, Downsview, Ontario, a unit of Boeing Co., said its de Havilland division had received an order for eight turboprop aircraft worth about $90 million (Canadian) from Air Atlantic.

headline: Rolls-Royce U.S. Sales
abstract: LEAD: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said today that United States sales of its Rolls-Royce and Bentley luxury cars jumped 6.4 percent in the first four months of the year. The British company's American subsidiary said it had sold 349 cars in the United States, up from 328 in the corresponding period a year ago.

headline: Human-Powered Craft Makes Test Flights in Mythic Quest
abstract: LEAD: A lightweight human-powered aircraft made a successful series of test flights today in preparation for a world-record distance attempt that also will recreate the mythical flight of Daedalus.

headline: Trans-Atlantic Fares Are Cut
abstract: LEAD: British Airways and Virgin Atlantic Airways began a price war today when they cut trans-Atlantic fares from London to increase sales in Britain.

headline: Illinois Gas Utility
abstract: LEAD: The Northern Illinois Gas Company, a unit of Nicor Inc., is offering $75 million of 9 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds due in 1996 at a price of 99.55 to yield 9.331 percent. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets is the lead manager for the offering, priced to yield about 55- hundredths of a percentage point more than Treasury securities of similar maturity.

headline: U.S. AND NORIEGA HELD NEAR ACCORD ON HIS RESIGNATION
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Panama have worked out the outline of an agreement by which Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, would relinquish power but might be allowed to continue to live in Panama, senior Administration officials said today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Combination in London
abstract: LEAD: In London, the recently formed alliance of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, a giant in the United States, and Publicis Communications, a huge French company, will create a new entity by merging FCB/ London with Mallett McCormick, one of two Publicis agencies in that city. The result will be Foote, Cone & Belding/ MM.

headline: U.S.-Mexican Talks on Debt Are Expected
abstract: LEAD: President Miguel de la Madrid will meet next week with the United States Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d, and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to discuss Mexico's debt crisis and related economic problems, Mexican and foreign officials said today.

headline: Palestinians Stage General Strike, But the Territories Remain Quiet
abstract: LEAD: Palestinians in Israel's occupied territories staged a general strike today, and all Arab businesses were closed. But the West Bank and Gaza Strip were quiet this weekend, even though Israelis and Palestinians alike warned that there was likely to be large-scale violence.

headline: Beazer in Pact On Koppers
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of Beazer P.L.C., the British company that this week struck a deal to acquire the Koppers Company, signed a statement today that he would keep Koppers in Pittsburgh.

headline: A Higher Net Is Expected at 3M
abstract: LEAD: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company expects its second-quarter earnings to exceed last year's levels, its chairman, Allen F. Jacobson said, while warning that its growth could slow later this year. The 3M Company's earnings should exceed the $240 million, or $1.05 share, report for the second quarter of 1987, he said.

headline: Market Place; Analysts Size Up Specialty Insurers
abstract: LEAD: WITH the stock market unable to gain much momentum above the Dow industrials' 2,000 level, diehard investors are being forced to search further afield for stocks to buy. Specialty insurers are among those that some analysts and investors say deserve more attention.

headline: Self Magazine Editor Is Named
abstract: LEAD: Anthea Disney, editor of US magazine, has been named editor in chief of Self magazine effective July 5, Conde Nast Publications Inc., Self's parent, announced yesterday.

headline: Pro-Guerrilla Senator Urges President to Reject Afghan Pact
abstract: LEAD: A United States Senator who is a leading supporter of the Afghan guerrillas called on President Reagan today to reject the emerging peace agreement.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Melitta Ads Offer 'Coffee Perfection'
abstract: LEAD: MELITTA Region North America, based in Cherry Hill, N.J., is the United States marketer of West German-made premium drip coffee makers, filters and a coffee, which it considers a rare, and perhaps unique, combination.

headline: Carter Oil Tax Hangs by a Thread
abstract: LEAD: It will be the end of the line for one of the most vigorously debated pieces of legislation of the Carter Administration, the 1980 Crude Oil Windfall Profit Tax, if President Reagan signs Congress's omnibus trade bill.

headline: Spiegel President Sees Bauer as a 'Great Fit'
abstract: LEAD: John J. Shea, president and chief executive of Spiegel Inc., sees a ''great fit'' of the Eddie Bauer specialty retail operation with Spiegel's catalogue enterprise.

headline: Coated Sales Faces Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: Coated Sales Inc. disclosed today that its internal investigation had uncovered a $6 million overstatement on its most recent financial statement.

headline: Suspect in Bombing Is Released, Angering Both Britain and Ireland
abstract: LEAD: The Irish and British Governments were angry, confused and critical today over the latest failure of their efforts to establish workable extradition procedures for terrorism suspects.
